proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: War and Violence Related Toys, Games and Video Games
petition.para: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that
They are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country.
They believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: that the senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games, and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

petition.title: Preservation of the Environment
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:-

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:-

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserved Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Joint Select Committee on Video Material
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned,

Note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

Call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We, the undersigned,
(a) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(b) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(c) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Radio Station 2JJJ: Broadcast to the Canberra Region
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in the Parliament assembled; The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully support the demand:

That the A.B.C. radio station 2JJJ signal be relayed and broadcast to the Canberra region, on stereo FM, round the clock, commencing as soon as possible. (There is currently no existing FM radio station in Canberra, offering alternative commercial-free stereo music.)

petition.title: National AIDS Program
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are offended and outraged by the direction of the AIDS Programme in Tasmania, in that it actively promotes Homosexual Acts and in particular anal intercourse, and that taxpayers money is being used to fund literature which directly promotes homosexual behaviour as a normal and desirable human activity.

Your petitioners therefore urgently and strongly request that the Federal Government and the Minister for Health review the National AIDS Programme and withdraw funding for this literature, and from any other aspects of the AIDS Campaign which encourages or condones anal intercourse.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: The Last Temptation of Christ
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That we strongly object to the contents of the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ''
2. That the film is blasphemous, grossly offensive and obnoxious
And your petitioners pray that the Senate take all necessary steps to require the Film Censorship Board to prohibit the release of this film for showing or sale in Australia
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Funding
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are
1. Opposed to the Government's decision to cut funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth year in succession;
2. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these funding cuts in terms of reductions in staff numbers and research capacity;

3. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these cuts on rural research in Queensland and on the long term economic well being of the rural sector, which makes a significant contribution to Australia's export income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Dear Minister,

At its meeting of 25 August 1988, the Committee considered the Interpretation (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 36 of 1988, tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee draws your attention to section 19 which provides for the amendment of section 50 of the Principal Ordinance. Paragraph (a) of section 19 reads in part:
``(b) the regulations shall take effect-
(i) if the regulations so provide-
(C) on the commencement of a specified Ordinance or a specified provision of an Ordinance;''

The wording of (b) (i) (C) is identical with the wording used in the original form of the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act that was proposed in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987. That original wording was the subject of the Committee's Eighty-Second Report. In that Report, the Committee said, in relation to the equivalent clause in the Bill, the following:

``Proposed subparagraph 48 (1) (b) (iii) would enable regulations to take effect from the commencement of a specified Act or a specified provision of an Act. The committee was concerned that under this amendment regulations could be expressed to take effect from the commencement of a specified Act that was already in force, thereby lawfully imposing retrospective liability. Since such regulations would not be expressed to take effect from a date before the date of notification but rather from the commencement of an Act, the Committee considered that subsection 48 (2) might not apply to prevent retrospective regulations taking effect.''
Following the Committee's comments and concerns, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, agreed to amend the legislation to read as follows:
``(b) shall, subject to this section take effect from:
(iii) the date, or date and time, of commencement of a specified Act or a specified provision of an Act; or''.

The Committee's concerns in relation to the amendment in this Ordinance are identical to those expressed in the Eighty-Second Report. The Committee would welcome your views in relation to this important matter.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins

Dear Bob

I refer to your letter of 30 August 1988 to the former Minister, the Hon. Gary Punch MP, expressing your Committee's concerns with regard to subparagraph 50 (1)(b)(i)(C) of the Interpretation Ordinance 1967 inserted by section 19 of the Interpretation (Amendment) Ordinance 1988.

This amendment is one of several which reflect amendments of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 made by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1987. New paragraph 50 (1)(b) of the Interpretation Ordinance was intended to widen the range of options for commencing ACT Regulations as new paragraph 48 (1)(b) of the Acts Interpretation Act would for Commonwealth Regulations.

As you observed, subparagraph 50 (1)(b)(i)(C) of the Ordinance is in substance the same as the original form of subparagraph 48 (1)(b)(iii) of the Act as proposed in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, but the latter paragraph was altered following the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, accepting your Committee's representations.

If there is merit in the reason why the Commonwealth provision was altered, that reason will of course be equally valid in relation to the Ordinance because subsection 50 (2) of the Ordinance corresponds to subsection 48 (2) of the Act proscribing retrospective regulations that would affect existing rights prejudicially or impose liabilities in respect of past conduct. However, I suggest that as the Ordinance stands at present, on a proper construction subsection 50 (2) would prevail so that offending Regulations could not circumvent it by relying on a commencement provision that attempted to tie them to ``the commencement'' of an existing Ordinance or a provision of an existing Ordinance. On that view, such Regulations would not have to refer specifically to a particular date to be caught by the subsection; a commencement provision of the kind described should still fall as contravening the spirit of the subsection because it would still be in effect referring to a date, i.e., the date of commencement of the Ordinance or provision. In expressing this opinion, I am of course agreeing with the view expressed by Senator Tate in the second paragraph of his letter of 18 November 1987 reproduced in your Committee's eighty-second Report.

However, the matter is arguable and the fact that the Commonwealth provision has been altered is a telling factor; a court that was required to construe the ACT provision may well attach unintended significance to the difference in wording between it and its Commonwealth counterpart.
In any event, these provisions deal with the important area of parliamentary control over delegated legislation, an area where uniformity is clearly desirable.

Accordingly, I propose to arrange for the ACT provision to be amended as soon as practicable to bring it into line with the Commonwealth provision. I trust this will resolve your concerns about the matter.
Yours sincerely
(Clyde Holding)
Senator Robert Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I am writing to you about your notice of motion for disallowance of amendments of the Telecommunications (Charging Zones and Charging Districts) By-laws and the Telecommunications (Community Calls) By-laws.

I share the Committee's concerns about the handling of recent zoning and charging changes by Telecom. However, the effect of the by-laws is not to impose or authorise changes retrospectively. It is to authorise future charges, from the effective date of the by-laws, due to zoning changes that were made previously. The matter of authority for charges made prior to the date of effect of these by-laws, but subsequent to the relevant zoning changes having been put in place in practice, is a separate matter.

I understand that Senator Evans, as Minister for Transport and Communications had asked for appropriate legislation to be prepared addressing the question of retrospective authorisation, because it was just not possible to retrospectively calculate adjustments to customers accounts for this period. Nor would it have been desirable, since many customers are likely to have had reduced bills as a result of the charges and retrospective surcharges would obviously be inappropriate.
Since Senator Evans' decision, the scope of the problem has been found to be greater than first advised.

I have therefore today sought the Prime Minister's concurrence to the drafting of legislation that will embrace all instances of unauthorised zoning changes. It is my intention that the matter be resolved equitably as quickly as possible.

In addition, I have sought from Telecom a report under section 100 of the Telecommunications Act 1975 on the circumstances of this whole matter. I would be pleased to provide you with a copy of that report when it is received.
Yours sincerely

Dear Mr Brack,

At its meeting of 29 September 1988, the Committee considered Telecommunications (Charging Zones and Charging Districts) By-laws-Amendment No. 82 and Telecommunications (Community Calls) Bylaws-Amendment No. 53, tabled in the Senate on 29 August 1988.

The Committee expresses some surprise that in the Explanatory Statements supplied with the Amendments reference is made to the fact that certain changes had already come into operation with some rates being higher and some lower. As this reference related to a period prior to the coming into operation of these instruments on 1 September 1988, there is clearly prejudicial retrospectivity.

The Committee notes that reference is made to the Attorney-General's legal opinion, as supplied to the Committee on 24 August 1988, in relation to the need for enabling legislation to validate such Amendments. The Committee views the making of these Amendments with considerable concern in view of the availability of the Attorney-General's legal opinion and the fact that no validating Act has yet been considered by the Parliament.

As these Amendments will affect some subscribers in a prejudicially retrospective manner they will contravene the provisions of section 48 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The Committee seeks your advice as to the reasons for the Commission making these Amendments after being advised by the Attorney-General's Department as to the legal position of such Amendments. The Committee also seeks clarification as to the action the Commission intends to take in relation to those subscribers who have been adversely affected by the changes prior to 1 September 1988.
Yours sincerely,
BOB COLLINS
Chairman
Secretary
Senate Standing Committee
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Sir

I refer to the letter of 30 September 1988 from Senator Collins concerning Amendment No. 82 to the Telecommunications (Charging Zones and Charging Districts) By-laws and Amendment No. 53 to the Telecommunications (Community Calls) By-laws.

The changes referred to in the letter as coming into operation before the date of commencement of Amendments Nos. 82 and 53 were physical changes made to the telecommunications network before 1 September 1988 which would, because of the metering arrangements associated with the changes, have the potential to increase or decrease subscribers' payments for some telephone calls by amounts not authorised in Telecom's Tariff and By-laws at the time when the physical changes were effected.

Telecom agrees with the Committee that the failure to authorise the network changes from the date of their commencement creates a situation of retro- spectivity. As explained in previous correspondence, however, it is unable to determine whether the retrospectivity has been prejudicial to any telephone subscriber or user because the manner in which charges are recorded does not enable Telecom to determine whether there has been a net increase in the Charges billed to any subscriber as a result of the unauthorised retrospectivity or whether any user of a public telephone made trunk or community calls during the period of retrospectivity which were affected by the unauthorised metering changes.

Telecom cannot agree with the Committee that anything in the subordinate legislation under review viz. Amendments Nos. 82 and 53 will affect some subscribers in a prejudicially retrospective manner or that the amendments will contravene the provisions of section 48 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The By-laws are expressed to operate prospectively and deal with telephone calls made after the date of their making and after their gazettal on 30 August 1988 (see Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S251 p.1).

Nothing in the amendments themselves is designed or intended to deal with the unauthorised application of charging rates to telephone calls made before the date of commencement of the amendments. As noted in the explanatory memoranda to the amending By-laws and in previous correspondence, the validation of unauthorised charges made before the date on which the charges were prospectively authorised by By-law must be approved by Act.

Telecom is deeply conscious of the need to obtain validation for any network charges which have been implemented before they were authorised by By-law and has been endeavouring, since the Attorney-General's Department's advice on the subject was received on 19 August 1988, to devise in conjunction with that Department, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel a satisfactory method of validating charge rates which require retrospective authorisation. It had been hoped to introduce validating legislation in the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988 which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 28 September 1988. However, the drafting difficulties associated with the legislation and the need to ensure that all unauthorised retrospective charges had been ascertained for inclusion in the legislation made that impracticable.

The Committee's letter under reply seeks Telecom advice as to the reasons for the making of Amendments after receipt of Attorney-General's Department advice as to the legal position of such amendments. It is submitted, with respect, that nothing in that advice suggested that it would be in any way improper for Telecom to make By-laws which prospectively authorises rates of charging. The advice related firstly to whether there was a need to validate unauthorised charges if the net effect of those charges was not prejudicial to customers and secondly whether the validation should be effected by Act. As Telecom reads the advice, it relates to the need to validate the retrospective aspects of any unauthorised charges. At no time has Telecom made any By-law which had the effect of increasing individual charges and which was expressed to take effect from a date earlier than its notification in the Gazette. As noted, Amendments Nos. 82 and 53 are expressed to take effect prospectively only.

The Committee's letter also asks what action Telecom intends to take in relation to subscribers who have been adversely affected by the changes authorised in Amendments Nos. 82 and 53 in respect of any application of those changes which occurred before the date of effect of the amendments. As noted in the explanatory memoranda accompanying the amendments, validation of any premature charging involved in the amendments would be sought in conjunction with the validations which are being prepared for submission to Parliament in respect of charges detailed in Amendments Nos. 81 and 52.

Until the outcome of any validating legislation presented to Parliament is known, Telecom will be unable to determine whether any further action is required in respect of the charges. However, as noted in previous correspondence, it would be extremely difficult, in the absence of detailed records of individual subscriber trunk dialling and community call charging to provide relief for any individual subscriber and, as also noted, it is quite likely that most subscribers have not been ``out-of-pocket'' as a result of the network changes not covered by By-law amendments.

This is not to say, of course, that Telecom is not extremely concerned at the failure in its mechanisms for ensuring that network changes are authorised before new exchanges commence operation or as soon as subscribers are cutover from one exchange or zone to another. There are 1,997 telephone charging zones and 5,227 telephone exchanges in the Commonwealth. There is considerable churn within the system due to closing and opening of exchanges and zoning points. Elaborate measures are in hand to increase the level of liaison and coordination within the commercial and technical areas of the Commission with a view to ensuring that future amendments relate to prospective network changes. However I regret the Commission is not in a position to guarantee that all past network changes were picked up in the August By-law amendments i.e. there may also be future amendments to the By-laws which deal with network changes which have been implemented before the date of operation of the amendments and these would also need to be included in the validating legislation being considered by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel.

Whilst all checks have not yet been completed, it appears that the main reason for network changes being effected in advance of By-law authorisation has been that the changes related to the installation of new exchanges or zoning points. The installations occurred in existing charging zones where no variation in charging relationships between zones was involved. In those cases it appears that the field staff effecting the installations were unaware of the need to include the new exchange or point in the By-laws and that the omissions were not picked up by regional staff until after the installations were effected.

The recording of aspects of the network relating to charging considerations is now centralised in a single national computer system, CHARMS (Charging Records Maintenance System), which is responsible for allocating the area codes and blocks of exchange numbers required to operate exchanges and zoning points and which will, in future, prevent codes and blocks being allocated unless any necessary By-law authorisation has been obtained. This should prevent network changes occurring without necessary authorisation. In addition, the lines of reporting of network changes from the field are being altered to ensure that notice of planned changes is received earlier in the areas responsible for procuring By-law amendments.
Yours sincerely
R. W. Brack

Dear Minister,

At its meeting of 25 August 1988, the Committee considered Air Force Regulations (Amendment), being Statutory Rules 1988 No. 129, tabled in the Senate on 24 August 1988. The Committee seeks your advice in relation to new Regulation 65a.

The Committee's concern relates to the determination of the criteria and procedures used in the promotion of certain officers. The criteria for promotion are not set out in the Regulation but are to be ``determined, by instrument, by the Chief of the Air Staff''. Similarly, in relation to the procedures, the Chief of the Air Staff ``may, by instrument, determine the procedures for the selection of officers for promotion''.

The Committee, while understanding the need to alter the criteria and procedures used in the promotion of officers, believes that the provisions of such determinations ought to be the subject of review by the Parliament. It would appear from the wording of new Regulation 65a that such instruments are not open to Parliamentary review.

Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter to the Minister for Defence dated 30 August 1988 in which you expressed concern that the new regulation 65a of the Air Force Regulations, contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 129, does not provide for parliamentary review of instruments made under that regulation.

It might be helpful in your consideration of this matter if I set out some of the background to the new regulation 65a. Prior to the amendment, regulation 65a provided that officers were to be promoted to the rank of Squadron Leader or above in the order of their relative efficiency, or if they were equal in relative efficiency, in the order of their seniority. In recent years, the concept of seniority has become outmoded as the basis for promotion and, to that extent, the former provision did not accurately reflect the desired policy. Then, in 1987, a review of officer personnel management in the Air Force concluded that changes were needed in the officer selection and promotion system.

Under these changes, officers that the Air Force intends to promote to the rank of Squadron Leader or above will be informed of their selection and placed in one of two groups. The first group is made up of officers who will be promoted at some date between 1 July of the year of selection and 31 December of the following year. The second group is made up of officers who are provisionally selected for promotion. Officers within this second group will be promoted at some date between 1 July of the year of selection to 30 June of the following year provided positions become available. If positions do not become available, they are automatically placed in the first group in the next round of selections. Officers within the two groups are therefore assured of promotions within a given time frame that meets the particular personnel needs of the Air Force.

This system of promotion will allow officers' skills, experience and qualifications to be matched to the requirements of the vacant positions. It is also expected that the system will reduce posting turbulence and associated personnel problems.

Two further points can be made. The first is that relative efficiency of eligible officers is not the only factor governing selection for promotion. Other factors such as availability, personal preferences and suitability for vacant positions at the higher rank also need to be taken into account. The second point is that there is no comparative ranking of officers within the two selected groups.

The amendment of regulation 65a was made to enable the Chief of the Air Staff to set up-to-date criteria for promotions and to enable promotions to be made in accordance with the new system as indicated above. The aim is to have determinations setting out the criteria for promotion and the system of promotion so that all officers affected by or involved in the promotion process are fully aware of the conditions attached to promotions.

You will appreciate from what I have said that, apart from its inappropriate reference to seniority in the event of equal efficiency, the former regulation 65a was inadequate in specifying relative efficiency as a sole criterion for promotion. In developing legislative changes flowing from the review mentioned above, consideration was given to simply repealing the former regulation 65a without replacement, but it was considered that there should be recognition of the need for criteria and procedures to be set.

While I recognize the basis of your concern, I would not favour the detailed prescription of matters of Defence Force internal management being made subject to Parliamentary review. Regulation 65a deals with one small part of the appointments and promotions scheme of the Air Force. No other part of that scheme, which is part and parcel of the normal day to day working of the Air Force, is subject to Parliamentary review.

However, in light of provisions contained in other regulations relating to the scheme of appointments and promotions (eg, regulation 65), I suggest that an appropriate resolution to the problem you raised would be to amend regulation 65a to include guidelines for the Chief of the Air Staff in the exercise of his power. The exact form of the guidelines is a matter that would have to be discussed with the Attorney-General's Department, but I envisage that the guidelines could provide that the Chief of the Air Staff should have regard to the skills and experience required for the performance of duties, the career advancement needs of officers, and the need to ensure the availability of an adequate supply of officers suitable for promotion.
I would be grateful for an indication of whether this proposal is acceptable to your Committee.
Yours sincerely
ROS KELLY

talk.start.para: —Some weeks ago I received a letter from an elderly constituent whose wife has been a patient in a Bush Nursing hospital for some 2 1/2 years. The private medical fund which was supporting her wrote to this gentleman to say that it was going to withdraw support. Not long after that-in fact, last week-two separate stories appeared in the Age and the Sun, stories of elderly patients in rural Bush Nursing hospitals who were being asked to leave because their medical funds were refusing to support them any more. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, responded and said that the withdrawal of the private funds' support for patients in Bush Nursing hospitals was `outrageous'. I suggest that the Minister's administration of long term care for the aged is outrageous, in particular the lack of assistance to patients in small Bush Nursing hospitals.

speech.para: What has led to this situation in Bush Nursing hospitals? We have Bush Nursing hospitals scattered throughout Victoria. They are classified as private hospitals and they usually service small rural areas. Some have approved nursing homes attached to them but the smaller ones do not. One of these hospitals has had eight patients who have been supported by a private nursing fund for a total of 6,300 days. In anybody's books, they are not acute hospital patients. If one were to get a geriatric assessment team to assess these patients they would be assessed as nursing home patients. Eight acute hospital patients would rarely spend a total of 6,300 days in an acute hospital unless they were in a public hospital when they ought to be in a nursing home but cannot move because we do not have enough nursing homes. It is outrageous that the Minister blames the health funds for his Department's inadequacy in dealing with these one-off situations.

It is bad luck under this present Government to be an elderly person in a small rural town where there is no nursing home. That is all I can say: it is bad luck. It is bad luck if a person has not had private health cover that at least may have covered him for the last 2 1/2 to three years. In Victoria there has been a 35 per cent reduction in the private health insurance market since February 1984, so a lot of people will be in that situation. It is bad luck for them that the Hawke Government is in power. The health funds can afford to pay benefits only to those to whom they are legally obliged to pay them. Not only has there been a downturn in the market but the funds have been hit by other government decisions which have reduced their funds to critical levels. They can no longer fund long term patients. One may ask, `Why should they?'. The very elderly patients they have been supporting are not acute care patients; they are long term patients. If they lived in major rural centres or towns in Victoria they would be eligible, if they were assessed as being qualified for a nursing home, to go into a registered nursing home and receive funding from the Federal Government. I will not go into what I think about the current funding. Because they live in small rural areas they are not eligible. What sort of treatment is this for our rural elderly? The Hawke Government is for big unions, big business and big organisations, not individuals. If the Government were more flexible and could assess these long term patients as qualifying for nursing home benefits we might then be able to meet the needs of people in small rural communities. I am cynical enough to think that this Government will not extend itself to be creative because there are very few votes arising from the 250 elderly patients this affects. There are very few votes for the Government in rural areas, so why would it bother?

Dr Blewett has painted the private funds as big bad bogymen. He said in the House when he was introducing the new funding arrangements for nursing homes that the recent changes to funding were designed `to ensure that nursing home care is affordable by all Australians who need it'. However, he forgot to talk about those people who live in rural areas which are not serviced by nursing homes. He forgot those 250 patients who are in bush nursing hospitals. I do not know how honourable members opposite can sit here when there are people in small rural areas not being cared for. Really the private funds are not the big bad bogymen; Dr Blewett is the bogyman. Let him take the blame. I call on Dr Blewett to stop passing the buck to private funds and to direct his Department to develop ways and means of ensuring that these elderly people in rural areas receive the long term care to which they are entitled.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —On a day when there is a great deal of comment about Aboriginal affairs administration in this country and we see a series of newspaper accounts of what has been occurring-much of which has been exposed in this Parliament, particularly in the Senate and its committees-I wish to raise another matter of concern to the Opposition in regard to what is currently happening. I do so because I think that to fail to raise it could give rise to the possibility of further abuses which could obscure the facts and make it more difficult for the Parliament to deal with the difficult issues before it.

speech.para: Before moving to describe the matters of concern to the Opposition, I want however very briefly to mention the suggestion by Mr Neville Bonner that there has been some sort of abuse of parliamentary privilege in raising matters relating to Aboriginal affairs. I do that because Mr Bonner is an old friend, as well as a colleague, of mine. He worked very closely with me when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and, indeed, on behalf of the then Government made the second reading speech to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) legislation when it was brought into the Senate. He worked closely with another of my colleagues Senator Peter Baume when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I just want to say in response to Mr Bonner that the very deep concerns felt by both Senator Peter Baume and me are no different from the sorts of concerns we shared with Mr Bonner when we were in parliament together.

As a balance to the views of Mr Bonner I simply wish to refer the Senate to the views expressed by Ms Pat O'Shane, who is a former Secretary to the New South Wales Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs and a person with whom I had dealings when I was the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I would say from those dealings that no-one could say that Ms Pat O'Shane was some Liberal or National Party stooge. She was a person of vigorous independence. She often put forward opinions that were highly critical of the governments of that time. I believe that the criticisms which she has made on both radio and television in recent days bear out the concerns of the Opposition. I do not wish to quote her at length but I simply remind the Senate that following the interview on the AM program of 1 November with Senator Grant Tambling, the Country-Liberal Party senator from the Northern Territory who has been raising many of these matters, Ms Pat O'Shane was interviewed and was very forthright in her comments in support of a general inquiry into Aboriginal affairs. She said:

. . . in my opinion, my view, it's very much overdue. There have been numerous allegations over some considerable years now about the financial management of the Aboriginal Development Commission and in more recent years, there's been the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
I wish to repeat what she said a little later, in fairness to the people who were involved in Aboriginal affairs. She said:

. . . let me emphasise first of all that the majority of Aborigines, like the majority of any people, are decent, honest people. Secondly, that in an organisation such as that, just like in any other similar non-Aboriginal organisation, there is going to be a level of corruption.

I support her general affirmation about the majority of Aborigines being decent, honest people and that is certainly my personal experience of them. The point is that, as Ms Pat O'Shane pointed out, there can also be corruption, and it is certainly the object of this Opposition to ensure that in this organisation, as in any organisation, those matters are properly dealt with. I thought it was interesting to note that when the interviewer put to her that Mr Perkins had denied all the allegations about the Aboriginal Development Commission she gave, I think, what is commonly the `Mandy Rice-Davies response'. When somebody had denied something Mandy Rice-Davies was reported as saying, `Well, he would, wouldn't he?'. I noted that in response to the question, `Mr Perkins has denied all the allegations, hasn't he?', Ms O'Shane said, `Well, I mean, it's in his interests to do so, isn't it?'. I was struck by that coincidence of expression.

In a television interview the next day on The World Tonight, Ms Pat O'Shane was very forthright about the fact that allegations have been around for a long time and she referred to the fact that there is a power struggle going on within Aboriginal Affairs. It is important to acknowledge that because it provides some of the context within which I wish to make some comments. She made the point that it is not just a matter of a power struggle; that allegations of corruption and so on have been around for many years and anyone who has an interest in this matter might find her remarks on television-which are available in transcript to any of the honourable senators who are interested-very interesting indeed. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, was recorded in the same interview as saying:
I'm charging ahead with ATSIC and I'll crash through or crash.

I think that is a very unhealthy and silly attitude for the Minister to be taking. I think that this is an area of real difficulty and the Minister should not be talking about crashing through or crashing. I think he should be standing back and trying to sort out what will work and what is a sensible way to proceed. I say to the Minister that I do not believe that this Senate will permit him to `crash through'. The Senate will expect the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation to be fully and properly scrutinised and the concerns which have been raised in the Estimates Committee and in the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to be fully and properly dealt with.

I turn now to the additional matter of concern which I wish to put before the Senate because I wish to prevent any opportunity for abuse developing-perhaps I should say `for further abuse'. It seems pretty clear that a pattern of behaviour has now emerged in Aboriginal affairs. That pattern of behaviour involves both the Minister and the permanent head of the Department. It seems that those who support ATSIC will be given favourable treatment and it appears on the evidence that I wish to cite in a moment that there is a preparedness to break the rules to advance the pro-ATSIC position. On the other hand, those Aboriginal people who choose to oppose ATSIC and who believe that this is the wrong way to proceed, are subjected to pressure and may even be sacked because of their opposition. The harshest critic of Aboriginal administration under the Fraser Government would not be able to find any evidence of that sort of behaviour. The previous Government was prepared to allow Aboriginal opinion of a very diverse sort to be freely aired, with the solitary exception that public servants were expected, in general, to maintain normal Public Service rules.

But Mr Perkins at times went beyond that. That was a matter of difficulty for the Fraser Government. I acknowledge that. In general, I think it would be fair to say that when one looks at the record particularly with respect to the advisory bodies-the National Aboriginal Conference and so on-and the dealings between Ministers and Aboriginals, often highly critical of the government of the day, any suggestion that we sought to influence, suppress or whatever simply did not occur. I believe that we now come to the concerns that I am expressing with clean hands.

We have been given reasons, we believe quite phoney reasons, for the sacking of the eight Aboriginal Development Commission commissioners. The Minister said that he sacked them to enable financial management of the ADC to be tightened. But in fact the new commissioners have, in our view, set aside the more careful financial arrangements that were being implemented and have embarked on some new quite irresponsible acts, some of which have been raised in questions and certainly some have been raised in estimates committees. There was evidence brought forward yesterday by Senator Peter Baume which suggested that the Minister himself urged on the Commission consideration of actions which were quite irresponsible and certainly were the reverse of tightening up the Commission.

The specific concerns that I have today, and which I think have not been previously aired in debate in this place, relate to answers and evidence given to Senate Estimates Committee E in relation to the appearance before the Senate Select Committee of three pro-ATSIC witnesses who were flown to Canberra at public expense. This matter was first raised on Tuesday, 25 October, when the Minister answered on advice from Mr Perkins that no departmental funds had been committed to bring witnesses to Canberra.

I would like to refer to the specific Hansard account of that. In that we find that Senator Tate, who was I am told advised by Mr Perkins in giving this response, answered in response to a question from Senator Tambling that to the best of the officers, knowledge funds had not been committed. That is in fact not true. The fact of the matter is that three witnesses appeared before the Select Committee. They gave evidence which is contained in the Hansard of the Estimates Committee and there was a follow-up indeed to the question asked by Senator Tambling by Senator Collins in the Estimates hearing on 26 October. We find Senator Collins raising a question in these terms:
I have a question for Mr Perkins which relates to some information that he gave the Committee yesterday responding to a question from, I think, Senator Tambling.
He paraphrased it in these terms:

. . . did the Department of Aboriginal Affairs pay the expenses of any witnesses who appeared before the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The answer to that question was no. The reason I want to ask Mr Perkins the question is that I am a member of that Committee and there were three witnesses, Mr Ray Robinson, Darby McCarthy-I think his correct name is Richard McCarthy-and Norman Johnson, who appeared before our Committee in Canberra. This may well be where the confusion lies.
I think that Senator Collins, whom I have accused of some fancy footwork in the Senate before, seemed to be giving Mr Perkins a chance to get off the hook here. Senator Collins said:

The reason I raise the question is this: I spoke to Mr Robinson about the evidence he gave to the Committee because I was curious as to why these three witnesses had appeared before us in Canberra when the Committee was going to Queensland. In fact, it is in Queensland at this moment. I actually said to `Sugar' Ray Robinson that I was curious about why they had actually come to Canberra and were giving evidence before the Committee when they knew the Committee was to go to Queensland and we could have taken evidence from them there. He did tell me, although there was not time to go into it in detail, that they had come to Canberra not for that reason but that they had simply taken the opportunity to appear before the Committee while they were there. What I want to ask the Secretary to the Department is this: Were the expenses of the three people that I have named paid for by the Department, and what was the major purpose of their visit to Canberra on that occasion?
Mr Perkins replied:
The major purpose was sport.

He went on to give a quite lengthy explanation about the importance of these people to sport administration and what the concerns with respect to sport were. I do not have time to quote that answer in full. Senator Collins then said:

So you can confirm Mr Robinson's advice to me that the primary reason for being in Canberra at that time had to do with consultations with you on sporting matters and was not related primarily to giving evidence to the ATSIC select committee?
Mr Perkins replied:
Consultations on sport.
I think it is important to note the content of Senator Collins's question:
. . . confirm Mr Robinson's advice to me that the primary reason for being in Canberra at that time . . .

That is, the reason it justified the expenditure of public moneys to bring these people to Canberra. I do not have time to talk about these three witnesses, but it is clear that they gave very substantial pro-ATSIC evidence and it becomes clear that one of them, Mr Johnson, is a departmental officer who told Senator Coulter that he would be the ATSIC regional manager in Cairns. Mr McCarthy has been employed as an ATSIC consultant. Some of Mr Robinson's history is set out in the record of the Select Committee and the transcript of the Estimates Committee.

talk.start.para: —The less said about that, the better.

—Yes, I do not intend to say very much about that at all. But the point that I want to make today-and I think it is an extremely important point-is that, on what we know of the visit of these three men to Canberra, it is simply not credible that the primary purpose of their visit was to discuss sport. The fact of the matter is that Senator Coulter, the Australian Democrats senator, has-I do not know whether intentionally or not-put on the public record his contact with these gentlemen. He wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. Whether that was intended to be a public document or not, I do not know, but I do know that the Minister chose to publish that letter from Senator Coulter. (Extension of time granted)

speech.para: Senator Coulter in his letter to the Minister-as I say, this letter was published, as I understand it, not by Senator Coulter but by the Minister who was the recipient of it-dated 2 November 1988, said this:

I am personally concerned that it now appears that DAA provided funding for travel for three prominent Queensland Aboriginal people to come to Canberra precisely at the time the Senate Committee Inquiry into ATSIC was taking evidence. All three were, and presumably still are, strongly in favour of ATSIC. I know it was said they were funded to attend a sport meeting in Canberra. All three contacted me in Canberra late the day before they appeared before the Committee, told me they had just arrived and were going back next afternoon at 4 p.m. All next day they were in Parliament House. I have great difficulty accepting the assertion they were funded to attend a sport related meeting in Canberra. It does not look good that someone who may be in line to take the top job in ATSIC may have had a hand in attempting to distort the Senate Committee perception of the strength of support for ATSIC.

That succinctly puts the basic concerns that we have in this matter. I am pleased to have, in support of the concerns which are felt by the Opposition, the concerns of Senator Coulter, the Australian Democrat who represents his Party in Aboriginal affairs matters and who is a member of the Select Committee. On the evidence which is available to us, the substantial time spent in Canberra by these men was spent on the ATSIC matter. I do not care if there may have been some nominal consultations. I want to raise this matter today because I do not want any attempt to gild the lily, to alter the record of these men's visit to Canberra.

On the evidence which is available to us at the moment, it appears quite clear that the substantial purpose of their visit was this ATSIC proposal and a weighting of the evidence on this critical and difficult issue the way Mr Perkins and the Minister wanted the evidence to be. It is a serious matter. I raise it on the public record because, as I said in an earlier debate in this place, people play it very hard in Aboriginal Affairs. There are some hard men. I agree with the comments of Ms Pat O'Shane. Most Aboriginal people are very straightforward and honest. I have enormous respect for them, but I do not believe it is deniable that there are also some hard games played. I believe that it is absolutely obligatory on this chamber and on this Parliament to ensure that, in determining the shape of Aboriginal administration, we get the message straight and the facts straight and the hard games do not distort what is before us.

We do not believe that there is evidence of any real or meaningful consultations with the Secretary on these matters. There may have been some discussions. The records tell us that the Secretary authorised the funds for travel. They were departmental funds, public funds. We therefore believe that the answer given by Senator Tate was not accurate. The Parliament was effectively misled. It is a serious matter. I want it to be on the public record early because it is very important that there be no distortion of the facts in this area. In what is a most difficult matter, I ask the Senate to take note of the matters to which I have drawn its attention. The record in this area is such as to give rise to very considerable concern in the Opposition that an attempt was made, using public funds, to obtain a weighting of the views before the Select Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1988
Mr President, this Bill will give effect to a number of the tax measures announced in the May Economic Statement, and to some measures announced in the Budget.

The May Statement measures relate to income tax deductions for depreciation or special write-off of income producing plant, prepaid expenses and mains electricity connection costs; the treatment of certain dividends; the abolition of section 26aaa; the valuation of live stock; and increases in pensioner rebates.

Budget measures in the Bill increase rebates for recipients of social security unemployment, sickness or special benefits, or of certain training or Commonwealth educational allowances; exempt from tax the special temporary allowance; and establish the basis for calculation of provisional tax for 1988-89.

Other income tax measures to be given effect by the Bill deal with the taxation of non-cash business benefits, debt finance for corporate restructuring, public trading trusts, expenditure substantiation rules and the gift provisions.
The Bill will also amend the fringe benefits tax law so that remote area home ownership benefits receive further concessional treatment as announced.
Concessional deductions for income-producing plant
In accordance with the May Economic Statement, the Bill will terminate most of the special deductions in the income tax law for income-producing plant.
These are-
(a) the general 5/3 accelerated depreciation allowances;
(b) certain five year depreciation arrange- ments for primary production plant and structural improvements; and
(c) the special write-offs for expenditure on general mining or petroleum mining plant, other than exploration or prospecting plant.
Plant to which these concessions currently apply will in future be written-off at effective life rates, increased by a 20 per cent loading for most plant as an incentive to investment.
Effective life rates, are determined by the Commissioner of Taxation and a definition of ``effective life'' is to be developed for inclusion in a subsequent Bill.
The present Bill will also require taxpayers who wish to use the prime cost method of depreciation to elect to do so in the first year in which the relevant plant is used.

These changes are estimated to produce revenue savings of $190m in 1989-90, $450m in 1990-91 and $1030m in 1991-92, rising further for a few years then settling at an annual gain of around $1 1/4 billion in the mid to late 1990s.
Expenditure paid in advance
The general deductions provisions of the income tax law authorises a deduction in the year in which expenditure is incurred even where the services being paid for are provided over several years.
On the other hand, the person providing the services may generally bring the income to account in the year in which the services are provided and this imbalance provides tax shelter opportunities.
The Bill will change the timing of deductions for expenditure paid in advance under agreements entered into after 25 May 1988.
Instead of being fully deductable when incurred, deductions for the expenditure will be pro rated over the period during which the services will be provided, with a maximum period of 10 years.

Immediate deductability will continue to be available if all the services will be provided within 13 months of incurring the expenditure; if the expenditure is less than $1,000; or if it is required by order of a court of by law, or is in respect of salary or wages.
Transitional provisions will ensure that the amendments apply prospectively.
The revenue savings from this measure are estimated to be $35m in 1989-90 and $20m in subsequent years.
Dividends paid by tax-exempt entities
Two measures announced in the May Economic Statement to prevent abuse of the intercorporate dividend rebate provisions will be given effect by this Bill.

Under the first, certain tax-exempt entities will be discouraged from using innovative financing techniques by which investors receive a return on their investment in the form of tax free dividends rather than as taxable interest receipts.

Denial of the rebate on dividends paid by relevant tax-exempt entities removes the distortion in the tax position of investors who would otherwise obtain unintended financial benefits at the expense of Commonwealth revenue.
Dividends received by private companies
Other intercorporate dividend rebate changes will deny the rebate on unfranked dividend income received by private companies.
These private companies will accrue franking credits that can be used to frank dividends passed on to their shareholders.

This removes the tax deferral advantage of receiving unfranked dividends through a private company and leaves the ultimate individual shareholders in the same position as if the dividends had been received directly.

Unfranked dividends that pass from one company to another within a wholly-owned company group will not be subject to the measure, nor will dividends paid under the arrangements for the phasing-out of Division 7 undistributed profits tax which are required to be unfranked.
These changes will apply to unfranked dividends paid after 25 May 1988, unless the dividends were declared on or before that date.
Abolition of section 26aaa

The Bill gives effect to the proposal announced on 25 May 1988 to abolish the provision which taxes profits made on the sale of property within 12 months of purchase, leaving those gains to be taxed under the general capital gains and capital losses provisions.
Gains arising from short term property sales will qualify for the five year notional averaging of liabilities under the capital gains provisions and may be offset against allowable capital losses.
This amendment will apply to sales of property after 25 May 1988 and is expected to have a revenue cost of $5 million in 1988-89 and $30 million in 1989-90.
Mains electricity connections
Capital expenditure in connecting mains electricity facilities to a property on which a business is carried on is to be deductable over 10 years instead of in the year in which it is incurred.
The amendments will apply to expenditure incurred after 25 May 1988, but will not apply to expenditure incurred under a contract entered into on or before that date.
The expected annual revenue saving from the measure in 1989-90 and subsequent years is $5m.
Valuation of natural increase in live stock
The value of live stock on hand at the end of a year of income is generally brought to account, at the option of the taxpayer, at either cost price or market value.

Where cost price method is adopted, the law permits the taxpayer to select a cost price for natural increase which, for a class of live stock, may not be less than the minimum cost price prescribed in respect of live stock of that class.

The minimum values prescribed are substantially outdated and the Treasurer announced in the May Economic Statement that the values are to be increased for natural increase occurring after 30 June 1988, but to a level that is still less than any reasonable estimate of the cost of natural increase.
A taxpayer who can demonstrate that the actual cost of producing natural increase is less than the relevant new prescribed value will be permitted to value the natural increase at actual cost.
This change will have minimal effect on revenue.
Pensioner rebate
The Bill will increase the maximum pensioner rebate from $250-or $308 for service pensioners-to $430 for both social security and service pensioners.
It will also increase the taxable income level above which the pensioner rebate begins to shade-out from $6,142-or $6,384 for service pensioners-to $6,892 for both classes.
These changes, which will have effect for 1988-89 and subsequent years, are estimated to cost $55m in 1988-89 and $210m in 1989-90.
Beneficiary rebate

The maximum rebates of tax for other social security beneficiaries and certain recipients of allowances under Commonwealth educational schemes, and the levels at which the rebates begin to shade-out, are to be increased for the 1988-89 and subsequent income years.
For married taxpayers the maximum rebate will increase from $430 to $600, with no tax payable on taxable incomes up to $11,059.
For other taxpayers the maximum rebate will increase from $180 to $260, with no tax payable on taxable incomes up to $6,184.
These measures are estimated to cost $20m in 1988-89 and subsequent years.
Special temporary allowances

Amendments will also be made by the Bill to give effect to the 1988-89 Budget proposal to exempt from income tax the special temporary allowance payable for a period of 12 weeks to a surviving social security or service pensioner following the death of his or her pensioner spouse.
This change will apply for 1988-89 and subsequent years and will have a negligible revenue cost in 1988-89 and cost $5m in 1989-90 and $6m in 1990-91.
Provisional tax for 1988-89
Provisional tax is that part of the pay-as-you-earn system designed to collect tax on non-salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived.
As such, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year.

This Bill provides for 1988-89 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1987-88 taxable income increased by 12 per cent, and by applying the 1988-89 rates of tax and medicare levy, and the increased low income thresholds for medicare levy.

Generally, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1987-88 assessments but rebates of tax allowed on franked dividends will be the 1987-88 rebates increased by 12 per cent.

Taxpayers who estimate that their taxable income for 1988-89 will increase by less than 12 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level, will continue to have the right to `self assess' and have the provisional tax for 1988-89 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
Non-cash business benefits

This Bill will also implement, subject to some minor variations, the proposal which was announced on 4 February 1985 to tax non-cash business benefits, but delayed because of the priority given to major tax reform measures.

This measure will address practices that became more prevalent following the full Federal Court's decision that the existing law taxes non-cash business benefits only if such benefits are convertible to cash and are in the nature of income according to ordinary concepts.
There had also been an increase in the provision of non-cash benefits to induce business taxpayers to purchase items of plant or equipment.
It was originally announced that the law would be amended to tax the arm's length value of non-cash business benefits, subject to certain special rules.
On review a more satisfactory approach is to provide separate simple rules to deal with both these practices.

The Bill will tax non-convertible benefits provided after 5 February 1985 in the same way as benefits that are convertible into cash and which are taxable under the existing law if they are of an income nature.
In other words, the existing rules that apply to the taxation of convertible benefits will be extended to non-convertible benefits.

To ensure that there can be no element of retrospectivity in this revised approach, the Bill contains transitional provisions that will allow benefits provided on or before today to be taxed on the announced basis.

In the case of non-cash benefits provided to induce business taxpayers to purchase items of plant or equipment or to enter into service agreements, the amendments will simply treat the portion of the expenditure that represents the arm's length value of the benefit provided as having been incurred in respect of the benefit.
This will ensure that the expenditure relating to the benefit will not be deductable or form part of the cost of a depreciable unit of property.
This approach, which varies the announcement, will apply only to benefits provided after 31 August 1988.
Corporate Restructure (Debt Creation) Rules

The Bill will insert in the income tax law rules foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 30 April 1987 against arrangements under which interest-bearing debt is introduced to finance the restructuring of related foreign controlled companies.

The measures will deny interest deductions on debt used to fund the transfer of assets from one related company to another where the buyer and seller are at least 50 per cent controlled by a non-resident or related non-residents, except where there has been an introduction of additional income producing assets.
The new rules will replace administrative measures that had previously been imposed as a condition for approval of investments under foreign investment policy.

While the amendments will generally apply from 1 July 1987, under transitional arrangements in the Bill, companies that are less than 100 per cent foreign controlled will not be subject to the legislation on restructures carried out between 1 July 1987 and 19 June 1988.

As part of its consultative approach to new and complex tax legislation, the Government released a draft of the main operative provisions of this legislation on 20 June 1988 and called for comment from interested persons.

This initiative was well received and, in conjunction with the seminars sponsored by the Taxation Institute of Australia, has resulted in constructive submissions being made by members of the accounting and legal professions and by industry.
A number of changes recommended in these submissions have been adopted so that the measures will not intrude unnecessarily into the normal trading activities of foreign controlled companies.
For example, although the earlier draft legislation was to have a 15 per cent foreign control threshold, the Government has agreed to increase the level to 50 per cent.

The legislation is limited to corporate restructures, but the Government will quickly respond if evidence emerges of entities other than companies being used to circumvent the provisions now being introduced.
Other income tax measures
Other income tax changes being implemented by this Bill will have negligible revenue effect.

One extends for the 1987-88 and subsequent income years the range of business activities that may be conducted by a public unit trust, without it being treated as a public trading trust and therefore taxed as a company.

Another eases the paperwork burden relating to claims for car expenses, by permitting certain information about car expenses to be specified in records to be retained by taxpayers, rather than in their income tax returns.
Remote area home ownership schemes

Effect is also being given to the Treasurer's announcement on 29 October 1986 that the fringe benefits tax law would be amended to allow employers in Australia's remote areas to amortise the taxable value of certain fringe benefits provided under remote area home ownership schemes.

Subject to a seven-year maximum, the value of the benefit may be spread over the period running from the date the benefit was initially provided until the employee is free to transfer the property on the open market.
Other amendments will extend the scope of the existing remote area concessions in certain other respects.
The amendments will apply with effect from commencement of the fringe benefits tax legislation on 1 July 1986, and are expected to cost less than $1m per annum.
Recovery of tax
Finally, the Bill will amend the Taxation Administration Act.

Following the decision of the High Court in the Moorebank case, provisions in the Act that modified limitation periods imposed by the various State and Territory limitation laws are redundant, and are to be repealed by this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988
This Bill will amend the Income Tax Act 1986 to formally impose the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1988-89 and 1989-90 financial years.
It will also impose for the same period the rates of tax payable by companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies.
In addition, it will impose rates of tax on superannuation funds, ineligible approved deposit funds and certain other trusts.
The rates to be imposed by the measures in this Bill are those declared in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986.
The personal rates for 1988-89 remain unchanged but, as announced by the Treasurer in the 1988-89 Budget Speech, reductions will be effected from 1 July 1989.
A four-step tax scale currently applies.

At the lower end of the scale for resident taxpayers, no tax is payable on taxable incomes up to $5,100. On taxable incomes in the range $5,101 to $12,600 the rate is 24 per cent. In the range $12,601 to $19,500 the rate is 29 per cent.
For income in the range $19,501 to $35,000 the rate is 40 per cent, and the top marginal rate is 49 per cent for income in excess of $35,000.

These general rates also apply to non-residents who receive Australian social security and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia, or who were residents at any time during the income year.
For all other non-resident taxpayers, the rate of 29 per cent applies to incomes up to $19,500 and the general rates apply to income above that level.
For 1988-89 a rate of 49 per cent applies to all unearned income of resident minors, subject to shading-in arrangements for such income just over $416.
The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and on other categories of income subject to anti-avoidance provisions of that Act, is 49 per cent in 1988-89.
The company tax rate payable in respect of 1987-88 income will remain at 49 per cent. As announced in the May 1988 Economic Statement, a lower rate of 39 per cent will apply to 1988-89 income.
The rates of tax, payable in respect of 1987-88 income, for unit trusts treated as companies and registered organisations will remain at 49 per cent and 20 per cent respectively.

Of course, when decisions are taken as to the reduced personal tax rates to apply in 1989-90 and any other tax rate changes, legislation amending the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 which declares the various income tax rates that I have just outlined for 1988-89 will be put before the Parliament.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum that accompanied the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 I have just introduced.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to impose the basic rate of Medicare Levy for 1988-89 and 1989-90.
The basic rate of the levy will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income.
That has been the rate since 1 December 1986.
The Bill also contains increases in the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy.
For 1988-89 and 1989-90, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $9,560, and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $16,110, will not be required to pay the levy.
The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student.
For example, a married couple with two dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $20,310.
The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $11m in 1988-89 and $27m in 1989-90.
The new low income thresholds will be reflected in tax instalment schedules as soon as practicable.
Mr President, the explanatory memorandum on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 about which I have just spoken contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1988]

talk.start.para: —Is it the wish of the Senate that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 be debated cognately with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —We are debating a very complex set of Bills covering numerous issues. I hope that the Government will give some consideration to a possible extension of time for me or other senators to cover the points in significant detail. The Opposition wishes to move second reading amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. In relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, I foreshadow the following amendment:

speech.para: At end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(b) the Government has mainly relied on bracket creep through the various personal income tax brackets, and also on the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax to fund its Budget surplus;
(c) such new taxes represent increased complexity and uncertainty in the administration of the taxation system and so decrease efficiency and equity;
(d) the Government has lost sight of the needed direction for Australia's future; and

(e) the Government should accept that the highest priority needs to be given to reducing the enormous tax burden, so that the standard of living of Australians can be improved while at the same time addressing the nation's external economic problems''.
In relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, I move:
At end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) notes that this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(b) notes that this Government's so-called tax reforms invariably involve simply offsetting tax reductions in one area by tax increases in others, as witnessed in this bill by the termination of the 5/3 depreciation arrangement to offset a reduction in the corporate tax rate;
(c) notes that the Government continues its propensity for taxation by stealth by again unaccountably raising the provisional tax uplift factor;

(d) notes that the Treasurer has failed to meet his responsibilities in respect of the administration of the taxation system and has hidden behind the rhetoric of the Commissioner of Taxation and encouraged the undermining of the rule of law in taxation matters; and

(e) condemns the Government for its practice of ``government by press release'' which can cause otherwise legitimate legislation to be called into question because of the unacceptable retrospectivity thus introduced''.
In relation to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988, I move:
At end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) expresses its concern at the increasing costs of Medicare despite a fall in the delivery of medical services, particularly to the poor and needy;
(b) deplores changes made by the Government to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme; and
(c) calls on the Government to ensure that all Australians obtain the high-quality, affordable health care, to which they are entitled''.

The amendment that I draw particular attention to is that which I have moved in respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988. I will now read it in order to set down the basis of the Opposition's approach to the case which the Government has put down in its second reading speech:
At end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) notes that this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(b) notes that this Government's so-called tax reforms invariably involve simply offsetting tax reductions in one area by tax increases in others, as witnessed in this bill by the termination of the 5/3 depreciation arrangement to offset a reduction in the corporate tax rate;
(c) notes that the Government continues its propensity for taxation by stealth by again unaccountably raising the provisional tax uplift fact or;

(d) notes that the Treasurer has failed to meet his responsibilities in respect of the administration of the taxation system and has hidden behind the rhetoric of the Commission of Taxation and encouraged the undermining of the rule of law in taxation matters; and

(e) condemns the Government for its practice of ``government by press release'' which can cause otherwise legitimate legislation to be called into question because of the unacceptable retrospectivity thus introduced''.
I would like to return to that last point later in my remarks, because it is the major concern of the Opposition with regard to the Bills before us.

The Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 sets down the rates of tax which are to apply for the coming financial year. It extends the rates which were set down in the equivalent 1986 legislation. As the Senate knows, this is an annual process and needs to be carried out each financial year. The rates are exactly the same as those which were applied by this Government in 1986. Since 1986, this Government, because of the effects of so-called bracket creep, and without any change whatsoever to income tax brackets, has reefed in $2,000m to $3,000m from taxpayers, without having returned that to them in the way of tax cuts. This has happened because people's incomes have risen and they have moved into higher tax brackets, causing them effectively to pay higher rates of tax and consequently losing a greater proportion of their income in payments to the Government.

The taxpayers were promised all kinds of benefits if they were prepared to restrain themselves. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have promised tax cuts which are to materialise next year. We await those tax cuts with bated breath. But economic events, and statements in the Parliament and in other places by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, Senator Button and Senator Walsh, all tend to indicate that the tax cuts which people expect some time next year-to be handed down just before the next election-may not materialise. The Government is surely on about some kind of election strategy here. We know that the Government aims to go to an election towards the end of 1989. It was significant that in the May economic statement the Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced that there would be tax cuts, applicable from 1 July next year-in other words, some three months before the people would have to go to an election. Obviously, it is a con trick, an attempt to buy votes through tax cuts given immediately before the next election.

Now Senator Walsh has said that tax cuts cannot be achieved without more spending cuts on the part of this Government. That is notwithstanding the huge surplus which the Government has in this financial year's Budget. That is a proper way to go, but what it means is that the Government is in no easy position to grant the tax cuts which we were all led to believe some months ago were quite easily achievable by the Treasurer with some kind of magic wand. The need for tax cuts is there. Notwithstanding Senator Walsh's statistical abstractions about what really measures living standards in this country, people are hurting because of the Government's economic and tax policies. Real incomes have fallen significantly. People's incomes have dropped, on average, $56 a week in real terms since the Fraser Government left office in 1983. In other words, under the Hawke-Keating Administration people have lost effectively out of their pockets at least $56 a week. That has happened by a combination of rising prices, heavier taxation and, of course, the effects of higher interest rates on mortgages and on the cost of housing generally.

Only a week or so ago we saw the consumer price index figures come out from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They demonstrated that inflation in this country is again on the increase. This is chiefly due to the increase in the price of housing, as a result of interest rates and the way that affects mortgage payments, higher rentals and, of course, the higher cost of purchasing a house in the first place.
