All that is impacting very heavily on the average family man and is having a tremendous impact on his standard of living and that of his family. That is happening right across the board. To put it simply, under this Government incomes in Australia are simply not rising as fast as are living expenses or taxation. People are finding it more and more difficult to exist.

One of our amendments is to the motion for the second reading of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. We all know what a very dangerous and difficult position Medicare is in in the way that it is restricting people's access to proper health care in this country at present. This Bill imposes a Medicare levy of 1 1/4 per cent of taxable income of eligible taxpayers. By that amendment we again draw attention to the rising cost of Medicare; how this Government appears to have absolutely no strategy to try to improve the standards of health care in this country for Australians; and how that is hurting people in Australia with particular problems such as the need for elective surgery.

I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Generally speaking, this Bill covers multitudinous concerns briefly described as instituting some roll-over relief from the effects of the capital gains tax which was introduced by the Government back in September 1985. During the debates on the capital gains tax when it was initially introduced-those debates occurred in the middle of 1986-the Liberal and National parties drew to the attention of the Government and the people of Australia the multitudinous anomalies, difficulties and errors in the drafting of that legislation. Of course, these have been continually brought to the eye of the public and of practitioners in the taxation field over the last 2 1/2 years, indicating that some parts of the law are totally and utterly unintelligible to ordinary human beings. The interpretation of that law is very much in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation, given his tremendous powers of discretion and by effective legislation through his income tax ruling system. That has been partially cleared up by virtue of these many amendments set down in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) that we are debating.

However, there is one area to which I wanted to draw the attention of the Senate which needs specific consideration by the Government in the course of debate in the committee stage and about which I understand the Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment. We will certainly consider favourably any amendment that they put forward after we have seen it but I understand that it will fit very much the set of circumstances which are of concern to us. This matter relates to the conversion of crown lease property to freehold property by those who have been holding crown leases for some time. Many taxpayers and many members on both sides of the House of Representatives have welcomed the Government's approach to this. It is to grant roll-over relief from capital gains tax where conversion has occurred from crown lease to freehold. However, there is a difficulty in so far as it obviously does not go far enough to cover the situation where there is some surrender of a crown lease and the adoption of a freehold title to property which may not cover exactly the same property that was the subject of the crown lease. This, of course, is usually at the behest of the State government which holds the crown lease. Therefore, it has an element of compulsion to it. By the terms of the law in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the roll-over relief would not be granted as many members on the Labor side of the House of Representatives apparently thought it would. Therefore, any amendment to fix up that situation we believe would be very beneficial. We will be considering favourably the Democrats' amendment on that matter.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 covers a multitude of matters which are of more direct relevance to ordinary taxpayers. First, I would like to mention what is known as the provisional tax uplift factor. Incorporated in this Bill is an increase-this was announced in the Budget-in taxation being applied to provisional incomes this financial year of 12 per cent. That has been raised from the 11 per cent that applied last financial year. Back in the days of the Fraser Government this uplift factor, as it is called, was increased in line with the current rate of inflation, as measured by the consumer price index. Now the Government has gone one better. With the inflation rate running at around 7 1/2 per cent to 8 per cent, it has now incorporated in the provisional tax uplift factor an additional element to cover real growth in the economy. So that is how it has arrived at a 12 per cent factor. That is imposed irrespective of the incomes of people being subject to change. There are many people on fixed incomes who will be unduly penalised as a result of that uplift factor being applied. It is true that there is relief available. People can apply to have that rate reduced. We also know that heavy penalties will be applied by the Commissioner of Taxation in the event of that being not got absolutely right. So the first point is that this is effectively a stealthy increase in taxation by this Government, by its going to the higher than expected level of increase in the provisional tax uplift factor which incorporates factors which under the previous coalition Government had not been applied.

The second issue concerns the rebate of tax which will be applicable to age pension recipients in the future. We all know that many pensioners are now suffering taxation on the little bit of extra income they earn over and above the pensions they receive. The Bill includes an amendment to extend the pensioner rebate to a somewhat higher figure in the current financial year. That will have no real impact on taxpayers until the early part of the next financial year when they lodge their taxation returns and therefore save on the tax that they would otherwise pay. The point I want to draw to the Senate's attention is that that amount of extra income which people can earn over and above their pension without its being affected by taxation was just under $1,000 back in the 1983 financial year, the last year of the Fraser Government. People could earn nearly $20 a week without any taxation being applied to it at all. However, in the current financial year under the Hawke-Keating Government the amount which one can earn without having to pay tax has fallen in dollar terms by half; that is, people can now earn only $10 a week over and above their pension and not be subject to tax. Of course, in real terms it is even lower than that. It is probably as little as $5 a week if we take into account inflation. That means that people are suffering as a result of the policy of this Government in that area.

I point out that I have had a very successful period of negotiations with the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) concerning proposed new section 21a of the Income Tax Assessment Act as set down in clause 13 of the Bill. This is the most controversial area of the whole Bill and covers, in a retrospective way, non-cash benefits payable to people by employers. The amendment proposed by the Government in this Bill is, as I say, retrospective not just for a few months, a year or two years, but for 3 1/2 years back to 4 February 1985. That was the day on which the Treasurer put out a press statement saying that from that date he was going to apply taxation to non-monetary benefits received by business taxpayers. That is all very well, but that was three and a half years ago, and during all that time people have had no detailed legislation to examine, to understand and to apply to their particular circumstances. It means that the law has been totally in a vacuum over that period of time. People have been incurring liabilities without knowing it, because the Treasurer's press statement did not spell out in sufficient detail exactly how the law was going to be applied. That has particular application in many different situations, which we will come to during the debate in the committee stage of the legislation.

I can instance one or two cases where people who are in receipt of some form of non-cash benefits would be caught as an unintended consequence of this legislation. Take, for instance, the situation where a garage proprietor receives the benefit of low interest loans from an oil company during the setting up period of his business. Under the terms of the Bill as they are presently set down, and before any amendments are introduced by the Government, that garage proprietor would be suffering heavy taxation on that amount, not just from the date when the legislation receives assent, but back to 4 February 1985. During that time he has not known that he was incurring any liability.

The point that has to be made is simply this: within clause 13 there is the most insidious application of retrospectivity that I have witnessed during my time in the Parliament. We have a situation where the Government announced by press release in the most vague terms something that might be called an anti-avoidance device. The use of a press release to foreshadow future legislation is recognised as being an appropriate use. But in looking at the Bill that we now have before us, in its unamended form, we see that it goes much further than was ever suggested in the Treasurer's press release. In fact, the sorts of people that I have just mentioned would be caught by the legislation and it would wreak havoc in the business community, far more than we would have understood by the Treasurer's press release.

One of the most significant examples of where people would be caught by this legislation is the example that has received some publicity. I refer to those ladies who earn a little extra money by selling Avon cosmetic products door to door and who do, on occasions, receive some form of prize, such as saucepans, coffee mugs or coasters. They are of minimal value but they would be taxed in the kind of situation that is included in this Bill. Quite apart from the stupidity of trying to value what such things are worth, we have the nonsense situation where Avon ladies, Tupperware salespersons and other people in that sort of situation who receive very low incomes, would find themselves incurring taxation back to 4 February 1985 on any of the goods which they have received.

That is why the Liberal and National parties will be moving at the committee stage to remove from the legislation any retrospectivity to February 1985 when the fallacious press statement was released. We will be moving an amendment-I hope it has the support of the Australian Democrats-to ensure that the Bill has effect from 31 August 1988. I understand that the Government will not accept that amendment, and I understand its reasons for that. But in the House of Representatives it will have to come to terms with the Senate if it wants to see the legislation enacted at some later stage.

What the Government is doing is totally wrong. It is wrong to apply the principle of legislation by press release for anti-avoidance measures in this way. This legislation is plainly retrospective and misleading. It will cause enormous concern to Australians if it is enacted in its unamended form. I also hope that the Government will move amendments at the committee stage in respect of certain definitional questions and wording in the Bill. I will not go into detail now but these matters will be discussed at great length during the committee stage of the legislation next week.

Let me make absolutely clear some of the problems that we see in clause 13 of the Bill. The definition of `arm's length value' which might be applied to any kind of prize or good that a person might receive on the side of earning any income as, say, an Avon cosmetics salesperson, is one for the connoisseur. Honourable senators will not believe this, but according to the Bill, the definition of `arm's length value' is, `The value of a transaction where people are dealing at arm's length'. This is incredible.

talk.start.para: —You know, you cannot get anything more accurate than that, can you?

—That is right; it is just amazing. Clause 13 does not contain a definition of what is a business relationship. The Government is very averse to trying to define what is a business relationship because it wants to allow its Commissioner of Taxation to run around freely with all the force of law, exercising his discretion which he has under taxation law, to define a business relationship in whatever way he sees fit. Therefore, the Government has not included in this Bill anything that defines closely what that relationship is. As a result, we can see all kinds of injustices being perpetrated on Australian taxpayers by virtue of the omission of that definition. But I will say more about that when we come to the committee stage of the legislation a little later in the piece.

speech.para: One or two other matters in this Bill are of very great concern. Firstly, the Bill seeks to deny taxation deductions for pre-paid expenditures. That, of course, was mentioned in the Treasurer's May economic statement. The Opposition wishes to draw to the Senate's attention the impact that this will have on all kinds of contractors, particularly transport contractors, earth-moving contractors, farmers and others who have entered into leasing arrangements for equipment over the last few years. Because of inflation, the value of second-hand machinery has increased significantly. When that value is taken into account in a trade-in for new machinery and there is an excess over what is called the residual value in a lease, that excess has been applied as a rental payment upfront when the new arrangement for the purchase of new machinery is entered into. Previously that was allowed as a tax deduction. That will not now be so allowable.

This will place additional burden and great strain on the financial arrangements of people running transport rigs, earth-moving equipment and so on. It will be felt significantly in the years ahead and it will have a big impact on transport operators. We all know that these days they are under significant pressure because of the costs of fuel, competition in the market-place and numerous other factors. This will ensure that many of them go to the wall.

Another matter I wish to mention in the brief moment or two remaining to me concerns the change in the depreciation law. The Government, scrooge-like, has wound back the system to a less generous regime for depreciation applying to plant, buildings and so on. That will apply from 25 May this year when the Treasurer announced the measure. Because of the difficulties that have occurred in applying this legislation, the legislation will have uneven impacts depending on the nature of the entity in which individuals engage in business. (Extension of time granted) I draw the Senate's attention to a situation that may arise when partners do not alter the ownership, in the real sense of the word, of the underlying property-whether it be plant and equipment or real estate-in a partnership. Partnerships alter their affairs and partners come and go, and they may represent only a very small fraction of the total change in ownership of the underlying property in the partnership. Because of the way clause 37 appears to have been drafted, any minor changes of the sort that I have just mentioned will be caught and consequently the new less liberal taxation regime for depreciation will apply thereafter; as a result the benefits of the old regime will have been lost to the continuing partners after the specified date-that is, 25 May 1988. That means that many professional partnerships which go through reconstitution of their structures almost on a day to day, week to week, month to month, basis will find-I am not talking about every firm, but it will occur across the whole spectrum of the Australian economy-their partnerships affected very greatly. The joint ownership of property other than in a strictly partnership arrangement will also be affected by this.

The point at issue here is that in most cases there is a very minimal change in the proportion of the total value of the underlying property of a partnership from one set of partners to another. Yet, the full rigour of the Government's rather ungenerous approach in this area will be felt by individuals in partnerships. I hope that during the committee stage of the debate we will hear from the Minister about his intentions in this area. I understand that there are discretions available to the Government, through the Taxation Commissioner, to make decisions in favour of taxpayers. I hope that we can get the Minister's assurances that that will apply in those cases. Otherwise, we would be very interested in looking to possible amendments to the Bill to make sure that taxpayers are properly protected by the law, rather than leaving the matter to the Taxation Commissioner's discretion.

In finalising my remarks on the Bills, I point out again the continuing confusion in the Government's ranks about whether or not taxes will be cut in the next financial year in the lead-up to the next election. At this point we understand-it is the only conclusion one can draw-that we have to listen to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who says that there will be no tax cuts without further cuts in expenditure. That means that we must go through another Budget process before we are likely to see tax cuts. It means a mini-Budget next May with further expenditure reductions. We know that the Government is in a great state of confusion over the general state of the economy, having failed to talk it up during the Budget process. The Budget now being seen to be in tatters, one can have no confidence at all that the Government will reach its objective of delivering tax cuts in the lead-up to the next election. We welcome the anomalies relief in respect of the capital gains tax and will be concentrating very heavily on the matters that I raised regarding the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) when we reach the committee stage of the Bill. I hope that when we debate that issue we will see some amendments, particularly to clause 13 of the Bill, emanating from the Government.

speech.speaker: Maguire Sen G.R.

talk.start.para: —We are debating jointly the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax Amendment Bill and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. The Bills once again reflect the Government's commitment to a thoroughgoing reform of Australia's tax system, a reform which is unprecedented in Australia's history and is long overdue following the blatant deterioration of the tax system under the previous Liberal Government. The Bills cover a wide range of issues and correct, by amendment, a number of anomalies in existing legislation. They refine the existing tax legislation and, in doing so, lead further towards the development of an efficient and fair tax system for Australia. The amendments include those to increase the pensioner rebate for this financial year, a very welcome move, and to alter the income threshold for the Medicare levy on an annual basis. The legislation provides amendments which are at the core of this Government's social justice strategy and, in the process, provides further assistance to those Australians in the greatest need.

speech.para: I wish briefly to discuss some of the amendments in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) regarding the fringe benefits tax and the income tax substantiation requirements. I am pleased to note that one of the changes included in that legislation is the removal of the requirement to keep car logbooks on an ongoing basis. Under the previous substantiation rules there was a requirement to keep logbooks for the running of motor vehicles for protracted periods. That has now been relaxed, and I am sure that will be welcomed by those taxpayers affected. There is also general exemption from the fringe benefits tax for a range of minor benefits. Also of great interest are the increased concessions for remote area housing, as well as several other benefits. I am sure that the increased concessions in the tax treatment of remote area housing will go down very well in the remote outback areas of my State of South Australia, where a number of employees benefit from subsidised housing. I am sure that that further concession will be of great interest to them.

The Bill, while not amending the basic structure or principles of the fringe benefits tax or the income tax substantiation rules, will significantly reduce the administrative burdens on taxpayers-for example, through there being a requirement for less paperwork. The passing by parliament of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) will also see the removal of the current five- or three-year accelerated depreciation provisions in the tax laws. It will replace those accelerated provisions with those which will introduce deductability based on the economic life of assets. Over and above that, there will be a loading of 20 per cent of value to encourage new investment. That approach is very important. It is vital to help to boost labour productivity and the competitiveness of Australian industry. Also, the scrapping of the accelerated depreciation over five or three years will help to remove current distortions in Australian investment behaviour. It will encourage future investment decisions to be made on the basis of the highest pre-tax rates of return on investments rather than on the basis of the availability or timing of particular tax concessions which apply. As a result, the tax system will no longer misallocate scarce resources by encouraging investment in longer living plant and equipment at the expense of short-lived assets.

Those critics who argue that the removal of the five- or three-year accelerated depreciation allowance will reduce business investment are failing to consider the Government's whole package of measures of tax reform in this area. Those critics who make those claims are simply evaluating individual tax changes in isolation from the overall thrust of the tax measures in general. For example, the removal of the five- or three-year depreciation allowance cannot be considered in isolation from the substantial reduction in company tax rates which was announced last May in the Government's economic statement to Parliament. That cut in the general company tax rate from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar should be associated with far more new investment than any reduction in investment resulting from the removal of the accelerated depreciation provisions.

The lowering of the company tax rate to 39c in the dollar, in revenue terms, could not have occurred without the removal of the accelerated depreciation allowance. Over the next three financial years it is the Government's estimate that the revenue saving from those two measures combined will total $1,700m-a very significant revenue saving, and one which is vitally important to the general revenues of the Commonwealth and, of course, to the development of the Budget surplus.

One of the most important social welfare measures contained in this package of Bills is the lifting of the pensioner taxation rebate. Previously, pensioners received a rebate-which is, in effect, a tax credit; it is not a rebate that they get at the end of a financial year-of $250. That has been increased to $430 in this financial year, coming into effect from 1 July last. As a result of that measure those pensioners who are wholly or substantially dependent on the pension will not pay income tax. In endorsing that measure, I should say that I believe that the record of the Labor Government on pensions, and on the treatment of pensioners, is second to none in Australia, despite the rhetoric and the misinformation being put around the community. Certainly, we have not gone down the road that Mr Howard took when he was the Treasurer of this country. I well remember that, for a period of 12 months, he suspended indexation of pensions. We have provided on a regular basis for the cash level of pensions to be adjusted twice yearly for increases in the consumer price index. That is in stark contrast to the record of the Liberal Government. While its rhetoric is about improving pensions, its record in government has been totally different.

The increase in the pensioner rebate to $430 in this financial year will mean that many more pensioners will be exempt from tax. In that last financial year pensioners were able to receive a tax-free income of $6,142 as a result of the previous $250 rebate, working in concert with the tax rate. In this financial year the figure has been increased enormously. Now, as a result of the rebate of $430, pensioners will be able to receive a tax exempt income of $6,892, which is a large increase. It must be compared with the level of tax exempt income which is available to the rest of the community. For example, members of the work force can earn a tax-exempt income of only $5,100, so the tax treatment of pensioners in that area clearly is a lot better than that of employed members of the community. While pensions are indexed every six months, in June and December-this increases the value of the pension because of price rises-these rises are not available to employed members of the community. As a result of the new pensioner rebate an age pensioner receiving $30 a week over and above his pension will save about $5.25 a week-quite a significant increase in his after-tax income.

This pensioner tax rebate is a highly equitable tax measure. It is focused on the neediest persons, on those aged persons with the lowest total incomes. The rebate is phased out for those on higher incomes. Consequently, it is a very fair measure. The phase-out begins at a taxable income of $6,892. Pensioners with combined incomes of up to $10,331 still receive some part of that tax rebate, which has the effect of reducing their overall tax burden. An income of $10,331 which is subject to some part of that pensioner rebate is quite a significant retirement income.

As a result of the introduction of the pensioner tax rebate, the Government estimates that pensioners will be able to earn very close to $10 a week over and above the basic pension without facing an income tax liability. The figure in the last financial year was about $3.75 a week. As can be seen, it is quite a significant increase in the after-tax income that is available to pensioners. In concert with that measure we have relaxed the requirement for the payment of provisional personal income tax by pensioners. In this financial year a pensioner will not be required to pay provisional personal income tax if he qualifies for a full or part pensioner income tax rebate. In broad terms, that means that, instead of facing a $1,000 investment income threshold, as was the case in the last financial year, before paying provisional tax, this year pensioners will be able to earn a combined income-investment income plus the pension-of $10,331 before they become liable for the payment of provisional tax. It is estimated that this relaxation will free a quarter of a million pensioners from the requirement to pay provisional tax. The changes are in line with the Social Security Review paper entitled Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy released by the Government recently. It recommended improvements to the pensioner tax rebate and other measures to assist low income pensioners.

The changes represent another substantial instalment in the Government's election promise to provide a new deal for pensioners. As a result of that promise made in 1983 the age pension has risen to nearly 25 per cent of the average weekly earnings of the Australian work force compared with the figure of 22.7 per cent under the Liberals in March 1983. So there has been a big percentage point boost in pensions in relation to the earnings of the employed members of the Australian community, and it can be demonstrated that in fact the age pension has increased ahead of inflation by 8 per cent over the course of this Government's term. So during the life of this Government there has been an 8 per cent real growth in pensions.

Not only has the purchasing power of pensioners increased under the Hawke Labor Government but, as this Bill demonstrates, the tax burden on pensioners and the inconvenience and worry that many elderly people face when filling out tax returns has been eased substantially, particularly as a result of the change to provisional tax as of 1 July last. The reduction in the pensioners' tax burden follows an overall decrease in tax rates for millions of low income earners since this Government came to office. There has been a reduction in the lowest marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar when Mr Howard was Treasurer to the present rate of 24c in the dollar for the lowest income tax bracket. As I pointed out, the income tax threshold, or the amount of tax exempt income, has risen from $4,595 to $5,100 per annum. The success of this Government's economic policies, its stringent fiscal restraint and the broadening of the income tax base have paved the way for the prospect of further cuts in personal income tax next year, and I believe that those income tax cuts, to be delivered from 1 July next year, will be quite substantial.

I want to direct some remarks to the parts of these Bills which relate to the Medicare levy. Low and middle income earners will benefit also from the provisions of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. In addition to authorising the collection of the Medicare levy, the Bill will increase the income threshold below which the levy is not payable. Of course that has been done in the past; I believe in every year of the life of this Government we have relaxed the income threshold for the payment of the Medicare levy. As a result of this Bill, more Australian families will not be liable to pay the levy.

This will further reinforce one of the primary objectives of this Government in developing the Medicare program-the development of an equitable medical insurance scheme which can provide universal high quality health services to all Australians based on their capacity to pay. I regret to say that under the previous Government there were gross inequalities in the provision of health cover because of the costs in relation to income required to purchase that cover. For example, in 1983 a family earning just above the health care card income limit had to pay of the order of 7.2 per cent of its income to obtain basic health cover. At the same time, a family on an income of $50,000-a very substantial income in 1983-had to pay only 1.4 per cent of its income to obtain the same level of health cover. So a high income family had to pay only 1.4 per cent of its income while a low income family had to pay 7.2 per cent-many multiples of the lower figure, to obtain exactly the same level of health cover. That was a grossly unfair situation and Mr Howard, the then Treasurer, and the Liberals condoned that position until they left office in 1983.

Of course, under Medicare all taxpayers earning more than the low income threshold now have to contribute 1.25 per cent of their taxable income towards health cover. In other words, health cover costs are now more in line with people's capacity to pay. Financing Medicare on the basis of each person's capacity to pay is not just equitable, it is also a major contribution to the social wage. The social wage, of course, has been one of the keystones of the accord with the trade union movement. The trade union movement now recognises that the economic welfare of its members and their families is not guaranteed simply by cash wage payments; it is also importantly underpinned by expenditure items provided by both Federal and State governments. They come under the heading of the social wage, and the Medicare health insurance system is an important part of the social wage provided by the Commonwealth Government.

Reverting to the pre-1984 system-that is, before Medicare-would mean that basic private health insurance at 1987-88 prices would cost an average family something like $21.50 a week more than the roughly accurate figure of $5.50 a week that such a family now contributes. So a family now paying $5.50 a week to obtain Medicare cover through the tax system would have been paying in the order of $27 a week to obtain the same level of health cover had the previous health system operated by the Liberals, by Mr Howard, still been in operation. Mr Howard has undertaken, in the unlikely event of his becoming Prime Minister, virtually to dismantle the Medicare system. In other words, he would be increasing the cost of health insurance. That would hit low and middle income earners in Australia the most and, as the figures I have put on the record demonstrate, that would mean a significant impact on the social wage of those lower and middle income Australians.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to a number of misleading statements by the honourable senator and point out that the Opposition has no intention of announcing its policy on Medicare at least until the election.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Senator Messner has really dug a deeper hole for the Opposition, because he is obviously telling the Australian people that they should buy a pig in a poke. It seems the Opposition has no intention at this stage of announcing its health policy. Mr Howard has certainly made statements which indicate that the coalition would dismantle Medicare. The measures it would put in place would virtually dismantle the system, they would completely emasculate it, and would hit the standard of living of lower and middle income Australians who benefit enormously from the present system. They would be paying the equivalent of $27 a week to obtain the health cover they are getting at the moment for $5.50. That is the comparison.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Is it in order for an honourable senator to continue to misrepresent a case in the way Senator Maguire is when what he is saying has just been plainly denied?
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The point I am making is that in the dreadful event of a Liberal government being returned to the treasury bench--
—Ask the people in the Bush Nursing hospitals how they feel.

—If we went back to the days before Senator Patterson was here, when we had a ridiculous private health insurance system which left two million Australians without cover, people would be paying the equivalent of $27 a week for health cover which they now get for $5.50. That is what it comes down to. A return to the archaic health system which operated when those opposite were in government would devastate the living standards of lower and middle income earners. One of the most important boosts to the living standards of ordinary Australians developed under this Government, which those opposite continually ignore, is the enormous benefits of Medicare. Their continued harping about wages and taxes completely ignores the enormous boost Medicare has given to living standards. We must remember, when making comparisons about taxes and wages, that there are important social wage programs such as Medicare over and above taxes and wages comparisons which affect the living standards of ordinary Australians. The point I am making is that if we were to go back to the sort of system the Liberals had, and now seem to want again, ordinary Australians would be paying $27 a week for health cover-$21.50 more than they are now. (Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted I was talking about the effect of Medicare on living standards. The substantial improvements to equity and the social wage under Medicare have contributed to its now becoming a widely accepted and approved part of Australian life.

speech.para: According to a recent public opinion survey, Medicare now enjoys an all time approval rating of 67 per cent; that is, 67 per cent of those polled said they supported the Medicare system. This is despite persistent criticism by the Opposition, carping about the system and pretending it does not exist. I ask the Opposition, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether it can boast a similar level of approval for any of its policies. Can it point to any of its policies where it has a 67 per cent level of support? Can it point to any opinion poll that shows 67 per cent support for the policies of the Liberal Party, for any of its proposed leaders or for the Party itself? Recently we saw an opinion poll in a national news magazine showing that, far from having a 67 per cent support rating, Mr Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition, had only 14 per cent support. I do not think the Liberals can point to any policy which has 67 per cent support, as there is for Medicare.

Lower and middle income Australians realise that their standard of living is enormously advantaged by having a universal system of health care. It is as simple as that. That is the reason why there is such a high level of support. It would be a dreadful mistake to go back to the old days of private health insurance. It was a costly and inefficient system with very high overheads, with a large proportion of its contributions eaten up by administrative costs. I think lower and middle income Australians realise that they are doing very well under the Medicare system.

The legislation before us today, along with the Government's overall reform of the tax system, will help ensure that the economic progress since March 1983 will not be put at risk. The Hawke Labor Government has already demonstrated its preparedness to face up to the hard decisions. Since coming to office in March 1983 it has worked consistently to reform the tax system. With renewed vigour, determination and imagination, we will continue to face the challenge of devising a fairer and more equitable tax system for Australians, a system that is conducive to the long term growth prospects of Australia. No doubt, and regrettably, this ongoing reform will continue to occur in the face of a hostile and belligerent Opposition.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in the second reading debate on the taxation Bills to make one point and one point only-the continuing abuse of this Parliament and the taxpayers of Australia by the Hawke Government with its penchant for legislation by press release. These omnibus Bills enshrine all manner of amendments to taxation legislation. In particular, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 hides one of the most gross cases of retrospective abuse that this Senate has been asked to pass. The Bill seeks to implement, subject to what the Government calls minor variations, the proposal announced on 4 February 1985-I emphasise that-to tax non-cash business benefits. This amendment was announced 3 1/2 years ago, yet only now has legislation been brought forward.

speech.para: Taxpayers have been obliged to arrange their affairs for a period of 3 1/2 years on the basis of a press release by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). This is simply not satisfactory. It becomes even less satisfactory when the Treasurer finally brings in legislation which he says varies the original announcement. The question needs to be asked: What is the obligation of a taxpayer to comply with a law that is not a law but merely a statement by the Treasurer? Not only does this question need to be asked but, more importantly, it needs to be answered. What is there to prevent a government from making an announcement and calling it a law for five or even 10 years? Clearly, this Government thinks that 3 1/2 years is not unreasonable. The only thing that will stop an arrogant government like this from behaving in such a high-handed way is for the electors to toss it out. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am proud to be a member, Madam Acting Deputy President, as I presume you are, said of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) in its twelfth report of 1988:
The Committee has consistently argued over a period of several years that legislation made retrospective to the date of a Ministerial announcement is undesirable . . .

The Committee again questions how a person may be expected to know the content of a law when the terms of that law are not publicly available, but may only be ascertained from a reading of Ministerial media announcements, or, in this case, a draft bill which was modified in content before its presentation to the Parliament.

The Committee accordingly draws the clause to the Senator's attention as it may breach principle 1 (a) (i) and, due to its retrospective effect, may be considered to unduly trespass on personal rights and liberties.
The Acting President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Alex Chernov, QC, has also issued a statement recently endorsing the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's remarks. He said:

The Law Council, like the Committee, has repeatedly urged the Government-and particularly the Treasurer-to stop using media releases to usurp the legislative role of the Parliament in a way that makes a mockery of the rule of law.

As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Law Council of Australia have indicated, this is not the first time that legislation has been made retrospective to the date of a ministerial announcement. I suppose one could read through ministerial press releases to find out about legislation but it would take a lot of reading. I have here a pile of press releases-I show them to honourable senators-by the Treasurer and Acting Treasurers of this Labor Government announcing changes to legislation that in due course are to be agreed to by the Parliament. I do not know what is meant by `due course' because in this case it is 3 1/2 years ago. Here is a pile of press releases which represent legislation by press release. If members of the public like to find these press releases and go through them they may find out what is in the Government's mind for them for the next four or five years-hopefully, they will not be subjected to this Government for that long.

talk.start.para: —It is simply outrageous.

—It is outrageous. I just cannot believe this pile of papers here. I would again like to refer to what the Law Council of Australia had to say about legislation by media release. This view of the highly regarded and influential Law Council sets out accurately what is evil about this Government's habit of using press releases to usurp the proper role of this Parliament. This document is so important that I propose to quote it in full:

speech.para: The Law Council of Australia has renewed its condemnation of the practice of the Federal Government known as `legislation by media release'.

This is the practice by which the Government announces its intention to ask the Parliament to pass a law at some future and perhaps indeterminate time-but declares that the proposed law is to take effect immediately.

The practice, which is being increasingly resorted to by the Treasurer, is open to many objections, the most fundamental of which is that it involves a usurpation of the Parliament's legislative power by the Executive.

The fact of the matter is that once a media release has been issued stating that legislation is to be introduced and operate with effect from the date of the statement, individuals have no option but to act as if the law had thereby been changed.

This is at a time when the merits of the proposed legislation have not been the subject of debate in the Parliament. It is beside the point to say that Parliamentary approval will be obtained in due course. The scope for proper consideration by the Parliament is severely limited by the media statement.

The individual, with his advisers, is placed in a most unsatisfactory position. He is forced to adjust his business transactions in anticipation of the proposed legislation. He does not know, and cannot ascertain, the details of the future provisions. Nor indeed can he be sure that the legislation will in fact be enacted or whether, if enacted, it will accord with the announced details. He may not even become aware of the media statement because it does not form a part of the law of the land and is not published as if it were.
The Law Council is not on its own in condemning this practice. As long ago as 1975 Mr Justice (now Chief Justice) Mason of the High Court condemned the practice in the following terms:

``There is, first, the risk that the proposed alteration will not be made by Parliament and there is, secondly, the possibility, sometimes unfortunately realised, that the law when enacted will not correspond exactly with the antecedent announcement. Above all, it is a technique calculated to encourage people to disregard and, indeed, to disobey the law.''
More recently, strong criticism has been voiced on a number of occasions by two Senate Standing Committees-the Committees on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and on the Scrutiny of Bills.
The latter Committee in its annual report for 1986/87 said:

``As the Committee has repeatedly stated, the practice of `legislation by press release' carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament.
``. . . quite apart from the debilitating effect of the practice on the Parliament, it leaves the law in a state of uncertainty.''

In a recent letter to the Law Council, the Treasurer has endeavoured to justify his practice by saying ``no arbitrary fetters can be allowed to interfere with the Government's ability to deal promptly and effectively with tax avoidance''.

I just interpolate that the Treasurer's statement that `no arbitrary fetters can be allowed to interfere with the Government's ability to deal promptly and effectively with tax avoidance' is the same kind of promptness he has demonstrated in getting in his tax return. In my view, a press release issued 3 1/2 years ago is not prompt. The letter continues:

To the extent that this implies that the Treasurer has been confining his legislation by media releases to measures to prevent tax evasion it is wrong and misleading. The Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has in fact in its annual report for 1986/87 criticised the Tax Office for resorting to the practice ``as a matter of administrative routine''.

While basically it opposes all retrospective legislation, the Law Council recognises that from time to time the Government will see a need for urgent action to prevent unacceptable tax-evasion practices. The Council has in fact put to the Government suggested guidelines* which would take account of such matters and ensure that the undesirable consequences of the media release practice were minimised.

The Government, however, has declined to accept these guidelines. It has amended instructions in its Cabinet Handbook, but these instructions are quite inadequate. The Government is plainly minded to continue to `legislate by media release' on a much wider range of matters and subject to much less stringent conditions than have been proposed in the guidelines.
The time has come for a halt to be called. The practice is making a mockery of the rule of law.

When an organisation such as the Law Council of Australia says that the practice we are now seeing is making a mockery of the rule of law one should be very concerned. The citizens of this country should be very concerned. For the information of honourable senators I seek leave to table the Law Council guidelines referred to in the letter I quoted.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. In addressing the Bills which are the subject of this cognate debate, I have confined my remarks to the one issue, but a fundamental issue. Indeed, it is one of the most fundamental issues facing this Parliament. If we, the representatives of the people, are deflected from our responsibilities in defending them from unreasonable actions by governments, if we fail to give proper scrutiny to proposed legislation-how on earth are we supposed to when we see half of it in this sort of form?-if we allow governments to treat as binding on citizens rules that are not enshrined in legislation, we are living in a dictatorship. Yesterday in this chamber I spoke on the export development grants scheme, expressing my concern at the lack of advance warning exporters have had about changes that will affect them. I also spoke about my concerns regarding the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the improper, and, I believe, illegal, way it originally implemented the current household expenditure survey. Today I have been compelled to speak about the totally unacceptable approach this Government has made to circumvent this Parliament and to legislate by press release. We are not living in a dictatorship-yet. However, unless we maintain our vigilance over this Government and its Ministers, who believe they can thumb their noses at the Parliament and its constitutional rights, we may yet be living in a dictatorship.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —Since 1983, when Mr Keating became Treasurer, the average wage has increased by 40 per cent, but the average tax bill has increased by 80 per cent. These figures represent the cold, hard reality. They show that the average Australian knows just how deeply Mr Keating is dipping into his pocket or her purse. The Opposition has moved certain amendments which will highlight just how convoluted and hard to understand tax legislation has become. I believe that the legislative process should be accessible and understandable to the general public. Accordingly, Bills which are presented to parliament should be able to be understood by the intelligent layman. However, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 and cognate Bills are anything but that and are a further indication that the whole range of taxation legislation is in urgent need of a complete overhaul.

speech.para: Members of the Liberal-National Party coalition have been urging the Government at least to take some steps towards revamping the Income Tax Assessment Act so that it can be understood. As an example of the complexity involved in these Bills it should be noted that Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988 alone-and we are considering a package of Bills-provides an additional 54 pages to the already copious amounts of tax legislation. The Opposition does not really oppose these Bills but it would like to highlight the tax jungle into which Treasurer Keating has led the ordinary honest citizen. For example, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) are the third and fourth major taxation Bills that have been brought forward in the 10 months of this year. When one turns to the explanatory memoranda one sees that it is clear yet again that the Government is proposing retrospectively to legislate in the area of non-cash benefits through proposed new section 21a of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and also by press release. For example, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, an amendment to the main Act, will tax non-cash benefits that are in the nature of income. This was announced on 4 February 1985-almost four years ago. It has taken four years to get that press release into some form of legislation before this Parliament.

The Treasurer is yet again putting forward proposals to change laws which were announced, in some cases, two, three or four years ago. We are seeing changes being introduced, not by legislation passing through this Parliament-the Bill being presented to the Parliament, speeches being recorded in Hansard and Ministers explaining it clause by clause-but by press release dropped into the press gallery boxes by members of Mr Keating's staff. Clearly, this is not good enough. It is a sorry state of affairs and a great insult to this Parliament and the people of Australia. In fact, in its last report, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills-an all-party committee of this place-again implored the Government to halt this undesirable practice of legislation by press release, as it had done in numerous other reports. Obviously the Government has taken no notice-it has taken no notice of its own members' requests.

It has become common to say that the Hawke-Keating Government is the highest taxing government in more than 40 years, but that does not make the statement any less true or shameful. The new system of self-assessment with the associated stiff penalties requires the Commissioner of Taxation to have a very wide taxation knowledge. Unfortunately, the business community is complaining that this increased emphasis on field audits is resulting in investigations often by inadequately trained tax officers because of a lack of resources. There have also been allegations of some tax raids being psychologically brutal. In the area of complex taxation it is also important that the Commissioner continues public rulings, even though there is no statutory obligation to provide them. Unfortunately, there is sometimes a lack of suitable linkage between what we might term the Tax Commissioner's objective analysis within the ruling and his preferred position. This would indicate that perhaps the legal department of the Australian Taxation Office is under-resourced. Although I welcome the decision of the Tax Commissioner to provide public and private rulings-and sometimes these private rulings are referred to as `advance opinions'-it is regrettable that these private rulings can apply only to the taxpayer who has sought the advice. They cannot be used as a general precedent. The rationale behind that is that sometimes the facts may not be identical.

Clause 25 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) terminates the accelerated depreciation concession which allowed plant write-offs over three or five years. The loss of this concession will have a big impact on the mining and manufacturing sectors which are essentially capital intensive. Although the offset for the loss of accelerated depreciation was a lower corporate rate, the companies that benefit most are generally those which are less capital intensive rather than manufacturing enterprises. At a time when the Government places such store by technology this is a retrograde step, because we are trying to bring Australia's manufacturing capabilities and expertise into line with the more competitive companies operating overseas.

It has become the practice for some operators or entrepreneurs to switch their depreciation method-from the diminishing value method to the prime cost method-at a point at which the prime cost method will give the greater deduction. The amendments before us today are aimed at preventing that practice and will remove the option of changing depreciation methods. Instead, the taxpayer will be required to make an irrevocable choice of method at the outset-that is, each year the taxpayer will be required to decide which depreciation method will apply to all his plant that is first depreciable by him in that year. Once that decision is made, the taxpayer will be required to continue to depreciate that plant by the method chosen until the end of its depreciable life. I raise this issue because it has not been given widespread publicity.

In another change the Government has reversed an earlier decision to tax the remote area housing scheme. This decision was subsequently changed, again by a government press release, on 29 October 1986. This is but another example of the Government's tardiness in bringing to a legislative base a decision which was made more than two years ago.

While there is some evidence of intimidation of tax agents by the Australian Taxation Office, I hope that this is not widespread. The growing lack of rapport between the Taxation Office and the professions must be reversed. The recent raids on the offices of Allen, Allen and Hemsley, Coopers and Lybrand and Citibank Ltd support this developing conflict and raise the question of professional privilege, particularly in relation to the photocopying and taking of documents and working papers. I believe the Government must take some responsibility for this situation as it continues its relentless pressure on the Taxation Office to collect more and more revenue from people. In fact, some financial journalists have suggested that one or more of the highly publicised Taxation Office raids were actually `fishing expeditions'. The Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Conwell, has been quoted as saying:
The Australian Taxation Office is keen to determine just how full and free access can be taken.

However, the term `fishing expedition' had another connotation recently on the Central Coast of New South Wales when it was reported that taxation officials were on the piers and the foreshore with cameras photographing a recent game fishing tournament.

The Taxation Office rejects the charge that those individuals who own expensive cars, boats and other such items are targets for tax investigations. However, there have been reported instances of this occurring. I quote one such incident in Melbourne where a luxury car retailer was approached by the Taxation Office to provide his company's register of all the expensive cars sold.

The Government takes great delight in criticising the taxation policies of the Fraser Government. Let us look at a few facts. In the 1982 Budget presented by Mr Howard, the average worker in middle class Australia was earning about $550 gross. He lost 23 per cent of this to the tax man. In each and every year since 1983, under the Treasurership of Mr Keating, the same taxpayer has been hit by a higher marginal tax bracket, ranging between 41c and 46c in the dollar. This is the truth about the present Government. It has picked on these people who represent the average Australian family with mortgages, children to educate, cars to pay off and provisions to be made for retirement. In fact, this Government is truly remarkable because it is hitting those middle income Australian families which, in its rhetoric, it claims to support. It has hit them with the highest taxes since World War II. More than two million taxpayers have been pushed into the top two tax brackets since the 1982-83 fiscal year and almost half of these have been pushed by this Treasurer into the top bracket.

In all these Bills before the Senate today, the Government is continuing its plan to increase the hidden taxation liability by again raising the provisional tax uplift factor. In the House of Representatives, the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) said that this uplift was to take account of the expected movements in property incomes and incomes in the unincorporated business sector. I remind the Senate that property incomes include rent, interest, dividends and the like. I accept the sincerity of Mr Morris but I draw the attention of the Senate to yet another example of the prospective tax increases based on unearned income.

Apart from that, there is a hidden inconsistency within these figures. The Budget predicts an inflation rate of 4.5 per cent, but the Government has determined an uplift factor for provisional tax of 12 per cent, lifting it from the previous year of 11 per cent. This is far higher than the inflation rate. Mind you, on top of this we have to add the Medicare levy to apply to that provisional income. The inflation factor is less than 4 per cent overall. Obviously the inflation factor for the ordinary pay as you earn people must have been significantly below the 4 1/2 per cent, maybe 2 or 3 per cent. We know that this clearly is quite untrue because of wage increases that have already occurred or are in the pipeline.

This is further evidence that the whole Budget strategy is quite unsound, particularly in relation to the expected blow-out before the end of the year. What the Opposition has been imploring for some time is that the Government try to increase the capacity for incentive in the work force. In fact, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has tried to do this and so has the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). But how can their efforts be successful if small and medium business people and people thinking about acquiring a business are shied away not only by crippling high taxation but also by the threat of press release by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) being issued without warning and drastically changing their tax liability?

In another place it was revealed that the Business Council of Australia survey of 16 countries with similar economic systems to Australia's showed that Australia had the second highest business taxation level. In fact, Australia was surpassed only by the Labour Government in New Zealand, a country whose economy is facing very turbulent times. Not only are lower and middle income earners in Australia being hit but also small and medium businesses, both with a record of high taxation levels. The only winners are the very rich, for instance, those earning over $3,000 a week, and the multinational conglomerates.

One of the Bills in this package of Bills we are debating cognately is the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. While we support the provisions in this Bill in alleviating the levy from the lower income earners, it is timely to remind the Government of its estimates about the cost of running the Medicare system. The Opposition has stated, from time to time, that these estimates are far too low and that the system now is becoming more and more expensive. There is no commitment to change in providing proper access to quality health care for all members of the community.

I now turn to another amendment proposed in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Clause 46 proposes to alter the roll-over provisions on the transfer of assets between spouses following a marriage breakdown. This change is to apply only to indirect assets transfers which occur after 28 January 1988. The Government is thus in my view intervening in the role of the Family Court of Australia in changing the nature of transfers carried out by order of that court. I ask: Why should this change apply from 28 January 1988? Why should it not apply when the capital gains system was introduced in 1985? The answer which the Minister will readily give is, `Well, after all, that was the date when Mr Keating issued his press release'. This does lead to the ludicrous situation where judges of the Family Court are expected to be aware of the Treasurer's press releases which announce changes in the law even though they have no legislative base. Perhaps Mr Keating should include Their Honours all around Australia on his Press release distribution list.

It has long been an important principle that, `The man is only liable to pay tax according to the law of the day'. The Government appears to be presiding not only over crippling bracket creep-in other words, while one's income goes up one's tax goes up by a very much greater amount or percentage-but also over a creeping disdain for Parliament. It does this by this practice of announcing changes to the media and many months later putting up a Bill to Parliament to ratify the press statement, as it is doing in this package of Bills before the Senate today.

I must impress on all honourable senators that, while this is a technical Bill which tidies up at the edges certain taxation laws, including taxes introduced by the present Government, and we do not oppose the technical changes as such, we deplore the Government for its tardiness in bringing these measures forward. We deplore it for the convoluted manner in which it has brought them forward, adding to an already highly complex taxation Act which is not understood by the ordinary individual. It brings another professional group between the layman and his understanding of the law. This high tax regime Government must urgently address the issue of tax which is paid by ordinary middle income Australians, because until this is alleviated people's standards of living will continue to decline. This will be the issue that the Australian people will take Bob Hawke and his Ministers to task on at the next election. With these reservations and comments I do not oppose the technical changes in this Bill.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I support the remarks of Senator Watson. While not opposing the technical changes in the legislation-it is another collection of technical changes to add to the extraordinary volume of technical changes that have been forced upon this incompetent Government and this disgraceful tax Act-I nonetheless draw the attention of the Senate once again to the amendments moved by Senator Messner, which in fact point out the extraordinary failure of this Government to convert the rhetoric it has expressed about tax into reality. The reality is that this Government, which continually talks about making the tax system fairer and reducing the tax burden on ordinary Australians, has in fact masterminded the most disgraceful attack on ordinary Australians through tax legislation.

speech.para: Australia now is without doubt higher taxed than ever before. The Australian people, particularly Australian pay as you earn taxpayers, are now suffering under the highest taxing government in Australia's history. That is roughly the burden of our amendments that we have moved to the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 and foreshadowed to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. While not opposing the legislation, in our foreshadowed amendment to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) we are saying:
At end of the motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(b) the Government has mainly relied on bracket creep through the various personal income tax brackets, and also on the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax to fund its Budget surplus;
(c) such new taxes represent increased complexity and uncertainty in the administration of the taxation system and so decrease efficiency and equity;
(d) the Government has lost sight of the needed direction for Australia's future; and

(e) the Government should accept that the highest priority needs to be given to reducing the enormous tax burden, so that the standard of living of Australians can be improved while at the same time addressing the nation's external economic problems''.
With Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) we are suggesting a similar amendment. The amendment reads:
(a) notes that this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;

(b) notes that this Government's so-called tax reforms invariably involve simply offsetting tax reductions in one area by tax increases in others, as witnessed in this Bill by the termination of the 5/3 depreciation arrangement to offset a reduction in the corporate tax rate;
(c) notes that the Government continues its propensity for taxation by stealth by again unaccountably raising the provisional tax uplift factor;

(d) notes that the Treasurer has failed to meet his responsibilities in respect of the administration of the taxation system and has hidden behind the rhetoric of the Commissioner of Taxation and encouraged the undermining of the rule of law in taxation matters; and-
Senator Watson certainly dealt with that-

(e) condemns the Government for its practice of `government by press release' which can cause otherwise legitimate legislation to be called into question because of the unacceptable retrospectivity thus introduced.

These are not minor complaints; these are concerns of a major nature at the style and the content of this Government's taxation law. This Government has set out to mislead the people of Australia continually on taxation and I believe has done so in a particularly disreputable way by using the Commissioner of Taxation in a political context. I presume that this is not really because he desires to be in a political environment but because he has been propelled to be a defender of the Government's tax policies in the public forum in a way that I believe has diminished the status, the independence, of the Commissioner of Taxation. The appearance of advertisements arguing the Government's highly political case for individual tax changes is an absolute disgrace. If the Treasurer (Mr Keating) wants to sign advertisements arguing a political position, that is up to him. If he chooses to use taxpayers' funds to do so, then that is a matter he can argue politically. But for the Commissioner of Taxation and his department to sign advertisements arguing a political case for a particular kind of tax, which this Opposition, for example, is opposing at the time, strikes me to have hit at the very heart of the independence and the non-political nature of the Public Service in Australia. I believe that what has happened in the area of tax in this way not only has been disgraceful but also has damaged the fabric of the system that has served us so well for so many years.

I believe the level of resentment in the private sector against the activities of the Commissioner of Taxation does not relate simply to his commendable enthusiasm for pursuing tax cheats. I support him on that. I endorse his very energetic chase after money that should have been paid to the people of Australia through the tax system by those people who have avoided their responsibilities. That does not mean that I can support or endorse the intrusion of the Commissioner in a political way into political issues of whether a particular tax is one that should be politically supported. The waste of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money in advertisements signed by the Commissioner is not only unfortunate but also unsupportable. I do not believe the Government really has the capacity to argue otherwise. It will certainly pretend that there has been no change-the reality is that there has been. That is only one of the many changes for the worse in taxation that have taken place under this Government. The main change is the one that every taxpayer in Australia feels through his hip pocket, and that change is, of course, the ever-increasing burden that Australian taxpayers have to pay.

In the recent Budget we saw that the total individual tax take in the coming year is forecast to rise by $5.7 billion, or 13.6 per cent. That is more than double the expected rise in average weekly earnings, which are expected to rise by 5.75 per cent. The Government has responded, `Ah, but that doesn't mean you are going to pay more tax'. The Government is saying that the total tax collection will go up at double the rate of wages, but that that does not mean that individual taxpayers will pay more, because it has a special curious mathematical capacity which endeavours to deny reality! With the Government's extraordinary public relations operation, the National Media Liaison Service and the other extraordinarily expensive Ministerial Media Group, it has the capacity, at public expense, to spend millions of dollars in propaganda to try to pretend that one and one do not make two. The reality is that there will be a 13.6 per cent increase in the individual tax take, but only a 5.75 per cent increase in average weekly earnings.

The Government's justification for this is, `Ah, but there are going to be more people at work and, because there will be more people at work, therefore the volume of tax will go up without each person having to pay more tax'. That sounds almost plausible, but not quite plausible because the Government does not give us the sums and does not tell us the amount by which tax revenue will be increased as a result of more people being at work. It does not tell us because it knows it will destroy its case. The Government knows that the truth is that the bulk of the increased tax take this year by this Government will come from people who are already employed and who are simply paying more tax this year because of this Government's use of fiscal creep. When I use the words `fiscal creep', I am not referring to the Treasurer himself, although I think it is a fairly apt description.

talk.start.para: —Order! I suggest that you be very careful, Senator.
—I am being extraordinarily careful.
—You are being very lax in relation to standing order 418.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I refer once again to fiscal creep in its inanimate form even though it has been alleged that the Treasurer does have the appearance of a mortician. Nonetheless, let us look at the situation of fiscal creep, which is the arrange- ment by which inflation pushes people into higher tax bills. The tax bill goes up at a faster rate than their wages. Every Australian knows that that happens, and that will happen to a very significant extent this year. We have heard continually from this Government that it has cut taxes and plans to cut taxes more. Every so-called tax cut that this Government has produced has resulted in Australians paying more personal income tax. On top of that we have the massive expansion of indirect taxes in this country under this Government: the introduction of a tax on ice cream, fruit juice, orange juice, flavoured milk and paddle pops. This kind of spread of taxation under this Government is on top of the fact that fiscal creep is pushing more people into higher tax brackets and they are having to pay more. The legislation we are looking at today is yet another example of the enormous volume of tax legislation which, frankly, has done nothing to diminish the burden of taxpayers in Australia and, on the contrary, has been part of the process of significantly increasing it.

speech.para: We now face a much more interesting situation. The Government has promised to cut taxes significantly. It will be interesting to see how it manages to do it because the tax cut was, hopefully, to be part of a deal with the unions in which wage rises were traded off for tax cuts. But that was when the Government was pretending that there would be an inflation rate of 4 1/2 per cent this year. I say `pretending' because it was never on. The Budget, which was brought down less than three months ago, was based on a farcical forecast that this year inflation would be reduced to 4 1/2 per cent. The recent inflation figure of around 7.2 per cent clearly indicates that this financial year there is not a chance-not that there ever was-of that forecast being met.

The Government will face very great difficulty in convincing the union movement that the tax cuts that it will introduce will be so substantial that they will offset the negative effect on Australian standards of living of a 7.2 per cent inflation rate. I expect the present rate to be reduced, but perhaps to around 6 per cent-certainly not 4.5 per cent. What will the Government do if that wages trade-off cannot survive? It will be faced with an enormous economic dilemma which will be solved in one way: the higher the inflation this Government's incompetence creates in Australia, the bigger its tax collections. I often wonder how genuine this Government is in the fight against inflation because whenever it has budgetary problems it stands to benefit in its tax collections from the highest possible inflation rate. While it talks low inflation and low tax, it acts in a way that increases the inflation rate and increases people's tax bills. There is an enormous gap between what the Treasurer and this Government say and what they actually do. It is remarkable.

Let us look at interest rates, for example. Soaring interest rates in Australia have resulted mainly from this Government's failure adequately to cut government spending. This has now created another enormous burden on Australia. Only recently the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia said that because the fiscal measures-those that should have been taken-were no longer available there would be a very heavy reliance on monetary policy. That means that interest rates will have to go up and stay high because the Government did not face its responsibilities in cutting its own spending. The implications of interest rates going up are other costs going up. The inflationary pressures that have already mounted in many areas will be sustained.

The Government is very keen to cut the States' revenues but very reluctant to cut its own. In many instances, cutting State revenues means that the States have to try to find other ways of raising money. State charges and costs then increase, which is then reflected in a higher cost of living. A great deal of publicity was given by the Treasurer to the fact that in New South Wales increased government costs and charges to offset, in many instances, significant cuts in Federal funding were the main factor in the big increase in inflation that has set the Government's strategy askew. In fact, the Government's strategy has not survived three months after its Budget. We are already hearing people talk about the absolute necessity of yet another May statement.

We have a clear situation where the Government's strategy has gone astray. Taxes will increase even more than the Budget indicated because of the inflation factor. The cost of servicing this Government's debt will be even greater, I imagine, than the Budget figure forecast. It is inevitable that interest rates will be far higher than the Government budgeted for when it said that the interest bill on its enormous debt would be $7.6 billion. This $7.6 billion is just the interest charge on debt. That is as much as this Government spends on defence; it is more than it spends on education. This Government's activities have generated high inflation and high interest rates at a time when it is absolutely vital for Australia to compete if we are not to see our foreign debt get bigger and our standard of living fall further.

Let us get back to those promised tax cuts which I believe the Government has no capacity to provide. Even if it does provide some tax cuts, inflation will have pushed Australians into such high tax brackets that the tax cuts will be meaningless. I remind the Government that, if it is unable to deliver the promised tax cuts, it cannot go round pretending that it has been prevented by the Opposition from collecting the revenue it needs to provide these tax cuts. Clearly, the best way to provide tax cuts is to cut spending. That is what this Government will not do. Instead, it has been saying that it will collect tax in other ways. For example, the tax file number legislation would collect, at its peak, $300m.

Last week we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say that if the Opposition did not support the tax file number it would be seen to be the friend of tax cheats and, by inference, this would prevent the Government from giving the people the sorts of tax cuts that it otherwise could give. That is total bunkum.
