We are not talking about just $300m to give Australians a genuine tax cut; we are talking about billions of dollars that this Government has to give back to the people-money that it has ripped out of their pockets by the insidious, sneaky, dishonourable method of simply pushing people into higher tax brackets by having an economic policy which allows inflation to proceed and the cost of living to go up. That pushes people into a situation where they have to pay more and more tax. In that sense, the Government is the Grim Reaper. I understand that this appellation has been used in respect of the Treasurer without anyone objecting, apart from the Treasurer.

talk.start.para: —I think he rather regards it as a compliment.

—Yes, he probably does. In the few minutes remaining, I want to say that there are some specific features of these two additions to the tax law. One of them is 46 pages odd, another 50 pages odd, adding to the trebling of the size of the tax law under this Government. The enormous increase in the physical size of the tax legislation that has taken place under this Government is extraordinary. There was a considerable increase in the size of the tax legislation under the previous Government-we have to recognise that-but the great bulk of the increase in the tax law that took place under the previous Government was to replace section 260, which the Commissioner of Taxation believed had been knocked out by the High Court of Australia. We had to pass tonnes and tonnes of amendments, it seemed, to the tax law to make up for the fact that section 260, in the Commissioner's view-I underline that-had been knocked out. Now we find that section 260 is alive and well and that a lot of that legislation was unnecessary.
—And living in Canberra.

—And living in Canberra. As I said, as section 260 is alive and well, obviously a lot of the legislation we were forced to pass was unnecessary. This Government has no such excuse. This Government is passing amendment after amendment because it has incompetently presented legislation in the first place or because it has put out so many press releases about what it is going to do that, 3 1/2 years later-or who knows how much later-it is then obliged to come out with legislation to put its ancient press release into effect. I noticed the other day that something like 280 amendments were made to company legislation within, I think, a month of that legislation having been brought into this chamber. That sort of monumental incompetence may suit the Government, but it certainly does not suit the Opposition, and it does not suit the people of Australia.
—When do you think they will bring in the superannuation legislation?

—There are many suggestions that the Government will not bring in the superannuation legislation. But who knows? We have a government legislating by press release. We have heard all sorts of objections to that recently. They are not new. We have been complaining about it ever since the Government set out on this abhorrent course-and it is an abhorrent course, as the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reported recently. This legislation was announced 3 1/2 years ago. People are supposed to have been abiding by this law, which has not existed. However, the press release saying what the law intended to do was released roughly 3 1/2 years ago. It is to operate from 3 1/2 years ago. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in its recent report, stated:

speech.para: The Committee again questions how a person may be expected to know the content of a law when the terms of that law are not publicly available, but may only be ascertained from a reading of Ministerial media announcements . . .
That view seems reasonable to me. I wonder why the Government cannot get itself into some state of competence to do something about the situation.

talk.start.para: —How do you reckon the Avon ladies would have got on reading that thing over the last 3 1/2 years?

—Exactly. People have been obliged to know not only the words of the press release but also the legal implications and potential subtleties of a law that was to be introduced 3 1/2 years later. How ordinary Australians can hope to cope with that ludicrous situation is beyond me. But this Government does not mind about that; it has no concern for the rights of individual Australians. It has no concern for the pockets of individual Australians, except a concern that as much as possible be ripped out of those pockets in order to feed an increasing government sector.

speech.para: It is all very well for the Government to say, `But we have recently cut down the size of the government sector'. I remind the Government that in its first two years in office it set out on a course which involved a massive increase in the size of government. In its first year in office, it made immense play, in a May statement, of the fact that it was reducing government spending by, I think, a little over $1 billion. In its first Budget, it increased government spending by $2 1/2 billion. The following year it increased government spending by something like $1 1/2 billion. The cumulative effect over a full year of those increases in the role of government, to the disadvantage and at the cost of the Australian people, was enormous. Any slight withdrawal from that huge increase that may have taken place in the latest year still leaves this Government having to be the biggest taxing government in Australia's history because it has to pay its enormous bills. Its huge debt involves an interest cost of as much as we spend on defence, and more than we spend on education. That huge interest bill has emerged as a direct result of this Government's massive increases in government spending in its earlier years of office. As Australians we all now have to pay that bill.

That is why we are moving these amendments in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). It is not that they will change the operation of these two Bills but because we are drawing to the attention of the Australian people the fact that this legislation is further evidence of continuing increases in the tax law, a tax law that has left Australians with the greatest tax burden ever in Australia's post-war history-a tax burden that is a direct result of this Government's policies.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Stone Sen J.O.

talker.name: Senator STONE
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —This morning we are debating four Bills cognately: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. In the relatively brief period available to me before Question Time, my remarks will initially be of a general character, relating to the Government's policies in the taxation field covered by these Bills. Thereafter they will be directed at a couple of aspects of the Bills: first, the extraordinary retrospectivity of certain provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988, in particular, clauses 38 and 43; and, secondly, by sharp and very marked contrast, what one might call the non-retrospectivity of clause 46 of that Bill, a clause which deals with the roll-over provisions in respect of assets owned indirectly by a person who might be called a `transferor spouse' by means of a trust or company, where those assets are to be transferred to the other, previous, partner in a marriage as a result of an order of, or pursuant to a maintenance agreement approved by, the Family Court of Australia. As I say, my remarks on that clause at a later point will be directed, so to speak, at the non-retrospectivity of that provision.

speech.para: I wish to commence my remarks on the more general aspects of the Government's taxation policies as related to the four Bills before the Senate today. We have been promised by this Government-we were told this most formally in the Budget Papers, as Senator Michael Baume, who has just concluded his remarks, quite properly pointed out-major tax cuts as from 1 July 1989. There was, it is fair to add, a marked lack of quantification in those promises and in particular there was no definition as to what in any case constitutes a tax cut in the vocabulary of the present Government. After all, we have had a couple of tax cuts, so-called, from the present Government during its life. What taxpayers are well aware of is that the real burden of their personal income tax is higher today than it has ever been before.

talk.start.para: —Every time you have a `tax cut', your tax goes up.

—As Senator Michael Baume quite properly reminds me, every time we have a so-called tax cut the real burden of taxes seems to rise, or at least within 12 months it is higher than it was 12 months earlier. There may be immediately, on day one, some nominal diminution, but 12 months later one is further behind in the field than when one started. That is the first point to be noted: when this Government talks about tax cuts, what does it mean?

speech.para: To sharpen the definitions a little, I suggest that the only meaningful definition of a tax cut is one which reduces the real burden of taxes-one which results, for example, in getting away from the present situation under which the Government has this year again, for the third time running, raised personal tax levels in this country to their highest level on record. I am talking now in terms of taxation levels as a proportion of the gross national product and by reference to other indicators of that kind. For example, if the Government is serious in talking about making tax cuts in any coherent sense from 1 July next year, it will have to start talking about real tax cuts. In particular, it will have to take note of the fact that it will have to cut taxes by at least $2 billion for 1989-90 in order to stop the real burden of such taxes rising, because that is about the extent of the degree of bracket creep which will be imposed upon the taxpayers of this country in the course of the fiscal year 1989-90 by simply doing nothing. So the Government has to `give away' about $2 billion of revenue by new measures in our next financial year in order to stop the real burden of personal income taxes rising.

Beyond that point, what can or is the Government likely to do when it comes to address, as it will in the new year or perhaps even before the new year, its capacity-I underline that word-to give tax cuts, at least in a responsible manner-that is not a word with which the Government unduly troubles itself; nevertheless we must give it the benefit of the doubt-over and above just giving back the product of bracket creep, as from 1 July next year? I have covered these matters at greater length than I will certainly be able to do when I resume my remarks on these pieces of legislation next week in a paper to the bicentennial economists congress which I delivered in this city, at the Canberra Hyatt Hotel, on 2 September 1988. At that time I pointed out that the only manner in which the Government can provide real tax cuts responsibly in 1989-90-leaving aside any adventitious gains we may get from any terms of trade windfall, which we have not considered and which the Government, to be fair to it, is not considering-is either by way of cutting its expenditure, which is most important, or by way of the productivity growth of the Australian economy. Of course, the latter is not at present noted for its rapidity. What we have is a situation in which the Government is basically looking down the barrel-I should say, the two barrels-of a gun, comprising of the failure of its own economic policies--

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Will the Minister confirm that Tranby College received a large grant of the order of $500,000 from the new commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) to conduct consultations on the so-called treaty-$100,000 to be used for the establishment of a secretariat at Tranby and $400,000 to be used for consultations? Was this decision made without regard to submissions or paperwork and was an ADC subcommittee, comprising commissioners Dodson, O'Shane and Yu, set up to administer the funds? Is Tranby College the headquarters of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations, with which Dodson, O'Shane and Yu have close links? Is it also a fact that Mr Robert Riley, the senior adviser to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, is a former Chairman of the Coalition and is still a senior prominent member of that Coalition?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —It is a fact that Tranby College, which as I understand it is incorporated in New South Wales as a cooperative institution for the furtherance of Aboriginal matters, did receive substantial funding, I think of the order of which Senator Tambling spoke, for the purposes of advancing consultation within the Aboriginal community around Australia in regard to the proposed treaty-to give it the shorthand title that has been spoken of over the last several months. Those moneys were provided to Tranby College by a decision of the Aboriginal Development Commission. I will have to get an answer on whether a particular committee comprised of particular people was set up in relation to the administration of those moneys.

answer.para: Senator Tambling asks whether Tranby College is the headquarters of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations. I imagine I will be able to get an answer on that reasonably quickly. He also asked whether Mr Robert Riley, an adviser to the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, is a past president of the National Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations and is still a member of that Coalition. I will seek information on that matter.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Are the consultations and the expenditure of $400,000 or $500,000 consistent with the Government's announced policy with regard to a treaty? Do they arise in any way from the announcement of the Prime Minister at Barunga, near Katherine, on 11 or 12 June? What direction did the ADC receive with regard to this matter from either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs?
—Order! The question is really a completely new question. However, I will ask the Minister whether he will answer it.

—Mr President, I will answer it as far as I am able. I do not know whether the Aboriginal Development Commission, in making its decision, was acting on any directive. I will certainly find out whether that was the case. The general picture that emerged during Estimates committee deliberations in relation to decisions of the Aboriginal Development Commission was along the lines that the Commission itself concluded that these particular consultations with the Aboriginal community were an essential part of any process of involving Aboriginal people, as they ought to be involved, in such an important matter which requires the fullest, most comprehensive and exhaustive discussions in a way which is amenable to the traditional modes of discussion, deliberation and consultation, peculiar perhaps to Aboriginal communities when compared with discussions that might take place within other sections of the Australian community. It was on that basis that Tranby College, with its long history of dealing with Aboriginal matters, from its early church based days if I recall the evidence, and in more recent times, was considered well qualified by the ADC to undertake this particular consultation process. I will seek answers to the other questions asked by Senator Tambling.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of claims made recently by the Victorian Minister for Tourism, Mr Crabb, that the national carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd, operates with an unfair bias towards Sydney, and that Qantas has blocked other carriers from serving Melbourne? Is there any basis to these assertions?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —This claim is periodically made by Victorian politicians on both sides of the fence. It is one I contested with some vigour in my previous ministerial incarnation. It is one that I think has to continue to be resisted whenever it is made, as no doubt it will be for time immemorial. Claims that Qantas is a Sydney based organisation from top to bottom and run exclusively by Sydney people as a Sydney airline are plainly insupportable. For a start, four members of the 12-member Qantas board, including the Chairman, are Victorians. The company operates eight fully owned travel centres in Victoria as against 11 in New South Wales and employs almost 1,000 staff to support its operations in Victoria. Again, there is no substance to claims that Qantas has been attempting to block foreign airlines from serving Melbourne. The matter of air services agreements, including rights to foreign airlines to serve Melbourne, has been and remains a matter to be determined finally by the Australian Government in negotiation with other governments. Consequently, claims that a number of foreign carriers including Swissair Pty Ltd, Iberia Spanish Airlines and Lauda Air, are being blocked by Qantas in operating flights to Melbourne are without foundation. I can certainly endorse that from personal experience.

answer.para: The proposition that Qantas is concerned only about the welfare of Sydney and not about the rest of Australia also does not stand up to any detailed examination. With the commencement of services to Tasmania early next year, Qantas will operate international air services to all Australian State capital cities as well as a number of key regional centres such as Cairns, Townsville and Port Hedland. Qantas currently spends in excess of $200m annually promoting overseas tourism to Australia as a whole. As such, it is probably the largest single contributor to promoting this extremely important activity which benefits all States including, of course, Victoria.

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister for Finance had cause in the last month to write to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs expressing concern at the apparent redirection by the Aboriginal Development Commission of $3.5m allocated by Mr Hand to be spent on priority areas of enterprise development and housing to traditional land purchases? Does the Minister consider the redirection as overturning intended Cabinet decisions? Is such conduct acceptable to him?

—I am not sure whether this came out in the Estimates committee hearings or not. I expect that it would have done. There were some differences between the figures published in the Budget Papers and the estimates which were presented to Estimates Committee E. I wrote to Mr Hand about those differences, but I am not going to disclose to Senator Crichton-Browne or anybody else the full details of correspondence between Ministers.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is it a fact that funds, specifically allocated to the Aboriginal employment development policy by Cabinet for the purpose of priority areas of enterprise development and housing, were redirected without Cabinet approval or any other approval? If so, is that conduct acceptable to the Minister? Is it a fact that it was an overturning of a Cabinet decision without any resolution?
—I have nothing to add.

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the recently announced decision of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to reject a proposal to reduce the caffeine level in cola drinks. Does the Government agree with this recommendation?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —Senator Zakharov raises a matter which has been of interest and concern to the NHMRC and its various committees for a number of years-in fact almost eight years now. It is a proposal to reduce the allowable level of caffeine in cola drinks from the current 145 milligrams per kilogram to virtually half that, to 75 milligrams per kilogram.
—Why face Question Time without a coke?

—I take caffeine warm. The NHMRC has rejected a proposal which has been advocated by a number of consumer groups within Australia. In view of the proposal to reduce the acceptable level the NHMRC has recommended an educational campaign. Its decision was based essentially on the fact that it did not have enough scientific evidence to indicate adverse health effects from caffeine in the cola drink as it is now being sold in the Australian community. In its decision it also noted that we already have one of the lowest levels of allowable caffeine in cola drinks throughout the world and that, in terms of effects on people's intake, caffeine through cola drinks contributes only in a minor way to the level of intake of most consumers. So with those thoughts in mind, the NHMRC has rejected the proposal virtually to halve the acceptable level of caffeine in cola drinks.

answer.para: It should also be noted in the context of this decision that there are a number of protections to Australian consumers. The presence of caffeine is very explicitly shown on labels-and that will continue-as opposed to many other ingredients that are listed under the general generic label of flavouring. As I mentioned earlier, if we were to reduce the acceptable level of caffeine, we would have one of the most proscriptive levels in the Western world. In fact, we would go down to about 40 per cent of what is currently allowable in the United States of America. Throughout the world at the moment the acceptable level ranges from 150 milligrams to 200 milligrams per kilogram of drink. So even at the moment we have the fourth lowest level of any country in the world.

In conclusion, I am quite relaxed about the decision of the NHMRC; in fact I welcome it. It is very much in line with my position and the Government's position on this matter, which was stated on 19 September 1988 in Sydney, where I indicated very clearly that the position of this Government was that we did not think there was a case for reducing the level of caffeine to the level wanted by some consumer groups.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the widely publicised leaked report of New Zealand's Prime Minister Lange to his Cabinet, in which the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, are reported to have said that if New Zealand pulled out of the Anzac frigate project, Australia-New Zealand relations would suffer. I also refer to Mr Beazley's reported view that `the region required . . . a frigate force of some 20 ships', that Australia needed New Zealand's `help' to achieve this number, and that industry protection would be applied in Australia if New Zealand did not participate in the Anzac frigate project. I ask the Minister: Does he know what are the details of the industry protection referred to by Mr Beazley? In the light of the reported apparent threats by Mr Hawke and Mr Beazley, and in the light of Mr Beazley's public statements on industry protection, did Senator Richardson mislead the Senate in his statement of 11 October that `there is no question of Australia threatening New Zealand' in relation to its decision on the Anzac frigates? Will the Government apologise to the people of New Zealand for having, at least up until recently, secretly tried to pressure the New Zealand Government into sharing the burden of Australia's defence and regional ambitions? Finally, what steps will the Government take to guarantee that the Australia-New Zealand relationship will continue to strengthen, irrespective of New Zealand's decision on the Anzac frigates, and that no further attempts will be made to counteract the democratic process in New Zealand?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —That is an enormously lengthy and detailed question. As a matter of fact, I did not hear a lot of it because the Opposition was having a front bench conference in competition with Senator Haines's voice which, if I might say so, I found very attractive. Nonetheless, I am able to comment to some degree.

answer.para: First of all, I think Senator Haines essentially asked me to comment on an allegedly leaked document and I am not disposed to do that. Of course, it is up to the New Zealand Government to make a decision on whether it will participate in the Anzac ship project. The suggestion in the leaked document is that the Australian Government might have tried to exert some influence on that decision. Of course the Australian Government is anxious for the New Zealand Government to participate in the project, but that does not mean that there was any further influence in advancing that view. Indeed, it is interesting to note that Mr Lange himself has rejected the suggestion that Australia was seeking to influence New Zealand in any heavy-handed way, and made clear that his decision to have a blue water navy preceded any talks with Australia.

As I indicated a minute ago, we see considerable benefit in maintaining interoperability here between the Australian and New Zealand navies as a way of preserving joint interest in the region. The Anzac ship project offers us a way of doing that and the Australian Government has gone to great lengths to match its requirements with those of New Zealand in terms of specifications, pricing, delivery arrangements and logistic support. If Australia and New Zealand are to maintain an effective defence relationship, I guess there is a need to maintain the military capabilities on which the relationship is based. I repeat in answer to what I interpreted to be the substance of the question: in no way has the Government sought to bring improper pressure on New Zealand on this issue.

After I study the honourable senator's question, there might be one or two aspects which I have not succeeded in answering, in which case I will endeavour to provide an answer to those parts. But I think the honourable senator will agree that it was a complex question and I would like to look at it before attempting to answer it all.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to an article in the Daily Mirror of 3 November headlined `Iron Lady's Poll Battle' in which Senator Bishop's hunting of the carefully coiffured scalp of Senator Puplick is given some treatment.
—What has this to do with the price of fish?

—The honourable senator will find out. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act relating to the declaration of election expenditures by candidates? Do these obligations extend to expenses incurred by candidates in Federal preselections within political parties, such as the bitter struggle currently under way within the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party of Australia? If the Electoral Act does not cover those preselection expenses, will the Government consider bringing forward amendments to that effect?

answer.ministerial: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —When it comes to disclosure of electoral expenses, we heard a lot about it in the first half of this year, but we have heard very little over the last few weeks. The reason for that is quite explicit. There was a New South Wales election at the start of the year in which the Australian Labor Party had an embarrassing incident, and we were sought to be embarrassed. What has in fact occurred over recent weeks is that the embarrassment is on the other foot, and we have heard no question and no discussion from those opposite. Plenty of free cars have been dished out in New South Wales. The Community Polling organisation is apparently free to put in false returns and it is now investigating a situation where tens of thousands of dollars were secretly given to candidates.

answer.para: I remind people opposite of the propriety of events at the start of this year, when we said we would deal with these matters properly. They were dealt with properly, in spite of all the prejudging of those opposite, in spite of all the questions that went to Senator Tate and me. Everything was done according to Hoyle. The opinion of the Director of Public Prosecutions was sought and necessary action was taken. I think I can guarantee in these other cases that absolutely no action will be taken. If Senator Aulich wants evidence of that, I just remind him of the claims that were made in this chamber regarding fraudulent voting in the Castlereagh by-election in 1980, in which one of the protagonists he referred to made those outrageous claims. I have written to Premier Greiner on two occasions and I have been put on the long finger each time-no action will be taken on those allegations, basically because they know the result would be to disprove them.

The honourable senator asked whether the Commonwealth Electoral Act could be regarded as covering preselection battles in as much as they can be expensive and eventually lead to someone's election. It is fairly unlikely that any drawing of a long bow could take that view. For instance, I understand that the Australian Taxation Office does not allow deductions for preselections, but only for elections as such. I do, of course, note in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that an esteemed member of the Senate said:
There has never been a preselection that I'm aware of where so much money has been thrown around in support of an internal Liberal Party decision.
Apparently there have been five cocktail parties, and a video and colour pamphlets have gone out. They are not disclosable under the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

talk.start.para: —Don't you wish you were a delegate?

—My first and only preselection cost me $1.10 for 11 phone calls, and look what the Party got-good value for money: whereas with those opposite the party always gets the best politician money can buy. It is quite interesting.
—That was good value.

—I reckon it is good value, too. The big difference between Senator Chaney and me is that when I run for preselection I do not get dudded at the last moment by my party, which he did by Mr Allan Rocher.
—Look what they got.

—This also applies to Senator Crichton-Browne. Mr President, I have only two other things to say about this. I do not think in the long run it would be appropriate to bring internal party matters within Federal or State legislative regulation. I think one of the great benefits of our political system is that the internal affairs of the political parties are not regulated as they are, for instance, in the United States of America. In some ways I am disappointed that we cannot do so in respect of misrepresentations. For instance, one of the candidates has been going around saying--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is giving a most enjoyable answer but I suggest that, having both amused us and responded to interjections in his defence, he is now proceeding to debate the matter and to canvass matters which are really quite irrelevant.
—I ask the Minister to wind up his answer.

—Mr President, I will just wind up with this anecdote: some time ago I read in the Howson Diaries of a young member who was attending the House of Commons for the first day. He was shown around the chamber by a very experienced parliamentarian. The young bloke went straight to the front of the chamber and said to the old bloke, `I want to be here. I want to look into my enemies' eyes'. The response of the old bloke was, `Well, all you will see from here, son, is the Opposition. If you want to see your real enemies, go to the back stalls'.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Does proposed section 7 of the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988, now before the Senate for debate, set down the global borrowing limits for the Western Australian State Government and its instrumentalities? Does this mean that, in the event of the Western Australian Government being called upon by the provisional liquidators of Rothwells Ltd to meet its obligation under its guarantees to the National Australia Bank Ltd for loans to Rothwells merchant bank totalling something like $150m, the State Government will need to negotiate higher borrowing limits at a future Premiers Conference? Failing this, will the taxpayers of Western Australia be called upon to meet any outgoing or shortfall in its obligations through higher taxes and charges? Further, has the Minister examined whether the global borrowing limits for Western Australia have been exceeded already following the recent investment of $175m in Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd by the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission, which funds were apparently financed by way of loan?
—I point out to the Minister for Finance that the answer should not anticipate debate on a Bill which is before the Senate.

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I do not think it will because it is a question of fact really. Proposed section 7 of the Bill to which, incidentally, the Government is proposing a couple of amendments, which do not change what it is intended to do or will do, does impose global borrowings on the Western Australian Government and all other State governments.
—Yes, they do. The amendments change the definition.
—I am not going to get into an argument about that now. As to the guarantee that the Western Australian Government has given, I am not sure that that guarantee is still alive.

answer.para: I was also asked what would be done if Western Australia exceeded its borrowing limits. The position, as I understand it, is that the agreement of all the States and the Commonwealth Government is required if any State wishes to exceed the global borrowing limits agreed to unanimously, with the exception of the Queensland Government, at the Premiers Conference. Frankly, I do not have the faintest idea whether Western Australia is approaching the global limit at this stage. But I would be surprised if it was.

talk.start.para: —Does the Minister representing the Treasurer recall statements by Mr John Elliott some 12 months ago that Australia was an unattractive place for business to invest in? Is the Minister aware that the statements received widespread national and international publicity at that time? Further, does available statistical evidence indicate that the content of Mr Elliott's statements is shared by the business community as a whole?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Mr President--
—Here is a full toss down the leg side.

—It is more like a free kick in the square. I do recall Mr Elliott saying, on more than one occasion actually, things like Australia is a terrible place to invest in and so on. Frankly, I never knew why he said it-whether he was trying to give his mates in the Opposition a handout or whether it could be attributed to too much Fosters. Whatever his motives may have been, the facts show that his views are not shared by the business community as a whole. The most recent figures on business investment and expectations are extremely good. The Budget Papers show that total investment spending in the last financial year was up by almost 10 per cent in real terms and a further rise of 12 per cent has been forecast for this year.

answer.para: An article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 October referred to a survey that was conducted by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce and the State Bank of New South Wales. That survey showed that spending on buildings and plant and equipment during the last quarter has increased. Of the 541 respondents to the survey-that is, about 29 per cent of the New South Wales manufacturing work force-23 per cent reported increased market share at the expense of imports during the last three months.

As Senator Button has already mentioned, last month North Broken Hill-Peko announced that it was going to go ahead with a $1 billion investment in a pulp mill in Tasmania. Further to that-and this makes Mr Elliott's behaviour even more confusing if he really is moving a motion of no confidence in the Australian economy-it is a little strange that the two representatives of ERN who sit on the North Broken Hill board had supported the investment decision, according to a report in the Australian of 18 October. ERN is commonly known as Elders Resources Ltd and one of its two representatives on the North Broken Hill board is the same Mr John Elliott who, under different circumstances or in different places, moved a motion of no confidence in the Australian economy.

So Mr Elliott's views about the attractiveness of Australia as a place for business investment seem to be about as confused as his views on whether he wants to get into Federal Parliament and roll the present Leader of the Opposition or not.

talk.start.para: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, concerns the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) investigation of Rothwells Ltd. Will the Minister confirm that the NCSC has been exercising its powers under section 16a of the Companies Code to carry out investigations as it thinks expedient where it suspects that an offence may have been committed under the Act by a company involving fraud or dishonesty and/or the management of the affairs of a company? Will the Minister advise the Senate as to the nature and scope of the investigations? Furthermore, is the Western Australian Government's involvement being examined? In particular, can he tell the Senate the extent to which its sponsorship of Rothwells encouraged small investors and gave false comfort to creditors, or will Crown immunity again be claimed as in the case of the Bond-Bell-State Government Insurance Commission affair?

—In so far as I am able to discover on behalf of the Senate the answers to the questions that Senator Hill has raised, I will certainly undertake to do that. One has to recall that the NCSC is responsible to the Ministerial Council and not to the Commonwealth Attorney-General. Indeed, we found when questions were asked before the end of the last session- -
—You found that you have been kept in the dark.

—We found that the NCSC is not responsible to the Commonwealth Attorney-General. Therefore, political responsibility is not as clear as it could be. As we all know, there is a matter before the Parliament at the moment. Those lines of political responsibility and answerability between the Commonwealth Attorney-General and the National Companies and Securities Commission-or whatever it may become in a new guise-are at the very key of the reforms which the present Attorney-General is trying to persuade this Parliament to adopt. I undertake to find out what I can from the NCSC, and in so far as that information is made available it will be passed to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports of a coup in the Maldives. Will the Minister make Australia's position on this question clear and emphasise the support that Australia has always shown to democratically elected governments?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Government deplores the attempted coup in the Maldives. We condemn the brutal attack that appears to have been made on the elected government of a peaceful Indian Ocean state. There have been reports of civilian casualties. It is believed that the foreign mercenaries involved in the attack are now holding a large number of civilian hostages. The Government of India, in response to a request for urgent assistance from the Government of the Maldives, has sent paratroops to the Maldivian capital, Male. This action in defence of an elected government under attack by foreign mercenaries has the full support of the Australian Government. I emphasise the issue of foreign mercenaries here because it does, among other things, distinguish the situation from a number of others where people may be tempted to draw comparisons.

answer.para: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, through the Australian High Commission in Colombo, has been in contact with two Australian citizens in Male who are safe. Other Australian citizens, including up to 200 tourists, are also in the Maldives. However, they are on other islands away from the combat zone and are believed to be in no danger at this stage. We are keeping a very close eye on the situation, to the extent that we can without resident representation on the ground. We fully expect to see the restoration of the elected Government and hope that that can be achieved without further bloodshed.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In the light of the Government's intended campaign to encourage Australian citizenship, why does it deny, on the grounds of period of residency, the opportunity for citizenship to a person who arrived in Australia more than two years ago but has spent part of the subsequent time working in Papua New Guinea, when that work has been through an Australian company, on a temporary contract, remitting both fees and income tax to Australia, thereby benefiting the Australian economy? Is the treatment of ordinary migrants in these circumstances, in meeting residential time requirements for citizenship, consistent with the concessions afforded business migrants for time spent overseas?

answer.ministerial: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —Quite properly, Senator Chapman did not refer to the individual by name, so I do not know the circumstances. There is a section in the Migration Act that allows us to dispense with the two-year waiting period if, for good reason, an individual has served in the circumstances which Senator Chapman indicated or there are other urgent circumstances. So that two-year residency can be varied-I think on grounds of compassion and hardship. I do not recall the exact section of the Act. If the honourable senator wants to refer a specific case for my attention, I promise him that I will give it prompt attention. I do not think that it has come to my personal attention at this stage, although it may well have been dealt with by the Department.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Would the Minister regard it as consistent that the Australian Taxation Office, for income tax purposes, regards the same person as a resident for the period of absence while the Immigration Department does not?

answer.ministerial: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —I suppose that presumes a certain merit in consistency. Sometimes government is inconsistent, with the very best of motives. Theoretically and philosophically, it likes to be as consistent as possible, but I do not think that that will ever be totally achieved. The Tax Office does have its own eclectic approach to these matters and I doubt that I will have any influence on changing it. In terms of the specific case which Senator Chapman raised, there are provisions in the Act for variation for good reason. If the honourable senator advises the person concerned to avail himself of those rights, through his local member of Parliament-presumably himself-we will see whether we can deal with it.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, is of particular interest to the citizens of the northern part of the State that I represent. I ask: What action is the Government proposing to take to limit the influx of Indonesian fishing vessels into Australian waters? Did any proposals for cooperative action emerge from the Minister's recent discussions during his visit to Indonesia?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —There are two separate dimensions to the problem of Indonesian fishing vessels in Australian waters and they are sometimes confused in the public perception of it. One concerns the traditional fishermen in non-powered boats or boats with, at most, an auxiliary outboard for emergency situations. Their access to Australian waters is governed by a 1974 memorandum of understanding which deals with, among other things, the ability to take water on the Ashmore and Cartier Islands and suchlike. That has given rise to a number of problems in recent years, not least as a result of the passage of environmental protection legislation in Australia for areas such as the Ashmore and Cartier Islands. It has given rise to a number of problems in interpretation and enforcement. The discussions that I had on that part of the problem with the Indonesians were very productive. We have identified some areas that need to be followed through, with a further round of negotiations in order to update, and possibly revise in some respects, that memorandum of understanding. I look forward to that being sorted out over the next few months.

answer.para: The more substantial and obvious problem has concerned the recently very rapidly escalating influx of commercial fishing vessels into Australian waters fishing for trochus or, more recently, netting commercial fish of one kind or another. The Australian Government has reacted in a number of ways to this: through improved surveillance activity, apprehension of the boats, legal proceedings, and proposals to destroy the boats in question. However, there is obviously a need to deter at source, rather than to rely wholly on ex post facto measures. With that in mind I discussed this matter very extensively with the Indonesians at a number of levels-the Foreign Minister and the Defence Minister and their respective officials. In the case of the Foreign Minister and President Suharto, we had quite a substantial exchange on this topic.

As a result, the Indonesians decided to send a substantial team of officials, quite soon-within a matter of days-to all the relevant fishing village areas of Indonesia to make very clear the consequences of trespassing in Australian waters. Perhaps more substantially even than that, urgent action is to be taken by both sides to set up more formal and ongoing institutional arrangements, possibly in the form of a joint border committee of the kind that Indonesia has with a number of its neighbours which offers an institutional channel through which information can be accumulated and exchanged and appropriate practical measures taken to deal with a particular situation. One of the things that would be considered under such a set of institutional arrangements would be coordinated naval activity by both sides. There are some logistical difficulties associated with that, particularly on the Indonesian side, which might make that not a practicable proposition. However, that remains to be explored and it will be.

There are a number of other solutions to the problem that remain to be explored. One that may be worth pursuing occurred in a letter which was drawn to my attention this morning-I presume it was in today's West Australian-from a correspondent by the name of I. Bevan, which reads:

My suggestion to keep Indonesian fishermen out of Australian waters would be to jail them in the same cell as Jo Vallentine. After two days of listening to her they would wish they had remained at home.

talk.start.para: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Australian Financial Review of 2 November reports that Australia has rejected Soviet requests on fishing. In view of the fact that no announcement has been made to the Parliament, nor any press release circulated, will the Minister advise the Senate whether a statement on this matter of considerable importance is to be made to the Parliament or whether the limited private media discussions of Mr Duffy are to serve as the only official advice to the Parliament, particularly in view of the different versions that have been circulated?
—I will take up that question with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and advise Senator Archer of what the Minister intends to do.

—Can the Minister for Resources indicate the significance of the agreement that I understand he has signed today with the Canadian High Commissioner for joint Australian-Canadian membership of the ocean drilling program? What benefits will result for Australia from this program?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Today geoscience in Australia made a massive stride forward. We have signed what many in the geoscientific community have been working towards for some time: an agreement between Australia and Canada for joint membership of the largest, most important international geoscience and marine engineering research program for the 1980s and 1990s, the ocean drilling program. Eighteen countries participate in the ocean drilling program. They pool scientific information and the financial costs of running that program and they explore the earth's last frontier, the ocean floor.

answer.para: The ocean drilling program spends about $50m per annum on research into the structure and history of the ocean floor. Australia's contribution under this agreement will be $1.2m per annum over the next three years. The funds that we are contributing come from a consortium of public sector institutions: $400,000 from the Bureau of Mineral Resources; over $600,000 from the Australian Research Council; $100,000 from the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee; and $50,000 from the Antarctic Division of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. All of those bodies will benefit from the scientific information discovered through the ocean drilling program.

Australia will make a number of big gains because of this program. Twenty-five holes will be drilled in Australian regions over the next two years. That drilling will occur mainly in or alongside our Antarctic Territory. Some will occur in the south and south-east of Australia and some in the north-west. If that drilling were done commercially it would be valued at about $100m. In one of the holes that has been drilled in the north-west of Australia an ancient, previously unknown reef, about 220 million years old, containing promising signs of oil sediments, has been discovered. That discovery could have been made only by this type of program.

talk.start.para: —Are you trying to beat Barry Jones?

—I am trying to give some information which is relevant to the scientific community in the answer to the question. Maybe it would serve the honourable senator's interests to listen carefully because it is important information in terms of what is fundamental research in Australia. The program, as I have said, will provide essential information on the ocean floor. As well, it will provide information on the evolution of climatic change, sea level alterations and mechanisms related to the greenhouse changes that have been occurring. It is a once-in-a-generation program. Australia will benefit in another way, too, in that the supply vessels and the drill ship associated with the ocean drilling program will be supplied and equipped at Australian ports when they call there. That is estimated to be valued at about $2m per port visit. It is a very forward looking program and one to which we hope to attract private sector funds in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the policy of the Romanian Government for the ruthless resettlement of its Hungarian minority in Transylvania, involving the destruction of more than 7,000 villages. Given that more than half of the villages in Romania-the great majority of them in the Hungarian community areas-are involved, does not this destruction amount to cultural genocide by the Ceausescu totalitarian regime? Is the Minister aware of the enormous concern already expressed in this country, as illustrated by the petition I presented to the Senate on Tuesday from more than 5,000 South Australians-the largest petition presented this year-stating their objections to this destruction in Romania? Given the Government's expressed concern for civil rights in foreign relations policy, I ask the Minister: What protests have been made by the Australian Government to the Romanian Government on this issue? Finally, is it the case that the Romanian Government is pressing Australia to establish an embassy in Bucharest? If so, what has been the Australian Government's response?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I am a little cautious these days about attributing the label `genocide' to any activity. It is one that ought to be applied with great care. Certainly, in this instance a very unhappy situation has emerged in Romania. It is one to which the Government has responded, and to which I respond again today. On 28 September I met participants in the pro-Transylvania run from Melbourne and Sydney to Canberra, and conveyed to them publicly both the Government's and my concern about Romanian policies towards its ethnic Hungarian minority. We are certainly well aware of the rural urbanisation plans of the Romanian Government, which will have a quite devastating effect on a great many rural communities, including the Hungarian minority, through, as Senator Teague said, the planned demolition of 7,000 villages and the urban resettlement of their inhabitants. The Australian Government has clearly and directly expressed its concern about the human rights situation in Romania, including this rural urbanisation scheme, to the Romanian Government on 18 August to the Romanian Charge d'Affaires in Belgrade and on 31 August to the Romanian Deputy Foreign Minister in Bucharest.

answer.para: Australia's trade relations with Romania are not inconsistent with our human rights concerns. This is a matter that is constantly raised and one that always gives governments some concern. Australia trades with a number of countries whose policies we do not agree with. It is only in rare cases in which there is agreed and concerted action by the international community, such as in regard to South Africa, that trade sanctions can begin to be effective as a means of bringing about a change in a country's policies. We take the view-I think it has some foundation-that our human rights representations are likely to carry weight precisely because of the importance that Romanians attach to their commerce with us. Each of these situations must be treated in a case-by-case way. Certainly, there is no question but that the Australian Government condemns, in the strongest possible terms, what is going on in Transylvania and has communicated that to the relevant authorities.

talk.start.para: —The embassy?

—I have explained that it has been done through the Charge d'Affaires in Belgrade and the Romanian Deputy Foreign Minister in Bucharest. What else would Senator Teague like us to do? Does he want us to wear sackcloth and ashes?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister of the last part of my question: is it the case that the Romanian Government is pressing Australia to establish an embassy in Bucharest? If so, what has been the Australian Government's response? With regard to the Minister's general references to trade, is he aware that West Germany and the United States have cut back their trade with Romania? He talked about action in concert with other nations. Specifically, what has the Government determined should be done to protest-and I thank the Minister for his answer; it is a protest by parties on both sides of this chamber and the Australian Government-at what is happening in Romania?

—I am not aware of the current state of play on the question of an embassy, nor whether there have been any recent developments in that respect. I will certainly find out. There is no question of any existing concerted action, of which I am aware, being taken by any countries in relation to Romania. There may have been some isolated instances of action taken by individual firms in the countries that Senator Teague mentioned, but I am certainly not aware of anything remotely resembling a government-backed sanctions policy being applied. It would be quite extraordinary, given the absence of will to apply those kinds of measures in the context of South Africa, in regard to which there is a world-wide willingness to engage in such action, if that situation were any different in relation to Romania. I will seek some further information and, if I am in a position to give any more substantial information than I already have, I will make it available.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Consumer Affairs been drawn to a recent article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail headlined `Tyre scam ``could kill'' '? Does this article claim that slightly used tyres of inferior quality are being imported to Australia and sold to unsuspecting local motorists as new tyres? Has this allegation any substance and, if so, what measures are being taken by the Australian Government to identify the culprits involved in the scam, which I believe, clearly puts the lives of Australians at risk? What penalties are in place in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and the Northern Territory against people convicted of this type of practice? Finally, have any consultations taken place between the Federal and State governments on this issue or are any planned in view of the allegations printed in the Courier-Mail?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —I am aware of the problem Senator Jones raises. It is claimed by local tyre industry sources that slightly used tyres have been imported. Having been bought cheaply in Japan, they are sold to dealers here and are subsequently sold to motorists, and at the time of sale they are claimed to be as new. In fact, I understand the tyres are up to 10 years old and it is claimed by the industry that they are failing in service and, as Senator Jones says, pose serious risks. However, in trying to confirm the allegations, we have been able to ascertain that second-hand tyres are being imported, but are being sold as second-hand tyres and not as new tyres. As a consequence, the misleading advertising provisions of both the Trade Practices Act and State fair trading legislation do not address the problem, because, if they are in fact sold as second-hand tyres, there is no ascertainable misleading conduct.

answer.para: Generally, the responsibility for tyre safety falls very much within the province of State and Federal transport Ministers. In this instance the authority the Main Roads Department in Queensland, has been approached by members of my Department to see whether we can distil any further information from it. The authority indicates that it has had no reported instances so far of dangerous accidents or serious impending problems because of the tyres being sold. However, the authority does believe that there is a problem that needs to be addressed and, as indicated, it believes that the sale of such tyres should be better controlled.

In regard to the last part of Senator Jones's question, I anticipate the matter will be raised for discussion between State and Federal governments. There is in existence, under the auspices of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which is a State and Federal body, a committee called the Vehicle Standards Advisory Committee. I anticipate that that Committee will be asked to address this problem, on the initiative of the Queensland authority.

talk.start.para: —My question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs follows his answer earlier in Question Time concerning the value of labelling and the protection given to consumers in regard to generic labels and so on. What reliance can be placed by investors on the generic label `authorised trustee investment'? I ask that question, of course, in relation to Rothwells Ltd, which had that status in Western Australia and elsewhere and which is now apparently not able to pay its depositors. What measures are taken to ensure the safety of investment for those people who put their money in an institution which is given that government imprimatur? Has the Minister seen Mr Dowding's statement wiping off the 1,200 small investors who are apparently caught, Mr Dowding being quoted as saying, `They have been warned.'? I ask the Minister: In light of the State Government's support for Rothwells, what was the warning issued, by whom was it issued, and what action will the Commonwealth take in the interests of those people who have consumed those facilities offered by the Rothwells bank and who now, it appears, are not going to be paid?

—I first answer this question by welcoming Senator Chaney's new-found interest in consumer affairs. I believe it was only half an hour ago that he was able to ascertain that the area is of some concern to the Government.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President: I think the fact that I had to ask who was the Minister for Consumer Affairs was more a reflection on the Minister's ineptitude and lack of presence than anything else.
—Sit down. This is frivolous.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I think I will let that point of order go; as Senator Cook suggests, it is frivolous. Senator Chaney asks a number of questions obviously related to an organisation in Western Australia. I think we can approach the matter of advice to investors and investment industry on a number of levels. In terms of individual consumers and investors the Government, together with consumer groups throughout the country, is looking at ways in which we can best assist those people who, because of overcommitment, have found themselves bankrupt or close thereto or who, because of bad financial advice, find themselves with problems. In regard to the latter, the Government is planning, as I think Senator Chaney would know, a rewrite of the current legislation. I think Senator Haines asked about this some months ago, and obviously at that stage Senator Chaney was not showing the interest that he shows now. The Government is looking at extending provisions to ensure that advice by investment counsellors is covered in such a way that consumers, whether they receive that advice either verbally or in writing, do in fact get some protection.
—Come on, Nick. Have a go at answering the question.

—I am not going to delve into the dirt, as Senator Chaney wants to do in this issue. What I am doing is addressing the question in the way I think I should properly address it, which is basically to put to the Senate the Government's response in terms of advising and assisting people in these sorts of situations.
—This was last week's question.
—Order! Senator Hill, you will cease interjecting. You have persistently interjected all through Question Time.

—Having detailed some of the responses that the Government is taking in these areas, without going into them in too much detail-I am sure, if Senator Chaney wants, he can either ask a supplementary question or write me a letter-I close on this point: it is interesting to note the attitude of the people in this Parliament who ostensibly and traditionally have claimed to represent the private sector, the sector that is keen to go into all sorts of bargains which involve risk--
—Buyer beware.

—It is the buyer beware mentality, as Senator Cook suggests. When we talk about consumer affairs this is raised quite often, whether by Senator Alston, Senator Short, or others. The caveat emptor philosophy that seems to dominate the other side when it comes to consumers and their place in the marketplace seems to raise its head only when one particular organisation does not seem to go as well as others are going, and in those instances we are talking about socialising losses or protecting those particular people who have embarked on investing in an enterprise where risk has always been understood to be a part of their investment. In short, the Government is addressing the problem of investment advice and its quality. It is addressing the problem of financial counselling, which is much more than any member of the Opposition has managed to do over the last six months.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I preface it by saying to the Minister that we have made it quite clear that we oppose taxpayers' money being used in the way the Minister described, but my question was totally ignored by the Minister. Is the Minister familiar with the expression `authorised trustee investment' or not, because he did not actually deal with that in his answer? Is he familiar with that expression at all? If he is, can he tell the Senate, as the Federal Minister responsible for consumer affairs, what reliance consumers can place upon that label which is affixed by a government to a savings or investment institution, and what measures are taken by governments to ensure that an institution which bears the label `authorised trustee investment' is in fact a safe investment for the widows and orphans who are presumably meant to be protected by that sort of investment?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —Once again, we do have a rather strange contradiction coming from the Opposition. When the Western Australian Government attempted to assist the organisation involved we received great criticism in terms of reaction from the Opposition that the Government was assisting and trying to offer some protection.
—Answer the question. You are supposed to be legally trained.

—If Senator Chaney cannot pick up the contradiction in his criticisms, then I do not know what he is doing in this place. There are provisions under the general structure of Australian law which offer protection to the sorts of people Senator Chaney mentioned.

He specifically asked whether any directive had been given by either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC)-obviously, directing that it should make such an allocation. answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Lewis asked me a question as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications about the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) and Mr Garvin Rutherford. I have sought advice from the Minister for Transport and Communications and am able to respond as follows. I am informed that Mr Garvin Rutherford, President of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters (FARB), did in fact make strong criticism of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in his speech of 9 October to that organisation's annual convention. I am advised that as a result the ABT wrote to Mr Rutherford on 13 October indicating a preliminary view that his comments amounted to contempt of the ABT in terms of section 25ab of the Broadcasting Act. That letter from the ABT was sent to the Minister for Transport and Communications for his information. I understand that at this stage the ABT is awaiting a reaction from Mr Rutherford on the matter.

answer.para: As to whether the Government considers it reasonable for FARB to criticise the ABT, I think that is appropriately a matter best left to FARB and the ABT themselves to sort out. I simply note that the role and functions of the ABT are, as Senator Lewis would know, the subject of an internal departmental review already and, moreover, examination by the House of Representatives Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. As to the article in yesterday's Australian entitled `Why the ABT must go', to which Senator Lewis made further, possibly rhetorical, reference, I understand this article is simply raising the question as to whether the ABT is still an appropriate form of regulatory authority, given the current direction of broadcasting and broadcasting technology. As I have already mentioned, these matters are the subject of an inquiry, both in the Department and by a parliamentary committee.

In the earlier part of my remarks this morning, when I set out my concerns, I referred to the Hansard account and to the Minister. I said

speech.para: In that-
that is, the Hansard-

we find that Senator Tate who was, I am told, advised by Mr Perkins in giving this response, answered in response to a question . . . that to the best of the officers' knowledge funds had not been committed.

I want to assure Senator Tate that I was not personally reflecting on him in any way.

The Hansard record continues:
Mr Gray-You are asking that of the Department?

talk.start.para: —by leave-Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1, standing in my name for the next sitting day, for the disallowance of the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 as contained in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Ordinance No. 72 of 1988 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. I noticed just half an hour ago that the Australian Capital Territory casino has been placed under a new cloud.
