—That is not the way I would put it.

—May I say that when I make this statement I am not necessarily reflecting the views of all of the members of the Committee in respect of the comments I might make in editorialising on this. The Senate needs to be advised that a number of important issues were raised in respect of this casino ordinance which related to the protection of the rights of individuals in respect of the way in which they may be treated by inspectors or by the Commissioner of Police. They related to the qualifications, for example, of the people involved as inspectors. They related also to the quite proper proposal that the Committee put forward in respect of tabling reports in this Parliament.

speech.para: I am pleased to say, as a result of those suggestions by the Committee, that we will in fact get a better ordinance than we had before. I would like to thank the officers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories who with me-I nearly said `late last night' but it was in fact into early this morning-worked on this matter. I would like to thank the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) for a very comprehensive and agreeable response that he provided to our suggestions. I would like to thank the members of the Committee for the speedy way in which they were prepared to deal with this matter this morning.

I can assure the Senate that, despite the fact that it has been speedily dealt with, I dealt with this matter in a particularly assiduous fashion. It was certainly appropriate for me to do so. Had I failed to have dealt with it in an appropriately assiduous manner I have no doubt that the Deputy Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, an honourable senator who has been recently described by the media as the formidable Senator Bronwyn Bishop, would have had my ears which no doubt--

talk.start.para: —And your tail.

—Indeed she would have. No doubt she would have been in a position to have added to the ears and the tail that she intends to collect from Senator Puplick tomorrow. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the correspondence of the Committee, for the information of honourable senators and others.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
THE SENATE
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
3 November 1988
The Hon. Clyde Holding, M.P.,
Minister for the Arts and Territories
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meetings of 20 October 1988 and 3 November 1988 the Committee considered the Casino Control Ordinance 1988 being ACT Ordinance No. 72 of 1988. The Committee draws to your attention the following matters.
(a) Excluded Persons

Section 69 provides that the Commissioner of Police may direct the casino licensee to exclude certain persons from the casino and, under section 6, the casino licensee must keep and provide a list of such people or incur a severe penalty.

The Committee considers that the Commissioner should be required to keep a list as it is the Commissioner's list. In addition it appears there is no provision for the person who is being excluded to be informed. The Committee notes that the Christmas Island Ordinance does require such service.
(b) Inspectors
Section 8 provides that the Minister may appoint any public servant or employee as chief casino inspector. No level of officer or qualifications are specified for this most important officer.

The Committee considers that means of identification of inspectors and their powers are generally appropriate. Section 14, however, gives wide powers to require certain acts and, having specified in s. 14 (2) (a) that the inspector is to give ``notice in writing'', s. 14 (2) (b) derogates from this by providing that the notice may be given orally ``where the inspector is satisfied that special circumstances make it appropriate''. The Committee suggests that this discretion should be limited by spelling out some criteria or requiring an emergency situation or, at least, requiring a test of reasonableness.
(c) Financial

The Committee believes that s. 17 dealing with the payment of fee and tax where the casino licence is suspended should include a reference to the licence fee having been determined under s. 15 as the tax is properly recorded as having been determined under s. 16.
(d) Tabling
Section 21 provides for the tabling of information before both Houses but gives the Houses no more authority. The Committee would welcome your comments on this.
(e) Membership of Authority

Section 25 provides for a Chairperson and 4 other members of the authority, appointed by the Minister. Section 27 (2) provides that ``If a member ceases to hold office before the end of the appointment, another person may . . . be appointed . . .'' Unless it were very near the end of a term, given the importance of the Authority's powers, the Committee considers it should be obligatory to fill vacancies.
(f) Operational Arrangements

Section 52 (3) provides that the Minister is to have regard to recommendations made by the authority as to the suitability of a proposed lessee. The Committee considers it unusual that provision is not made for the Authority to make recommendations in relation to the casino licensee who is more likely to be involved in the actual operations of the casino.
(g) Equipment
Section 60 provides that the Authority ``may'' approve equipment. The committee considers this should be ``shall''.
(h) People to be removed

Section 66 (3) (b) (i)-(v) list classes of people who may be asked to leave the casino. Section 68 (1) (b) (i) provides that the licensee commits an offence for ``knowingly or recklessly'' failing to remove the first four classes of people, but not people who have ``previously contravened the approved rules of an authorised game or rules of conduct in force in the casino.'' The committee recognizes that the first four classes are situations where a person ``appears'' to do something and that would be actually observable in the casino, whereas the fifth is not that situation. On the other hand, however, the offence is only committed ``knowingly or recklessly''. The Committee would welcome further information on this point.
(i) Cheques

Section 80 (2) provides that the period for presentation of Cheques is to be specified by Gazette notice by the Minister. The Committee considers that this may be more appropriately done by regulation, so that Parliament would be aware of the matter and it would be subject to disallowance.
(j) ``Dice''

Section 109 (3) (c) states that an ``illegal thing'' includes ``dice that has been marked, loaded . . .''. The Committee believes the wording should be ``a dice that has been marked, loaded . . .'' or ``dice that have been marked, loaded . . .''.
(k) Review of decisions
Provisions for review of decisions are included in ss. 125-127 and the Committee notes many decisions are reviewable.

The Committee also notes, however, that certain decisions which appear similar are not subject to review. The Committee would be grateful for comments on why the following decisions are not subject to review: s. 20 (3) and (5) (secrecy and divulgence of information); s. 39 (1) (approval of developer and owner); s. 40 (development agreement and variation); s. 41 (sale of casino); s. 42 (control agreement and variation); s. 45 (grant of licence); s. 48 (suspension of licence); s. 49 (procedures); s. 50 (assignment of licence); s. 52 (lease of casino by developer or proprietor); s. 53 (casino operation agreement); s. 54 (variation of lease or agreement); s. 86 (provision of information about casino employee); s. 96 (provisional casino employee's licence); and s. 129 (directions to management).

An additional point here is why the word ``owner'' is used in ss. 39 (1) and 41 (1) instead of the defined word ``proprietor'' used, for example, in ss. 42 and 43. The word ``ownership'' is also used in s. 40 (1).
(l) Forms

The Committee notes that many sections of the Ordinance refer to forms approved by the Minister: some of these are s. 50 (4) (b) (assignment of casino licence); s. 52 (4) (application for approval of lease of casino); s. 86 (1) (b) (information relating to casino employees); s. 89 (application for casino employee's licence); s. 94 (form of employee's licence); s. 96 (form of provisional employee's licence); s. 97 (application for renewal of employee's licence); s. 98 (variation of casino employee's licence) and s. 122 (form of statement of accounts). It appears there is no provision requiring tabling or even Gazettal of these forms. The Committee considers these forms should be made by regulation which would be tabled and subject to scrutiny.
(m) Annual Report
The Committee is concerned there appears no provision for the making of an Annual Report by anyone to the Minister or to the tabling of any such report in Parliament.
The Committee would welcome your assistance and advice in relation to these matters.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
3 November 1988
Dear Bob
Thank you for your letter of 3 November 1988 regarding the Casino Control Ordinance of 1988. I have dealt with the points raised in your letter below.
(a) Excluded Persons
I agree to amend the Ordinance as you suggest.
(b) Inspectors

I will amend section 8 to set a minimum qualification for this position. I agree with the point you make about the Section 14 and propose to amend it to provide that an oral direction is only to be given where the Inspector is satisfied that the circumstances amount to an emergency.
(c) Financial
I agree with the Committee on this point.
(d) Tabling

The Government was most concerned in drafting this Ordinance to ensure that as many aspects of the commercial transactions involved as possible were disclosed to the Parliament and, through it, to the public. This is why a tabling provision has been included. However, the reality is that the Government would not be able to successfully conclude the necessary commercial transactions if they were subject to disallowance. For this reason the Government believes that it is essential that these documents not be disallowable instruments.

(e) I am prepared to amend Section 27 to make the appointment of another person mandatory, provided that the Minister may decide not to make that appointment if he or she is satisfied that it would be inappropriate to do so, having regard to the small size of the remainder of the appointment period.
(f) Operational Arrangements

I believe that the existing provisions of the Ordinance will meet the Committee's concerns. Under sub-paragraph 23 (1) (d) (ii) the Authority is given the function of making recommendations to the Minister on the suitability of a proposed Casino licensee. Under subsection 45 (4) the Minister must have regard to the Authority's recommendations concerning such a person.
(g) Equipment
I agree with the Committee on this point.
(h) People to be removed
Sub-paragraph 66 (3) (b) (v) was inadvertently not referred to in paragraph 68 (1) (b). I will have the Ordinance amended to rectify this.
(i) Cheques

I agree that the period set should be subject to disallowance. I would also be prepared to provide for this by Regulation, but would prefer to use the `disallowable instrument' provisions of the Interpretation Ordinance 1967.
(j) ``Dice''
I agree to the suggested amendment.
(k) Review of decisions

I agree to making a decision under subsection 20 (3) reviewable. However, it is not appropriate to make a decision under subsection 20 (5) administratively reviewable, because the resulting delay may frustrate the purpose for which the information is being disclosed to a court. Instead, I propose to amend subsection 5 to provide that the Minister shall give the subject of the information such notice of his or her intention as is reasonably practical in the circumstances, so that the person would have the opportunity of applying to the court concerned for an order that the information not be disclosed to certain (or all) persons.

It is not appropriate to make decisions under sections 39, 40 and 41 administratively reviewable because these decisions are essentially of a commercial and policy nature. The same applies to decisions under Sections 42 and 45. Nevertheless, a number of the decisions which you mentioned adopt a formula under which a Minister is not to approve something unless he or she is satisfied that certain requirements are met. I propose to amend each of these sections so that the Minister is required to grant the approval concerned, unless he or she is satisfied that these requirements are not met. This will have the effect of making it easier for a person adversely affected to apply for judicial review of the relevant decision.
I agree to make decisions under Sections 48 and 49 reviewable, but cannot agree to this in respect of Sections 50, 52, 53 and 54, again because of the policy and commercial nature of these decisions.

In respect of Section 86, providing for administrative appeal may frustrate the operation of the section by virtue of the delay involved. However, it would be open to an employee to seek judicial review in the event of an abuse of the Authority's power under this Section.

I agree to make decisions under Section 96 administratively reviewable. It is not appropriate that decisions under Section 129 be administratively reviewable, again because of the time factor: a series of appeals against directions could totally frustrate the proper control of the Casino. However, I propose to amend the section to require that directions given be reasonable.
I agree to the Committee's suggestion about the word `owner'.
(l) Forms

Given the nature of this Ordinance I am prepared to make forms subject to tabling and disallowance. I propose that this be done by making forms `disallowable instruments' under the provisions of the Interpretation Ordinance 1967, but I am prepared to do this by regulation if the Committee believes this to be essential. My consent in this case is not to be taken as a general precedent that forms should be made as legislative instruments: it will depend on the circumstances in each case.
(m) Annual Report
I agree to provide for an Annual Report.
Yours sincerely
(Clyde Holding)
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
