talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 4 November, from Senator Newman:

interject.para: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to acknowledge:
(a) that the recent visit of warships from friendly nations to Australia for the Bicentennial was at the invitation of the Federal Government;
(b) that the Defence White Paper acknowledges the need for Australia to maintain a credible defence deterrent capability;
(c) that that deterrent includes the maintenance of our support for the Western alliance;
(d) that the instability in our region demonstrates the need for Australia to exercise sensitive leadership and to maintain our international reputation and influence in our region;
(e) that there is therefore an urgent need for the Government to take all action necessary to ensure that visiting warships of friendly nations can dock and be serviced unimpeded in Australian ports.
Yours sincerely,
JOCELYN NEWMAN,
Senator for Tasmania
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to acknowledge:
(a) that the recent visit of warships from friendly nations to Australia for the Bicentennial was at the invitation of the Federal Government;
(b) that the Defence White Paper acknowledges the need for Australia to maintain a credible defence deterrent capability;
(c) that that deterrent includes the maintenance of our support for the Western alliance;
(d) that the instability in our region demonstrates the need for Australia to exercise sensitive leadership and to maintain our international reputation and influence in our region;
(e) that there is therefore an urgent need for the Government to take all action necessary to ensure that visiting warships of friendly nations can dock and be serviced unimpeded in Australian ports.

The Opposition today raises a matter of great urgency which I believe has enormous consequences for the people of Australia both in the short term and in the long term. The recent disgraceful events involving visiting warships have already had serious repercussions with our allies. The Opposition is concerned that the long term implications for our standing in the region will also be left at risk if a clear commitment is not given speedily by the Australian Government to take all action necessary to ensure that visiting warships of friendly nations can dock and be serviced unimpeded in Australian ports.

I draw honourable senators' attention to the plight of the Ark Royal and her supply ship Fort Grange, denied tug assistance by the Seamen's Union of Australia and therefore unable to berth in the port to which they were invited by the Federal Government as bicentennial guests. Honourable senators will also be aware that the USS Ingersoll was unable to leave port for the same reason-union refusal to provide assistance. Perhaps less well known is the fact that this internationally embarrassing exhibition of union power followed the ships around the country to Adelaide and Perth. As a result, the Ark Royal decided not to berth in Port Adelaide and HMAS Edinburgh had to berth in Adelaide's outer harbour, rather than Port Adelaide proper, due to partial union bans. The only reason the bans were not total was that the Edinburgh carried Prince Andrew. Had it been prevented from berthing, there would have been no royal visit to Adelaide. And so on to Perth, where our national humiliation was made complete. There the Construction Mining and Energy Workers Union of Australia, in particular the port's crane drivers and operators, refused to service the Ark Royal; so gangways could not be swung into position to allow the ship's crew to come ashore. These ships were in the country at the invitation of the Federal Government.

talk.start.para: —They were our guests, weren't they?

—They were our guests, Senator. It was an invitation given on behalf of the Australian people. They were not here at their own request; it was an invitation to our birthday celebration. But a small group of people thumbed their noses at the Commonwealth Government and, by taking enormous power unto themselves, held the reputation and defence of Australia, along with the security of its citizens, to ransom.

speech.para: The episode is well known. Yet at a time when recent events such as the disputes on the Papua New Guinea-Indonesia border clearly demonstrate that we live in a volatile environment, at a time when such issues impact directly upon Australia, and at a time when the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is laudably trying to protect Australia's leadership and strength in our region, there is a compelling need to remind ourselves of these shameful events. The first and very serious result of these actions is that we have jeopardised Australia's standing as a member of the Western alliance. All the regrets and apologies in the world are not enough in this situation. Apologies and regrets cannot guarantee that the episode will not happen again and cannot restore our tarnished international reputation. Our reliability as an ally has been called into question and we need to act now so that Britain and America will be sure that the episode will not ever be repeated again. If we need to call on our friends in a time of emergency or, heaven forbid, in a time of war, we need them to see that we have taken the necessary legal steps to ensure that it cannot happen again. If we cannot convince our Western allies of our reliability or of our Government resolve, how can Australia hope to project a vital image of strength and stability for our immediate neighbours to look to and respect? Likewise, on the world stage, how can we hope to conduct diplomatic business in all seriousness when our international honour and credibility have been severely damaged?

All around us world trading blocs are being formed which may result in the isolation of Australia. Understandably, our trade and foreign Ministers are roving the world putting Australia's case to prevent this from happening. If they are to succeed, they must be able to argue from a position of strength. They must be able to speak on behalf of a Government which is demonstrably in control of its country and therefore capable of guaranteeing trade contracts. Sadly, this incident has to undermine their case.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised to speed up our acquisition of naval tugs. But extra tugs will not remedy the damage done, nor will they prevent a repeat performance. After all, there were tugs on hand at Perth, and they could do nothing about the crane operators. Access means nothing without the guaranteed availability and facilitation of supplies and service. That is the whole point of access. Tugs cannot guarantee supplies and service, which are still subject to the whims of unions. What we need is a strong commitment to see that these events can never be repeated and that we are prepared to fulfil our obligations. Foreign policy has to be decided upon, and implemented by governments-not only by individuals acting independently of government.

The friendly visits to Australia of foreign warships are an important part of our obligation to the Western alliance, and as such are vital to our national defence and security. This is particularly relevant when we consider our own limited naval capability in the context of the current political and military instability of our closer neighbours. Not having much time, I skate over the region. We have problems in Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, as I mentioned. We have had problems in Vanuatu, continuing problems in Fiji and difficulties with New Caledonia. This morning we heard about the conflict in the Maldives. We have an incomprehensible build-up in the Indian Ocean of the Indian navy. There has been trouble in the Straits of Lombok and Sunda, and continuing tensions in the Philippines over the renegotiation of the United States bases.

While recognising the steps taken by the Government to re-equip our Navy, we do not as yet have any great capacity to effectively protect our shipping lanes. In these circumstances, how much more important are the naval capabilities of our friends in extending our defence capability? Given that the defence White Paper records a strong belief in the importance to Australia's defence of the Western alliance-a belief which is shared by the Opposition-it is clear that this situation cannot be allowed to continue. We criticise New Zealand for its lack of support for ANZUS and its stance with Anzac ships, but we are also letting the side down. In today's editorial in the Australian it is said that there is no doubt that Australia has every reason to take a firm stance on the matter of our military relations with New Zealand. It is true that New Zealand does seem prepared to enjoy a free lunch under the United States nuclear umbrella, and it would seem half-hearted in its contribution to the Anzac arrangement. But we must take care that the United States does not react to our treatment of its ships with bluntness similar to our reaction to New Zealand. Those who criticise other people's free lunches should make sure they pay for their own tucker.

It is a Commonwealth and not a State responsibility to maintain Australia's defence and international arrangements. We need to see that the Federal Government is empowered to exercise that responsibility, and to prove to the world and to our allies in particular that Australia's defence arrangements are not subject to industrial negotiation or to groups of raucous individuals who seem to be able to exercise real power regardless of the wishes of a democratically elected government. I therefore urge the Government to support this motion and to urgently take steps to see that the visits of warships from friendly nations are not impeded. After all, the policy on alliances is a bipartisan policy. I would like to remind honourable senators of the defence White Paper 1987 released by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I would like to draw a number of quotes to the attention of honourable senators because they emphasise the importance of this bipartisan policy. The White Paper says.
The Government reaffirmed Australia's natural association with the Western Community of nations and our attendant defence interests and obligations.
The White Paper also says:
All of our defence relationships, formal and informal, impose responsibilities on Australia.
Defence co-operation will continue to be sustained with the United States in peacetime.

Consultations between the two countries facilitate extensive co-operative activities including military training and exercises, intelligence exchanges, defence science and technology, communications and logistics co-operation.
Clearly, the alliance is extremely important to this country. It extends our defence capability in no uncertain terms. The White Paper goes on to say:
The defence relationship with the United States gives confidence that in the event of a fundamental threat to Australia's security, US military support would be forthcoming.
That is a most vital statement, in my view. The White Paper goes on to refer to the five-power defence arrangement:
Under the five-power defence arrangement Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom cooperate to support the security of Singapore and Malaysia.

It is on the basis of all that that we have a bipartisan policy of being good allies and friends, an attitude which, sadly, we have not seen too much of in the latest visit of our friends. We believe that we also share a bipartisan view on the visits to Australia by foreign warships, although anyone could be forgiven for having believed otherwise in the past couple of months. We have to demonstrate our total and bipartisan national commitment to the Western alliance. One step which must be taken toward that end is to place the direct authority for future visits to Australia by foreign warships under the Minister for Defence. We need to ensure that tugs will always be available when needed, particularly in difficult weather conditions. We need to ensure that berthing will be unimpeded and that basic services such as power, telephone, waste disposal and resupply will all be available at the dockside. These are little enough, but they are basic to the good manners which are expected to be displayed by a host to an invited guest. We must make sure that any attempt to deny our guests these facilities in the future can be effectively dealt with and prevented.

Inevitably, this has to mean that such powers must be given by legislative authority. This is particularly so because any State or Territory laws to the contrary must be overcome if the Federal Government is to exercise its defence and foreign powers. Yet those powers, and our ability to execute our obligations, have been thrown into doubt by the events of last month. The Australian people and their Government are entitled to see that no-one is able to prevent a goodwill visit by friendly warships to our ports, particularly so when they are here at our invitation. Our international reputation, our standing in our region and the willingness of friends to come to our aid in difficult times, are all affected by the ability or otherwise of the elected government to ensure that such visits are not unimpeded.

I believe that it is only by strong and unambiguous legislation that the Government will convince the rest of the world, particularly our Western allies, that our arrangements for defence and foreign relations are run by our Government, and not by our unions, and that this episode will never happen again. This is an urgent and weighty matter of great long term importance to Australia. So I urge the support of all the Senate.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —There is a ritual quality to these exchanges in this place on defence matters-a timeless, deathless, musty, incense-ridden, ritual quality which, I must confess, I get quite nostalgic for when I miss out on them for a few weeks in a row, as I have, it seems, recently. Because these debates have that quality and because I can, I think, deal with the issues rather succinctly, I propose to do so and to let the Opposition get on with the task of tearing at the throats of the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine in the way that it wants to do in the glorious irrelevance that so often constitutes debates in this chamber. I say `the Opposition, the Democrats and Senator Vallentine' because the Government really has no particular quarrel-Senator Newman might be disappointed to know-with the text of the motion before us. We have a quibble or two about particular words, but we certainly do not think the topic justifies the urgency with which it is surrounded by this procedure. Nonetheless, we do not oppose the basic sentiments that it contains. I do not say that just because I have been conned by Senator Newman's opening and rather disarming reference to my recent laudable diplomatic forays. I will be much more polite than might otherwise have been the case, but I can assure Senator Newman that that does not mean that we would otherwise have any basic problems with the motion. Let me explain why by going through the terms of it. It states first of all:

speech.para: that the recent visit of warships from friendly nations to Australia for the Bicentennial was at the invitation of the Federal Government;

Indeed, it was. Moreover, it was a great success. Some 33 ships from 16 nations visited 24 different ports around Australia in what has been hailed, I think quite rightly, as a high point of our bicentennial celebration. Secondly, the motion goes on:
that the Defence White Paper acknowledges the need for Australia to maintain a credible defence deterrent capability;

Indeed, it does. Moreover, it needs to be acknowledged that this Government in the White Paper has put forward for the first time a comprehensive, coherent defence strategic analysis and defence policy for Australia, building on the principle of self-reliance and creating a consistent and constructively thought-through scenario for the way in which that self-reliance policy can be budgeted for and put in place over the years ahead. All of that is in quite spectacular contrast, it has to be said, with the Opposition's approach to defence policy. I am indebted to Senator Newman for acknowledging the Defence White Paper in the terms that she has because it rather suggests, as is the case, that the Opposition has no credible alternative defence policy of its own and is quite content to rest with the Government's.

talk.start.para: —It does no such thing.

—If there is no veracity to the assertion I have just made, let us wait and see what the Opposition produces by way of a defence policy. It is now over a year since the last election and still it has not articulated its policy. I do not know whether it will do a retread as it did with Mr Beale's education policy, which was the product of the photocopier, as Mr Dawkins made so clear yesterday in the other place, or whether it does have something new to say. Whatever the case may be, we have not seen it. We are told that it has been to the shadow Cabinet but we have not heard anything more about it. It apparently having been knocked back by the shadow Cabinet-which is the only assumption one can make after tailing its history so far-it seems that the Opposition's policy and its spokesmen are in a condition of some confusion. We await with fascination the next episode in that respect.

speech.para: Senator Newman goes on to say in her motion that a credible defence deterrent capability should include the maintenance of our support for the Western alliance. Of course, we agree. I make the point that our policy includes, also for the first time, a very rigorous analysis of the essential role of the United States alliance in our defence policy. That commitment to the United States alliance is not, however, born solely of purely in-house considerations-concerns for Australia's immediate physical security; our commitment to the Western alliance is part of our commitment to larger global security issues, not only in the context of the maintenance of an effective nuclear deterrence strategy but also because alliances of the kind in which we participate with the United States are an important element in the stabilisation of the whole global order. For all those separate and interrelated reasons, we agree with that proposition. The motion goes on to say:
that the instability in our region demonstrates the need for Australia to exercise sensitive leadership and to maintain our international reputation and influence in our region;

I think it overstates the situation a little to talk in terms of the instability of the region. Obviously, events have occurred in the South Pacific over the last year and a half which have given cause for concern, at least so far as the domestic situation of a couple of countries is concerned. Nonetheless, there is no evidence of any wider regional implications and I think it is possible to exaggerate again some of the things, for example, the recent border controversies between Papua New Guinea and Indonesia. All of those things have to be seen in their context. But it is, of course, the case that the Government needs to continue to maintain and, as far as is possible, enhance our defence relationships and our strategic role throughout the region, bearing in mind that our defence policy does cover and define an area of broader strategic interests than Australia's own shores, an area which encompasses the whole of South East Asia and the South Pacific, indeed a quarter of the earth's surface.

What we have done, faced with that reality, is set about consolidating and enhancing our defence relationships with the countries of the region through the five-power defence arrangement, which is the subject of a good deal of renewed interest by the other regional members, Malaysia and Singapore in particular, with a view to possibly further developing that arrangement. We have consolidated and advanced our position through the joint declaration of principles with Papua New Guinea signed in December 1987, which was the subject of an extremely successful two-day ministerial forum, focused on a whole variety of defence and regional issues, which was held over the last two days in Papua New Guinea.

talk.start.para: —Nevertheless, the border incidents are very relevant, because we have our treaty.

—Of course the border incidents are relevant, and they are made no less relevant by the terms of article 21 of the treaty, which recognises the nature of Australia's potential involvement in the region, and of course it is necessary, as a result, to develop and consolidate those arrangements. We are in furious agreement, Senator Newman, about this matter, so let us get as unexcited as we possibly can-and as I am-about this debate.

speech.para: The other point that is worth making in terms of regional defence relationships is the extremely interesting statements that have been made recently by General Murdani, the Indonesian Defence Minister, during my visit there and in particular publicly in the context of his speech to the Australian-Indonesian Business Cooperation Council in Bali last week, where he foreshadowed an interest in a renewed kind of defence cooperation with Australia, on essentially a basis of equality and mutual participation in ways which remain to be defined but which nonetheless recognise the reality that both countries are major, significant players in the region and need to operate in an environment of constructive cooperation, and not the converse. So all of that is true and none of that causes any particular difficulty except, as I say, I would not wish to overemphasise the instability. I think it is possible to overstate that. What is important is that we act constructively, in the way we have been, to minimise the potential of any such developments as do occur to create problems for the region and ourselves in particular.

The question of our reputation, which is also part of the paragraph, I think justifiably deserves some reference. I do not think our reputation could stand any higher than it does around the South Pacific in defence terms with the constructive nature of the relationship we have been developing, the Pacific patrol boat program, I suppose, being the most obvious recent manifestation of that. Our relationship with South East Asia is, I think, reflected by what I have just said about the renewed interest in Australian participation and upgrading that is involved with the five-power defence arrangement by the reaction of Indonesia in the way I have just described. Our reputation with the United States could scarcely stand higher, as has been amply demonstrated by some things that have recently been put on record. Admiral Hayes, the now retired Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific forces, on 17 May at the National Press Club in Canberra said:

Security co-operation between Australia and the US could hardly be better, and this is no accident. It's the result of shared values and dedicated efforts of outstanding individuals such as, on the American side, Ambassador Bill Lane and, on the Australian side, Prime Minister Bob Hawke and his team.

talk.start.para: —Didn't he mention you?
—Not yet. This was back in May. Give him time to catch up. Admiral Crowe, the United States Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, on 11 October 1988 in Canberra said--
—Those are testimonials?

—Well, they are important testimonials. If the honourable senator raises the question, as she does in her motion, of Australia's reputation and standing and expresses the sorts of doubts that she does in her chirruping budgerigar, grumpy, shrill fashion, I am justified to put a few encomia into the record as well. There has not been any negative reaction to what has happened and I will come to that in a moment. Certainly not a word was uttered to me on the subject of Australian treatment of warships in my little recent odyssey around South East Asia. I am not aware of any problems that have arisen with any of our other allies either. The atmosphere is as I described it and as Admiral Crowe put it on 11 October, when he said this:

speech.para: The United States and Australia have enjoyed one of the world's exceptional friendships. Our military to military relationship is also exemplary . . . Your American friends admire the Australian effort to maintain strong national defences and we greatly appreciate your contributions to global deterrence and world peace.

Senator MacGibbon can wince-it is true, it is florid, it is intense and it is emotional but it represents the reality of our relationship. This is something that the honourable senator has been most unhappy to acknowledge during his time of--

talk.start.para: —The Americans are now acutely embarrassed by the actions of the Government at the highest defence level.
—Well, that is not the impression that we are getting. Admiral Crowe says:

speech.para: We have the highest confidence that our countries can continue to work together to our mutual benefit.
So the basics of our relationships around the region with our Western alliance partners are impeccably well intact.
Let us get to the final part of the motion which reads:
. . . there is therefore an urgent need-
we do not think it is urgent but we do acknowledge a need-
for the Government to take all action necessary to ensure that visiting warships of friendly nations can dock and be serviced unimpeded in Australian ports.

The reality of the situation is that the vast majority of port visits that did occur last month went ahead without disruption. I have described them-33 ships, 16 nations and 24 different ports. Wherever possible, when industrial action did deny a particular service to a visiting ship, the Navy provided the service instead. The only visit which was actually disrupted in any significant way by industrial action was the visit of the Ark Royal to Melbourne. Because of bad weather the ship could not berth without tugs and no naval tugs were available in Melbourne, which is not a base, and has not been hitherto, for Royal Australian Navy warships. The Government, as I made clear at the time, and as I certainly repeat now, does deeply regret the union action and the demonstrations, for that matter, that accompanied it which at times went well beyond the exercise of the right to express one's views-a right, of course, that we acknowledge.

We unequivocally support visits to our ports by allied warships and we accept the policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons aboard such ships. I make that point because of the reported comments yesterday of the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, suggesting that the visit could have gone ahead if the United Kingdom had confirmed that nuclear weapons were not aboard the Ark Royal. I make the point for the record-it is hardly a new one-that we, of course, continue to support a `neither confirm nor deny' policy as the only credible way of responding on this issue.

The disruption that did occur-major in the case of the Ark Royal and minor only elsewhere-is, for the reasons that I have indicated, anathema to the Government. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has made that clear publicly and I repeat it now. We have decided to take steps to ensure that in the future the Navy itself is able to berth its own and visiting warships anywhere in Australia. We have decided specifically, as has been announced, to bring forward the purchase of naval tugs which had been planned for the proposed fleet base at Jervis Bay and to purchase a tug as a trial and recovery ship for the submarine project in South Australia. We believe that that and other measures that may prove appropriate and necessary will be the solution.

talk.start.para: —Will you adopt my private member's Bill?
—No, I have to disappoint the honourable senator in that respect.
—What legislative base are you going to have?

—Let me explain. We believe that the kind of approach I have suggested of making available the necessary logistic support for these kinds of operations and not having to depend on non-government support, rather than legislation, is the effective way of preventing a recur- rence of the problem. We believe that that approach, rather than legislation, is the effective way of preventing a recurrence of the problem.
—Why?

—The reason, as Senator Newman ought to appreciate, is that legislation designed to compel workers to berth ships would be a recipe for confrontation. While it might be a cause of satisfaction for the macho instincts-or whatever the female equivalent of that is-of those opposite, it would be highly unlikely, in practice, to resolve the problem. What we are about is resolving problems. The course that we have decided upon is, by contrast, a practical and effective response. The threatened trouble in Adelaide, for example, was not averted by bullying. It would not have been averted by legislative bullying of the kind the Opposition proposes. It was averted by a reasoned approach by the Government to the union. That is the way we will proceed. We will respond in a sensible, measured, reasonable and responsive way to resolve these problems as they arise. With the utmost respect, we do not need an urgency motion from the Opposition, let alone one moved by Senator Newman, to make us conscious of our responsibilities in this respect. For all those reasons, and with the odd cause for minor contretemps along the way, but not seriously, I indicate that the Government does not oppose the motion which has been moved.

speech.speaker: McLean Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —This is a valuable urgency motion. It allows an airing in our cherished democracy of differing sincerely held points of view concerning the issue of nuclear warships in our harbours. It also provides an opportunity to destroy some of the fabrications and deliberate distortions surrounding the actions of those who courageously oppose nuclear-armed and powered warships in our ports. That having been said, we will oppose the urgency motion.

speech.para: I respect and note Senator Newman's commitment to the cause of nuclear armaments, a commitment carried forward into a private member's Bill. I note also that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills cited at least one clause in that private member's Bill which impinges unduly upon individual rights-in fact, precisely those rights that were being exercised by those who were criticised in the urgency motion.

Senator Newman, and I assume therefore the remainder of the Opposition speakers, see this issue in terms of disruption of a bicentennial celebration-the spoiling of a party. That is rubbish. This issue is about life and death. It is about the potential for nuclear war. Totally and utterly it is about the survival of human kind. It is in those terms that the Australian Democrats address this urgency motion.

Senator Newman cited the embarrassment and inconvenience resulting to some warships from the lack of servicing available to them. What a pathetic argument that was. We are talking about the most sophisticated naval warships on earth. Hopefully they can survive more than this transient embarrassment of a temporary lack of servicing in one port which they were visiting as part of a so-called celebration.

The Australian Democrats are categorically not against defence. We are not opposed to navies, service personnel, sailors, visiting warships or anything of the kind. On the contrary, it will have been apparent from the contributions that I and other Democrats have made to debates in recent times that our opinion is directly the opposite. We believe in a viable defence force; we believe in potent and viable navies. However-it is important that this be equally clear-we are anti nuclear weapons. Therefore, we are anti nuclear warships and anti any action which encourages their development or deployment, including their presence in our harbours, albeit to attend a bicentennial naval review.

I will briefly address the specific parts of the urgency motion. My interest in this issue will be apparent from the fact that on 27 September, during the period of these visits, I asked a question of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I draw the Senate's attention to that question and to the reply which focused on the question of contingency plans in relation to visiting warships. I was alarmed, as I would imagine most Australians were alarmed, to find that there were no contingency plans relating to possible actions concerning visiting nuclear warships. It is for that reason that those brave people took those actions in Melbourne when they did. It is for that reason that they expressed the opinion of 66 per cent of Australians that they did not want those visiting nuclear warships-I emphasise, visiting nuclear-powered or armed warships-in our harbours. The majority of Australians do not want them in our harbours. We praise and applaud the action of those people who opposed their entry and opposed their servicing in our harbours.

Of course, a number of obvious, soft platitudes could be uttered in relation to this motherhood urgency motion. I will not address the first few points because it is obvious that we need adequate leadership in our region; it is obvious that we need adequate defence; it is obvious that we need an adequate, well structured and potent navy. It is obvious that our Government should provide these things. I turn my attention, however, to the last part of the urgency motion which is what it is all about: the offensive, unnecessary and potentially dangerous visitation of nuclear armed and nuclear powered warships. I draw the attention of honourable senators to Senator Robert Ray's answer to my question of 27 September which centred on the question of contingency plans for nuclear accidents. The Minister, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, said:
An accidental nuclear detonation is essentially impossible. Secondly, the chance of any kind of accident involving a nuclear weapon is virtually nil.
I will cite some of the nuclear accidents that have occurred around the globe in recent times. They will show the absolute irresponsibility of that reply on behalf of the Minister for Defence.

talk.start.para: —Start with Chernobyl.
—I do not intend to start with Chernobyl. I will confine my remarks to accidents that have occurred on nuclear powered and nuclear armed vessels.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Would you instruct the honourable senator that, when speaking in this debate, he cannot point fingers or argue directly with another senator in the chamber and that he must address his remarks through the Chair. It is an elementary matter of courtesy and a matter contained in the Standing Orders. If he does not know the Standing Orders, he should leave the chamber and read them.
—Senator MacGibbon, as always, I will watch the gesticulations of speakers with interest and bear your comments in mind.

—What an extraordinary intervention! I will cite some of the nuclear accidents that have occurred in relation to nuclear powered and nuclear armed ships of the type that entered our ports. In April 1963 the nuclear reactor on the USS Thresher shut down while the submarine was on sea trials off the New England coast. The submarine plunged to the sea floor, imploding and killing all 129 hands on board. The reactor's remains lie on the ocean bottom. In January 1966 an airborne collision occurred above Palomanes in Spain between a United States KC135 refuelling tanker and a B52 bomber loaded with four hydrogen bombs. Three bombs scattered radioactive material on sea and land.

speech.para: In 1967 there was a core meltdown resulting in a major radiation leak aboard the Soviet icebreaker Lenin. This accident is believed to have killed 30 people and rendered the ship too radioactive to be used for over three years. In May 1968 the nuclear-powered attack submarine USS Scorpion mysteriously sank in the Atlantic Ocean with all hands aboard. In 1970-71 a Soviet November class nuclear-powered submarine reportedly sank in the Atlantic Ocean. In the spring of 1982 during the Falklands war four British ships-the Sheffield, Britannia, Ardent and Coventry-which were reported to have carried anti-submarine nuclear depth bombs, sank. In the summer of 1983, a Soviet nuclear-powered submarine sank in the North Pacific, and 90 crew members were killed. In October 1986 there was an explosion aboard a Soviet Yankee class nuclear- powered submarine in the Atlantic. The submarine sank with 10 nuclear missile warheads and a nuclear reactor. I would like to develop on that last accident further. The notes I have on the accident state:

On 3 October 1986, an explosion ripped through an SS-N-6 submarine-launched ballistic missile aboard the Soviet `Yankee' class submarine, while it was in the Atlantic Ocean approximately 2,000 kilometres southeast of New York. At least three Soviet crewmen died from the blast. Three days later, seawater flooded the damaged hull while it was under tow and the submarine sank to the bottom of the Atlantic.

A single one megaton nuclear warhead-or possibly two one hundred kiloton warheads-were probably ejected from the missile tube by the force of the explosion. At least 15 more nuclear weapons went down with the submarine, each containing several kilograms of plutonium.

A complete nuclear reactor, with a radioactivity inventory of around one billion curies (twenty times greater than the amount released at Chernobyl) also went down. The impact of the hull striking the ocean floor-at an estimated velocity of 200 kilometres per hour-combined with the deep ocean pressure and the force of the original explosion, almost certainly damaged both the reactor's containment structure and the missile warheads.

This incident is only one of scores, possibly hundreds of environmental disasters caused by the five nuclear navies. Because the navies evade public scrutiny, little or nothing is known about most of these calamities.

Yet the Minister sits here and tells us that it is not necessary to have a contingency plan because nuclear accidents do not occur. He says that they are virtually impossible, yet I have just cited 15 such calamities since 1977.

talk.start.para: —Almost none of which had to do with nuclear reactors.
—Does Senator Stone regard that as being of no consequence? It is of monumental consequence.
—You are not making your case.

—Now Senator Stone says I am not making my case about the safety, or the potential non-safety, of visiting nuclear ships. I cannot believe my ears. I cannot believe that such a comment can come from a person who purports to make intelligent, constructive comment in this chamber day after day.

speech.para: Of course, the potential for nuclear disaster has not gone unnoticed by the authorities of at least some of the world's leading cities. I have a detailed report of the special consultants which was handed to the authorities in New York. They decided that it was utterly unthinkable to consider the entry of such nuclear-powered ships into their harbour-the harbour of a city which has a population only a little less than that of the whole of Australia. One paragraph from the consultant's report states:

Past nuclear weapon accidents have caused the dispersal of plutonium into the environment, and numerous government agencies have acknowledged that such an accident could happen again. The Navy has reported an average of 32.6 nuclear weapon accidents and incidents per year between 1965 and 1985, including 66 that occurred in port. According to Navy figures, it had 638 nuclear weapon incidents and two accidents between 1965 and 1985. At least 140 of these involved nuclear weapons-including ASROC and Terrier missiles-on board ships similar to those that will be based at Staten Island.

That is, if the base at Staten Island is permitted. Yet Senator Stone sits here and says that I have not cited anything that is relevant to the carriage of nuclear weapons into ports. I find that extraordinary.

talk.start.para: —That is right.

—Senator Stone actually confirms, right now, that he is prepared to accept that that was his proposition. I find it difficult to differentiate between the degree of irresponsibility in the answer I got from the Minister on 27 September, when he said that there was no contingency plan, that there was no likelihood of accidents-in light of which I have just presented evidence to the Senate-and in fact that it was unnecessary therefore to have a contingency plan, and the level of irresponsibility contained in this urgency motion today. The motion says that it is inappropriate for courageous Australians in a democracy, in an age of potential nuclear war, to deny the access of such vessels into Australian ports. I admire their courage. I am alarmed by what I hear from the responsible Ministers in this chamber. I am alarmed by the fact that Senator Newman did not have enough perception and penetration of insight or enough information available to realise that this motion is utter irresponsible rubbish.

speech.speaker: Stone Sen J.O.

talker.name: Senator STONE
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —Today we are addressing the urgency motion put forward by Senator Jocelyn Newman, our shadow Minister for defence science and personnel. This motion springs out of the shameful occurrences in the port of Melbourne at the time of the recent bicentennial visit by ships of the Royal Navy, the United States Navy and the French Navy. The facts have already been clearly stated and there is no point in repeating them. The truth is that the facts are very well known because they are so shameful. They are shameful to the people of Victoria in particular and to the Australian people generally.

speech.para: There is an additional reason for that sense of shame to be so deeply ingrained in the consciousness of the Australian people, particularly the Victorian people, at this time, and that is the visit to this country not so very many months ago by the Prime Minister of Britain, Mrs Thatcher. During a street walk in Bourke Street, Melbourne, she was harassed and set upon by a band of thugs and hooligans who were also expressing-and from precisely the same point of the political spectrum-their views about what freedom in this country constitutes.

If I might digress for a moment on that topic, you may remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, that at that time I contributed an article to a London newspaper, the Daily Mail, in which I expressed my sense of personal shame over that incident. I expressed that shame lest the people of Britain should think that the actions of that mob were in any way representative of the attitudes and views of the decent majority of Australians. I expressed my personal shame at the appalling lack of security provided to the Prime Minister of Britain by the then and still Premier and Government of Victoria. I expressed my shame at the abject conduct of our own Commonwealth Government, including our own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In particular, I expressed my sense of shame at the fact that not even an apology was subsequently tendered to the Prime Minister of Britain for those actions whilst in our country on a bicentennial visit.

talk.start.para: —Absolutely disgraceful.

—Yes, it is absolutely disgraceful. There was not even an apology. Not even the grace of a simple courtesy was extended at the time either by the Premier of Victoria or by the Prime Minister of the Commonwealth of Australia. I conclude that slight digression by saying that what we have recently witnessed in the port of Melbourne carried the same hallmarks, and it carried them for the same reasons.

speech.para: I want to use the remaining minutes available to me to address the key elements of this matter. It is necessary today to place the Ark Royal incident-I will use the Ark Royal incident as shorthand for the similar treatment of our friends from the United States and the French Navy-in the context of the wider strategic interests of the Soviet Union. In a book published by Sidgwick and Jackson entitled We Will Bury You-a phrase originally uttered by Mr Nikita Khrushchev-a Mr Jan Sejna had some interesting comments to make on that matter. Mr Sejna was for many years the Secretary to the Military Committee of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, and held the position of Chief Political Officer in the Czech Ministry of Defence until he defected from Czechoslovakia in 1968 after the Russian tanks had snuffed out the brief experiment with liberty under Mr Dubcek in that country. Mr Sejna quoted Mr Boris Ponomarev, who ran the Soviet Politburo's International Committee for 30 years. Mr Ponomarev said:
You must understand that if we wish to control Asia, we must first control Australia.

The Soviet activity in our region at present must be analysed in this light. It is particularly important to note that the Ark Royal incident is not an isolated event. In 1983 the communist-influenced Amalgamated Metal Workers Union refused to allow the Royal Navy aircraft carrier Invincible to go into dry dock in Sydney to undergo repairs. That ship was forced to go to Singapore to undergo those repairs. It is worth noting that the Victorian Secretary of the Seamen's Union of Australia which, of course, was the union responsible for applying the recent ban on the Ark Royal, has held the position of Vice-President of the Australia-USSR Friendship Society. It was Mr Dolman, the man in question, who moved the relevant motion at the meeting of the Victorian Trades Hall Council to the effect that these actions should be taken against the visiting warships. He did so in the name of the Anti-Nuclear Warships Committee.

It is worth noting, having in mind Mr Dolman's connection with the Australia-USSR Friendship Society, that the nature of the relations between that society and the Soviet Embassy in Canberra was spelt out by Mr David Combe during the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. The report of that Royal Commission said, in recognition of the evidence tendered on that matter at that time, that, the Australia-USSR Friendship Society has close links with the Soviet Embassy in Canberra. The significance that the Soviet Union places on Australia-I say this despite all the material we are being deluged with at the moment about perestroika and glasnost and matters of that kind; all of which I welcome, so far as they go-is evidenced by the stationing in Australia of Mr Valery Zemskov. Mr Zemskov has been recently exposed by Mr John Barron, writing in the current issue of the Readers' Digest, as a member of Directorate R of the Soviet Union. Directorate R was apparently formed after the mass expulsion of a very large number of senior KGB and GRU officers-139 of them in fact-from the United Kingdom in 1971. That body, which operates under the cloak of being a body primarily concerning itself with trade matters, is under the direct control of General Pitovranov, who doubles in the capacity of Deputy Chairman of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce. Mr Zemskov's appointment in Australia was opposed at the time by senior officials in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). Their opposition to his acceptance by our Department of Foreign Affairs was overriden by that Department, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, as it is now called. Nevertheless, Mr Zemskov's membership of Directorate R is known to our ASIO and, in the light of some denials emanating from the Soviet embassy, it is entirely possible that, until at least the expose of the last few weeks, even the KGB resident in Canberra may not have been aware of Mr Zemskov's role, because indeed the role of Directorate R has been so highly secretive, even within the Soviet Union itself, that the KGB would not necessarily have been aware of the existence of this body.

It is interesting to note, in the half a minute remaining to me, that Mr Zemskov in January 1987, last year, actually distinguished himself by denying the existence at that time of the Soviet naval base at Cam Ranh Bay. This is a man who, in his role as a diplomat, promotes within the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade the virtue of what I suppose would be called New Zealand's defence policy, that policy which is so eloquently expounded in this chamber by our senatorial colleagues in the Australian Democrats and by representatives of the Nuclear Disarmament Party, including Senator Vallentine, who is about to follow me in this debate.

I conclude by saying that I welcome the Government's acceptance of, or non-opposition to, the terms of this motion. I can only trust that, when another episode of this kind occurs, the Government will indeed live up to the view expressed in the final paragraph of Senator Newman's motion, which calls upon the Government to accept the need to take all action necessary to ensure that visiting warships of friendly nations can dock and be serviced unimpeded in Australian ports.

speech.speaker: Vallentine Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank Senator Newman for this very interesting opportunity to discuss the visits of nuclear-armed, nuclear-powered warships to Australia, although I note in the wording of her urgency motion the amazing omission of the word `nuclear'. I wonder whether it has not occurred to the Opposition that it is the fact that these ships are nuclear-armed that people in Australia are objecting to. Has the Opposition not twigged to the fact that that is what over 50 per cent of Australians are now opposing? The entry of nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships into Australian ports is increasingly unpopular internationally. This is part of an international campaign. In western Europe, in Spain and in Denmark there are clear indications of a great deal of antinuclear sentiment as far as warship visits are concerned. Some of the organisations that are involved in this international opposition are: the North Atlantic Network, the Campaign to De- Nuclearise the Irish Sea; the Greenpeace International Campaign to Disarm the Seas; the Pacific Campaign to Disarm the Seas. We have to look at the fact that the Soviet nuclear navy in the Baltic has also been protested against by Greenpeace, the international organisation. It held up the docking and barred the way of a Soviet vessel bearing nuclear weapons earlier this year. In the Pacific, closer to home, it is not only New Zealand that has an anti-nuclear position but also Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands. There are ongoing campaigns in the Philippines against the presence of nuclear weapons, and in Japan, in Australia and, of course, Belau which is a tiny nation of only 15,000 people who have a genuinely nuclear-free constitution.

speech.para: There is also a campaign for the demilitarisation of the Indian Ocean. In the United States itself there are campaigns against the home porting of nuclear naval vessels, in New York and San Francisco in particular. Senator McLean referred to the New York opposition and it is indeed a very vocal opposition of people in that large city and it is the same in San Francisco where people do not want nuclear weapons coming into their ports.

The only point of Senator Newman's motion that I can actually agree with is point (a). They were warships of friendly nations which were invited to participate in our bicentennial naval review. That is true. They were all friendly nations and they were invited by our Government. That is about where the point of agreement would have to end. The Government was very unwise to invite nuclear vessels into our ports during this bicentenary. I want to quote from an article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph of December last year. It reads:
Seven senators yesterday presented Parliament with petitions signed by more than 10,000 people-
that is quite a large petition to be presented here-

calling on the Federal Government for a nuclear-free bicentenary. Peace Squadron spokeswoman Michelle Grosvenor said the petition particularly asked the Government to cancel all invitations to the Bicentennial Naval Review for nuclear capable ships.

The honourable senators who presented this combined and very large petition were: Senators Bruce Childs, Paul McLean and Robert Wood from New South Wales; Bryant Burns from Queensland; Jo Vallentine and Jean Jenkins from Western Australia; and Norm Sanders from Tasmania. There were seven senators from various parties presenting this petition. That was a very clear signal to the Government that we did not want nuclear warships invited into our harbours for our bicentenary. We gave the Government fair warning a year earlier than that during the seventy-fifth birthday celebrations of the Royal Australian Navy when we congratulated the Royal Australian Navy on 75 years of nuclear-free service to the nation and we said then, `But we disapprove--

interject.speaker: Senator Tambling

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 421, which reads:

interject.para: The President or the Chairman of Committees may call the attention of the Senate or the Committee, as the case may be, to continued irrelevance or tedious repetition, and may direct a Senator to discontinue his speech . . .

I submit that the matter being put before us by Senator Vallentine is in fact continued irrelevance certainly and tedious repetition of all of the speeches that she has made continuously in this place for some time. I would ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to rule in accordance with standing order 421.

talk.start.para: —I do not so rule. I might suggest that if the Chair did so rule in many other cases this place would be a much more silent place than it is.

—Neither the Government nor the Opposition should have been surprised at the protest which has already been alluded to by various speakers. If there was any embarrassment caused during the bicentennial visits, it should be laid firmly at the door of the Government and particularly at the door of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) who has been better labelled `Minister for Nuclear Risks'. He is putting the country and the people of Australia at risk by inviting nuclear weapons into our ports. We do not like that and we have a right to say no. There are no safety plans dealing with nuclear weapon accident possibilities. Yet, Kim Beazley plays God and says that a nuclear weapon accident will not happen. I quote from the television program, the 7.30 Report, on 26 September 1988. Elizabeth Jackson asked:

speech.para: But accidents do happen?
Kim Beazley said:
No, they don't. Accidents do not happen on board these ships that come into Australian harbours.
Later on in the interview he stated:
There will be no accidents, none, no accidents, that involve a discharge of nuclear weapons or a problem with the reactors.

How dare Kim Beazley play God-a very dangerous game, I would suggest, for any human being to play. It has been a very embarrassing time for the Minister for nuclear risks indeed. First of all, the USS Berkeley collided with the Coralita, a pleasure craft, in a Queensland port. Who will pay the damages for the problems that ensued? The Berkeley was not being interfered with by protesters on this occasion, it rammed into a pleasure craft which was due to take people out to look at one of Australia's great treasures, the Great Barrier Reef. There is still no decision about who will pay for that; yet our Minister has said that accidents will not happen in Australian ports. Admittedly, there was no emanation of radiation on that occasion, but the point still remains that ships do collide, they do have accidents in ports and out of port. Has the Minister forgotten the Voyager and Melbourne disasters in this country concerning our own Navy? We still have not found out who paid for the damage that the USS New Jersey caused when it rammed the Brisbane wharf a couple of years ago. So there have been accidents in our ports with warships bearing nuclear weapons.

The second great embarrassment for Mr Beazley during the bicentennial naval review was that the HMS Edinburgh required repairs and had to limp back into Sydney. Fortunately, it did not require dry docking. But this reminds us very much of the 1983-84 debacle over HMS Invincible, also a United Kingdom ship. These ships do seem to get into a bit of mechanical difficulty. In that instance I am very grateful indeed for the very good work that was done by Brian Toohey when he uncovered in the Hayden papers, and reported in his magazine, The Eye, of September 1988, the outrageous situation that occurred when an earlier request was made for dry docking of the Invincible in an Australian port because it required repairs and it was nuclear-armed. I would like to table this document, the Hayden papers, from that magazine because it is too long for me to go into now but it very clearly shows that George Shultz wrote a press release for the Australian Government. It was used almost word for word. It was a very embarrassing incident indeed which could have been repeated on this visit had the Edinburgh not been patched up by underwater technicians so that it did not require dry docking. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —I will not worry about that, I will have another opportunity to read it in full. The third embarrassment that was caused to the Minister was that unions in four ports refused service to warships bearing nuclear weapons, culminating in the embarrassment of HMS Ark Royal having to limp away from Melbourne. This was followed by Mr Beazley's very embarrassing offer of reunion flights for the families who were disappointed not to be able to catch up with their loved ones in Melbourne. He promised to fly them to Perth for their reunion. My question in this place is still unanswered: how many people were involved, and how much money did that cost? How was it decided who was eligible or not for such reunion flights? It would have been very embarrassing indeed had the one sailor had three or four women requesting reunion flights with him. It could have created all sorts of problems. Yet Mr Beazley made that grandiose offer on behalf of Australians to cover his embarrassment. That was his own problem; he should have copped that full embarrassment.

speech.para: The Ark Royal has had a dreadful time indeed. It was kept out of Malta as well. It was kept out, incidentally, by the Labour Party which is in opposition in Malta and which orchestrated the demonstration against a nuclear weapons bearing ship in that port. It was kept out there for four days. Sailors on the Ark Royal must be thinking that there is something wrong with them; indeed, there is-it is called nuclear weapons on board, which Senator Newman's motion did not even refer to.

I want to concentrate on the `neither confirm nor deny' policy which is political, not strategic. It is very important to note what was said in 1974 by the former United States Assistant Secretary of Defense Morton Halperin of the `neither confirm nor deny' policy which we have had espoused here this afternoon by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). He said that the policy:

. . . is aimed at the public of allied countries. Many governments are prepared to let the United States have the ships with nuclear weapons call at their ports provided the people don't find out about it.
The same former United States Assistant Secretary of Defense, in testimony to the United States Joint Committee on Atomic Energy in 1975, said this of the `neither confirm nor deny' policy:

In part, this (policy) is at the request of nations where the weapons are deployed, since in most nations the existence of U.S. nuclear weapons within their borders is a difficult internal political issue. Thus they generally have requested that the United States not declassify the fact that nuclear weapons are located in their specific nation-even though the evidence that they are there is obvious and generally known by their population.
This is a quote from United States Rear Admiral Eugene LaRoque in 1974 when he was still operational in the United States Navy:

My experience has been that any ship that is capable of carrying nuclear weapons carries nuclear weapons. They do not off-load them when they go into foreign ports such as Japan or other countries. If they are capable of carrying them, they normally keep them aboard ship at all times except when the ship is in for overhaul or in for major repair.

That is common knowledge. Anybody can go to a public library and get a copy of Jane's Fighting Ships to get very good information as to whether ships have nuclear weapons on board. I remind the Senate that this is what the Opposition is about. In the ridiculous motion put up by Senator Newman she does not even mention that fact. She also has a `neither confirm nor deny' policy-not even an acknowledgment policy. Jane's Fighting Ships is in the research section of the Parliamentary Library, so I could not bring it down; but I assure honourable senators that it is a very heavy document. I have a copy of it in my office in Perth. There is a shorthand version for those who need to carry with them a ready reckoner. It is called Nuclear Warships and Naval Nuclear Weapons: a Complete Inventory. It is a Neptune paper put out by Greenpeace International. On that basis I am prepared to list the nuclear weaponry on board seven ships recently in Australia ports. Intercept Foundation Ltd, a research foundation in Sydney, put out a very good inventory of the seven ships which bore nuclear weapons: HMS Ark Royal, HMS Edinburgh, HMS Fort Grange, USS New Jersey, USS Ingersoll, USS Berkeley and USS Brewton. All those ships carry nuclear weapons.

The technical means of verifying the presence of nuclear weapons is also available. We do not have to rely on book documentation. In 1981 Sweden detected nuclear weapons on board a Soviet whiskey class submarine which ran aground in Swedish waters. The Swedes used the gamma ray spectroscopic technique to do this. Operational nuclear weapon detectors are probably in use by all nuclear weapon states, and many non-nuclear weapon states too.

In 1985, Mr Robert Tickner, MHR, asked a question in the House of Representatives about whether it was possible to detect nuclear weapons on warships. Mr Beazley's reply was very interesting. It was along the `neither confirm nor deny' line, but it also suggested very strongly that in fact that capability is available to Australia. Mr Tickner, after the response he received to the question to Mr Beazley, said that he was certain that detectors were being used. He said that the existence of such devices showed that the United States was using a strategic myth to bully New Zealand. This was in 1985, soon after the warships ban had been imposed.

It is a political problem; it is not a strategic problem. Everybody knows which ships have nuclear weapons. It is ridiculous for nuclear navies-allied or not-to hide behind this `neither confirm nor deny' policy. Mr Gorbachev said very clearly at his final press conference in Washington after he signed the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement last year that the Soviet Union has that technical capability. So do the Americans. In light of this information, the New Zealanders have been treated absolutely disgracefully.

I assure Senator Newman and Opposition senators that the opposition to nuclear- armed and nuclear-powered warships in Australia will continue until government policy changes. We are absolutely clear on that. This is happening not only in Australia but also internationally. When discussing the defence of Australia, it is important to realise that nuclear weapons and nuclear reactors coming into our ports add to our risk. They do not add to our defence.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: -I rise to support Senator Newman's motion. I will deal briefly with the previous speakers. Senator Evans, opening for the Government, showed his great interest in this by ridiculing it and talking about the glorious irrelevance of the debates of this nation. On a more serious note, he showed a fundamental misunderstanding as to what is going on in the South Pacific, our near neighbourhood. I know that Senator Evans is new to the post of foreign affairs and knows nothing about it, but I would have thought that he had been given some advice. Maybe he could not accept it. Saying that the regional instability had to be seen in perspective shows his lack of understanding. It is not the degree of instability which is the problem. The significance of the regional instability lies in the fact that what was formerly a very placid, very stable and, above all, very predictable region is now quite unpredictable, with revolts in Fiji and New Caledonia, uncertainty in Vanuatu, the border incidents in New Guinea and the troubles in the Philippines, to name but a few. I hope that before we get into too many problems in international affairs Senator Evans learns a little. His greatest mistake was saying that the alliances Australia has-I quote him precisely-are `impeccably well intact'. The reason why this motion is before us today is that those alliances are not intact, particularly the alliance with the United States. I will come to that later.

speech.para: Senator McLean spoke with the usual intellectually bankrupt line that we have come, sadly, to expect from him. What I say about the Democrats equally can be said about nuclear disarmers and others of that ilk. I congratulate Senator McLean on being awarded the golden logie, or the academy award, for the Chipp thespian of the year. He has graduated to the rank that all other Democrats hold-they can be sincere about anything. All we got from the Democrats and the Nuclear Disarmament Party was the usual unilateralist, pacifist, disarmament doctrine and the same sort of propaganda we get out of the Soviet-funded peace groups.

The reason this debate is before us is that there is a need for urgent remedial action to address Australia's seriously weakened security. Redress is necessary because of basic errors and neglect by this Government. The thing that Australia lacks under the Hawke Labor Government is a coherent, reasoned, intellectually thought through policy on Australia's security. Australia's security is not a matter of dealing with issues as they arise day by day. It is not simply a matter of having an Australian defence force. It is not a matter of having some flashy piece of equipment. It is a matter of putting a lot of thought into Australia's security. The one essential thing about Australia's security is that it is the first duty of the Government to protect its people. That is an ever present demand on the Government. It is a long term exercise. It requires all the resources of government to be coordinated and brought to bear to preserve the welfare of Australians in the years ahead in circumstances which simply cannot be foreseen. It is this lack of a coherent, thought-through policy, with all the instruments of the community brought together to give us the security that we are entitled to, that is so missing at present.

What passes for policy under the Australian Labor Party is a mixture of the political mythology of the ALP in seeing things it wants to see in the region and in Australia's association with other countries and what the Government wants to spend on defence at the time. So the realities of the situation are concealed behind the facade of newspeak-`the credible contingencies'. For `credible contingencies' read `What Mr Beazley thinks he wants to pay for defence'. He writes the scenario to meet the expenditure that he makes. `Constrained establishments' is another of the buzz phrases being used at present. `Constrained establishments' means that the force structure and postings to units are reduced to whatever manpower or womanpower is available in the Services. It has nothing to do with the organic needs of the units. We have been beguiled into accepting that constrained establishments are the reality, whereas they are a fiction. Sadly, at present the constrained establishments are not even being met. We are way below them.

Let me come to the reason why we had to put this motion before the Senate today. The defence of Australia is concerned not only with Australia's essential interests but also with the interests of the region. We, on this side of the chamber, believe that our interests are involved very much in regional peace and security. We have to protect our trade routes. We have to be able to project power. We can do that only through a system of alliances. We cannot do it on our own.
When we look at the defence White Paper, The Defence of Australia, published last year, which the Government quotes as its bible, we find that on page one, chapter one, paragraph 1.2 states:
This policy of defence self-reliance is pursued within a framework of alliances and agreements.

I will come back to that in a minute. In the Government's own words, the alliances of Australia are extremely fundamental to our security. What led Senator Newman to put this motion of urgency before the Senate this afternoon can be considered on two planes: first, we had a bicentennial naval review. Australia invited navies to send ships and crews to this country to help us celebrate our Bicentenary. The Government failed to honour the obligations that were binding on Australia towards our guests. At one level there is a gross discourtesy and a gross dishonour involved in inviting people to this country and then putting the crews and the ships physically at risk in the way the Government did.

The second plane concerns the danger the Government did to the Australian alliances by refusing to supply support facilities for those ships when they were here. Australia is part of the Western democratic union of nations. We share their common defence policies. That gives us great benefits, but hand in hand with those benefits are obligations that are binding on us. One of the points that seem to be overlooked by the Democrats and by the disarmers is that alliances are not made between parties that are in power at the time. They are not things that can be acquired on a day to day basis as governments change. They are fundamental and long term, and they are between governments; they are not between parties. Therefore, they require the bipartisan support of the parliament as a whole and they have to be kept and worked at.

The first thing of note in the ships visits was the absence of tugs. When I was in the United States and in the United Kingdom three weeks before the bicentennial review, defence officials at the highest level in both countries expressed concern about problems they might have with the Seamen's Union. And well they might be worried about the Seamen's Union because it is controlled by the pro-Soviet elements of the Australian Communist Party. It has a 50-year history of supporting the foreign affairs policies of the Soviets. Because the Government lacked the moral and political courage to take the Seamen's Union on, ships and crews were put at risk, particularly in Melbourne and Adelaide when bad weather prevented those ships docking.

The Government's approach to buy tugs is a coward's way out. It treats the symptoms but not the problem. It does not get over the problem of the picket lines that were formed at Port Kembla, of the crews being spat on and physically abused, and all the other degradations that were heaped on them by the far Left and the pro-Soviet agents. Far more serious than that was the failure to grant dry docking facilities. This is why the alliances are awry. In 1983 the Government backed off from providing facilities for the HMS Invincible when it was in distress. This year, it failed to support the HMS Edinburgh when it needed dry-docking facilities. The facts of life are that the British Navy has a ship visit frequency to Australia of less than one visit a year. The Americans come here for at least 60 ship visits a year. They know they face the certainty that a ship will rub a propeller against a dockyard or a wall and that that ship will need dry- docking facilities. It is Australia's obligation to be able to provide those facilities. This Government has shown that it does not have the capacity to do that. So our alliances are in disarray because the Government has not honoured them when it has been put to the test. If those alliances are not honoured, we do not have the strength in our security that we should have. Owing to the fact that some Ministers have cut into the time available to debate this matter, I am now out of time, and with regret I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Newman's) be agreed to.
