speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I table the revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988. I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988
Mr President, this Bill will implement measures to attack the last remaining area of widespread tax evasion in our economy.
It builds upon the unprecedented action this Government has already taken in the past 5 1/2 years to close the net on tax evasion and avoidance.

Right from the beginning of our period in office we announced our intention to act retrospectively against any new avoidance schemes that emerged, in one stroke wiping out a large part of the professional tax avoidance industry.
That overriding commitment to nullify any reward from avoidance has been backed up by a host of specific measures aimed at particular schemes that threatened the revenue.
At the same time we have given the Tax Office the necessary resources in staff and equipment to do its job properly.
But much more than that, through the most comprehensive tax reform process in Australia's history, we have turned the whole psychology of avoidance on its head.
The integrity of the tax system has been restored.
Today people much more readily comply, simply because lower rates make compliance less of a burden.
But if they choose to evade, they run the risk of much stiffer penalties, some of which had not previously been up-dated since 1936.
At the same time the old loop-holes have been eliminated and closed off.
Income derived from capital gains is now taxed on the same basis as income derived from employment.
Fringe benefits are no longer tax preferred, the deduction for entertainment has been removed and people claiming tax deductions now have to maintain proper records.
All of the proceeds of these and the other measures we have taken have been fully devoted to cutting personal income tax rates.
The result is that we now have a genuinely progressive personal income tax scale.
That is in complete contrast to the situation before, when what at first sight appeared a highly progressive scale was in reality highly regressive.
Higher income people walked around it while lower income P.A.Y.E. taxpayers carried much more than their share.
Mr President, the same principle of lower rates, tougher enforcement and fewer concessions has been extended to the corporate sector.
As recent publicity testifies, the Tax Commissioner has devoted a large part of his increased audit resources to a crackdown on company tax avoidance.
I make it clear to the so-called `Tax Industry' that the commissioner's actions in this area receive the full support of the Government.
However, I stress that there is something much more fundamental than increased enforcement activity underlying the improvement in compliance from the company sector.
By implementing the new imputation system of company tax we have changed the whole basis of company tax collections for the better.
The new system allows tax-free dividends to be paid to shareholders if tax has already been paid at the company level.
In other words, it removes the double taxation of dividends, and in doing so it completely reverses the previous incentive for companies to minimise their tax payments.
Today, managers who arrange their corporate affairs so as to minimise tax will only be depriving their shareholders of tax-free dividend payments.
Only now is there a growing recognition of the massive shift in favour of the psychology of compliance that has been brought about by the imputation system.
In this way its impact is totally beneficial-it tips the balance of the system towards companies that earn genuine profits and honestly pay their full tax liability.
Mr President, as I said at the outset, this Bill mounts a fundamental attack on tax evasion, where people use false names, do not declare income, or fail to lodge returns.
The measures contained in the Bill will attack these practices by increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian Taxation Offices' income matching system.
In doing that, they will return to the revenue $2,200 million over the next 10 years.
All of this money will be redistributed in the form of tax cuts.
There is a clear need for action to clamp down on these evasion practices.

To take one recent example, an inspection of the employment details of a firm with an annual wages bill of some $13 million revealed that less than $2 million had been included in returns lodged by employees with the Tax Office.
The Tax Office estimates that tax properly payable was in excess of $5 million.
In another case, in a firm with some 800 employees, over 400 resigned hurriedly on hearing of the arrival of Tax Office inspectors.
That they were being less than honest with their tax affairs can be gauged from the fact that they have left behind almost $120,000 in unclaimed severance pay.

The case for concerted action against such evasion is reinforced by the opportunity recently allowed by the Tax Commissioner for people who have not been lodging returns to do so without penalty or prosecution if they did by 31 October 1988.
For those who did not take up the Commissioner's invitation, the file number arrangements now being introduced will provide a trial for future strong enforcement action by his office.
Mr President, the Government fully shares the genuine concerns in the community for the protection of privacy.
For this reason we have introduced into the Parliament a revised general Privacy Bill.
The revised Privacy Bill includes provisions relating to the tax file number.
More specifically, the Government has also been determined to include very strict privacy safeguards in the present Bill.
There will be no requirement on people to produce a card or any other evidence of their tax file number.

No other government or non-government agency will have access to the tax office file number registration system, nor will they be able to use an individual's tax file number for any registration system of their own.
In addition the Bill contains a range of quite specific privacy safeguards.

New offences punishable by a penalty of up to $10,000 or two years imprisonment are proposed for a person who in unauthorised circumstances requires or requests another person to quote his or her file number, keeps a record of another person's file number, discloses another person's file number or uses another person's file number.
While the tax office has an exemplary record in maintaining the confidentiality of taxpayer information, this Bill further toughens the law against disclosure.
It doubles to $10,000 or two years imprisonment the penalties that already apply to unauthorised release of information by tax office employees.
An equivalent offence is being introduced for disclosure of information obtained in unauthorised circumstances by non-employees.
The Commissioner will also be able to obtain an injunction to prevent unauthorised disclosure of information.
Mr President, I will now turn to the major features of the Bill.
As foreshadowed in the Treasurer's statement in May, extensive consultations have been held with industry groups affected by the proposals.
Those discussions have proved fruitful and the views expressed have, where possible, been incorporated in the arrangements.
Before doing so I should record the Government's appreciation for the constructive way in which industry groups have approached the discussions with tax office officials.
The Treasurer and tax officials have also discussed these measures with members of the Opposition, and in particular, the shadow Treasurer.
I believe that the Opposition has approached this issue constructively, and has made a number of positive suggestions which have been incorporated in this Bill.
In particular, the Government has adopted the Opposition's suggestions on extending a withholding tax system to interest paid on bank accounts where no tax file number is quoted.
This is in lieu of the original proposal to freeze bank accounts.
The Government has also agreed to adopt the Opposition's suggestion that a similar provision apply to dividend payments on shares.
This means that people will not be obliged to quote their file number to enter into a relevant transaction or operate an investment account.
However, prior to receiving income from those investments the taxpayer would be able to quote his or her file number to avoid tax being deducted from the income by the payer.
Further, the Government has accepted the Opposition's suggestion that the tax file numbering scheme be made completely voluntary.
The Bill now ensures that taxpayers will in all circumstances retain the right to elect to have tax withheld at source rather than quote their tax file number.
Another matter on which we have been able to agree with the opposition is that the tax file number legislation should not commence before the privacy legislation.
The tax file number Bill now ensures that the file number system will commence on the same day as the privacy legislation that has the general support of the Opposition.

As I stated, the essential purpose of the new file number arrangements is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian taxation office's income matching system as a means of furthering the attack on tax evasion.

That system presently relies on names and addresses to match details contained in taxpayers' returns with those supplied to the tax office on, for example, interest and dividend advices received from companies.
By providing for the use of tax file numbers rather than just names and addresses, the measures incorporated in this Bill will substantially improve the matching process.
By way of example, the present reliance on names and addresses means that around 30 per cent of interest reports cannot be readily matched.
Subject to certain extensions to ensure comprehensive coverage, the new arrangements will apply to the principal areas in which income reports are already received by the tax office.
The first of these is employment.

After the first phase of the new arrangements are commended by proclamation those starting a new job or changing jobs will be able to quote their file number on an employment declaration to their employer.
If they do not, tax will be deducted from their pay at the highest rate, plus the medicare levy.
Later the arrangements will extend to all employees who will be asked to lodge with their employer a revised income tax instalment declaration form and quote their file number.
These arrangements will extend to recipients of unemployment or sickness benefits.
Pensioners, including age, invalid and service pensioners, will not be required to quote a file number; nor will children under 16 who do not earn enough to have tax taken out of their pay.
The second phase of the implementation of the scheme will be its extension to investment uses.
The investment areas to be covered by the legislation fall into two groups.
First, interest income received from investments with banks and other financial institutions and with companies, government and semi-government authorities and solicitors' trust funds.
Second, dividends from share investments and distributions from cash management and property trusts.
In the May statement it was announced that the investment use arrangements would be phased in over two years from 1 July 1990.
However, discussions with organisations have established that, provided there were adequate lead time, phasing arrangements were unnecessary and were, in any event, difficult to administer.
Revised implementation arrangements now decided on will enable file numbers to be quoted for all new accounts opened or investments made on or after 1 July 1991.
The quotation requirement will also apply for existing accounts or investments at that date.
To assist in the administration of these, people will be able to quote their file numbers in respect of existing investments from 1 July 1990.
The Government has also considered views expressed about the severity of the original sanction for non-quotation.
The Government has now decided to align the investment sanction with that proposed for employment.

That is, where people have elected not to quote their file number at the time any interest or income distribution is payable, tax will be withheld at the maximum marginal rate, plus the medicare levy.

In light of the new sanction arrangements and administrative difficulties identified in relation to the original proposals, the quotation arrangements for investments in shares in public companies will apply to pre-existing shareholdings at 1 July 1991, and not just new investments, as was originally proposed.
In this way the rules for shares will apply on an equivalent basis to that for other forms of investments.
The general rule is that the withholding sanction will apply to interest or income distributions made on or after 1 July 1991.
In the case of shares the withholding sanction will apply on a pro rata basis to the extent that the dividend is not a franked dividend.
As with employment, deductions made under these arrangements will not be a final tax.
A person will be required to include total investment income in his or her income tax return, and credit will be allowed for any amounts deducted.
Early access to funds withheld will only be possible in certain hardship cases.
There will be a range of exemptions to these investment uses.

For accounts with banks, building societies and credit unions in existence at 1 July 1991, there will be no need to quote a file number where interest is payable at a rate that is less than $120 per annum.
This reflects the original proposal to exclude pre-existing accounts with a balance of less than $1000.
Financial institutions have advised that they cannot efficiently administer a system that distinguishes accounts by reference to account balances.
A file number will be able to be used in relation to all new accounts opened after 1 July 1991 irrespective of the level of interest paid.

Mr president the bill ensures that people receiving any part of an age, invalid or other pension from the Department of Social Security, or service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, will have no need to quote a tax file number to operate bank or similar accounts, buy shares, or have dealings with other financial institutions.

A person in receipt of any part of an eligible pension, benefit or allowance will be taken to have quoted a tax file number to a financial institution or other investment body upon the lodgment of a declaration with the investment body.
This exemption will not apply to people receiving unemployment or sickness benefits, since in these cases there can be no expectation that the recipient will permanently remain out of the work force.

Children under the age of 16 who do not have a tax file number will also have no need to obtain one for banking and other financial transactions, provided interest is payable at a rate that is less than $420 per annum.
This exemption does not extend to dividend income.

In order to ensure that financial institutions will have no need to quote their tax file number when making loans to their corporate or government customers such loans have been removed from the investment categories for which tax file numbers might be used.

As a further measure designed to improve the efficiency of the income matching system, the Bill will also introduce an obligation on employers and investment bodies who store information on computer to supply information reports to the commissioner in a form suitable for processing by the tax office computer system.
Organisations will not be required to establish computer storage systems where they do not already exist.

For those who presently store information on computer, there will be exemptions from the requirements where meeting the commissioner's specifications for transmission of data would create substantial difficulties.
Mr President, as was announced by my colleague, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, there will be one other use for the tax file number.
That is, as part of the higher education contributions scheme, students choosing to pay their contributions throughout the tax system will need to have a tax file number.
The legislative authority for that use of tax file numbers is included separately in the legislation introduced for the higher education contributions scheme.
I stress at this point, that the same strict privacy safeguards I have outlined applying to this Bill apply to the use of the tax file number under the higher education contributions scheme.
Mr President, as I said earlier, the measures in the Bill will result in retrieving substantial revenue that would otherwise remain uncollected.
It is estimated that revenue will progressively build up from 1988-89 to the point where an additional $337 million annually will be collected by 1993-94.
Those who choose to oppose these measures are choosing to allow those who are cheating on the tax system to continue to do so at the expense of the more honest members of our community.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
PRIVACY BILL 1988

The first purpose of this new Privacy Bill is, like its 1986 predecessor, to regulate the collection, handling and use by Commonwealth Departments and agencies of information about individuals. The Privacy Bill will establish an independent privacy guardian, the Privacy Commissioner, within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, to oversee these matters and handle complaints. In addition, the Bill provides guidelines for the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information which all tax file number information users are required to comply with.

At the present time, our privacy rights are protected by various existing branches of the law which provide limited protection. The laws on defamation, breach of confidence, copyright and passing off can be used to prevent unauthorised circulation of personal information or comment in various circumstances. Also, statutory secrecy provisions in Commonwealth legislation such as section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the vigilance of Parliamentary bodies and other community groups have been important in maintaining and promoting the individual's right to privacy.

The enormous developments in technology for the processing of information are providing new and, in some respects, undesirable opportunities for the greater use of personal information. These developments have focused attention on the need for the regulation of the collection and use of personal information by Government agencies and for an independent community spokesperson for privacy. The Privacy Commissioner will ensure that some balance is brought to the debate as to the desirability of using the opportunities provided by new information technology to their fullest extent.

There is no doubt that with the greater range of services being provided, Governments are accumulating more personal information about individuals in order to provide those services efficiently and effectively. This, together with the ever-increasing capacity of modern computers to search and process information offers significant potential for invasion of personal privacy by misuse. Also, the legitimate needs of agencies in acquiring personal information and the use made of it must be balanced against the need to sustain personal privacy. It is now clear that legislation is necessary to meet the challenge that information technology is posing for the individual's right to retain some measure of personal privacy. Again, the Privacy Commissioner will have a role in providing advice to Government in this area.

Internationally, there is an increasing trend for Governments to enact privacy legislation. The Council of Europe's Convention on Data Protection and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines on Personal Privacy have been developed to encourage countries to take privacy protection measures. Australia has formally signified its intention to adhere to the Guidelines and in so doing to take into account in any privacy legislation the principles set out in those Guidelines. Most European countries, the USA and Canada have enacted privacy protection legislation. It is now an appropriate time for Australia to enact such legislation.

The Government has been giving detailed consideration for some time to comprehensive information privacy protection legislation. In December 1983 a very detailed report and recommendations were received from the Law Reform Commission following a reference to the Commission in 1976. The recommendations included draft legislation which drew on the OECD Guidelines. In 1986 this Government introduced privacy legislation. There has been considerable comment and debate on the proposals contained in that Bill. The Government has taken account of those comments in formulating the current Bill.

The Scheme of the Privacy Bill is to enunciate a series of rules, called Information Privacy Principles, which are based on the Principles recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its draft legislation. Under the Principles, Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector. An agency collecting personal information from the individual to whom the information relates must see that that person is generally aware of such things as the purpose for which the information is being collected, whether it is compulsory to supply that information and the collector's usual disclosure practices in relation to that information. The Principles require agencies, when both collecting and retaining information, to see that it is relevant to the purpose of collection, up-to-date and complete. Before using any information, agencies must also check its accuracy.
``Personal information'' is widely defined to include anything-fact, true or false, or opinion-that reasonably identifies an individual.

The Principles require agencies to store information records securely against loss or misuse. They are to provide information about the types of personal information they hold. Subject to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 exemptions, they are to provide an individual with access to his or her personal information records and to make corrections for accuracy, relevance and completeness. Subject to certain specific exceptions, notably for law enforcement and preservation of life, information may not be used for a purpose or disclosed to a person other than with the agreement of the individual concerned. The exceptions recognise that any claim for privacy by an individual must be considered against equally justified claims by other individuals and the community.

This legislation also recognises the special nature of medical research in particular epidemiological research. To that end provision has been made to give the Privacy Commissioner and the National Health and Medical Research Council a role in the development and approval of privacy guidelines in the conduct of such research.

Commonwealth agencies will be required to comply with the Information Privacy Principles. A breach of the Principles will be deemed by the Bill to be an ``interference with privacy''. Under the Bill an individual will be able to complain to the Privacy Commissioner about alleged interferences with privacy, who will attempt to resolve the allegations by conciliation and, failing that, make binding determinations against agencies, including determinations for compensation and costs.
In effect, the Privacy Commissioner will be the means by which there will be accountability to the public on the use by Government of their personal information.

The Commissioner will be empowered to undertake random audits of agencies' databases to ensure their adherence to the Information Privacy Principles. To help agencies achieve compliance with the Principles, the Privacy Commissioner will be able to give advisory opinions, issue guidelines and examine proposed enactments for privacy implications. Where an agency believes that a current or proposed practice that may breach the Principles is nevertheless essential to its operations, it will be able to seek from the Commissioner a determination allowing the practice to continue or go ahead without risk of its being found to be an interference with privacy. Such a determination may be granted only if the Commissioner is satisfied that the public interest in permitting the practice substantially outweighs the public interest in adherence to the Principles. Such determinations will be able to be disallowed by the Parliament.
The Information Privacy Principles in the Privacy Bill will apply to Commonwealth Departments and agencies to the same extent that the FOI Act applies to them.

Since the 1986 Bill the Government has introduced the tax file number legislation which has substantial penalties for unauthorised requests for, recording and disclosure of tax file numbers. The Privacy Bill supplements those protections by providing additional privacy protections by way of requiring that tax file number users comply with statutory guidelines. The Privacy Commissioner, in consultation with the proposed Privacy Advisory Committee, will issue guidelines for the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information to assist the Commissioner of Taxation and all bodies and individuals lawfully using tax file numbers on what measures should be taken to protect privacy interests. These guidelines will be reviewable by the Parliament which will be able to disallow them.

To ensure that tax file number legislation does not come into operation without adequate privacy protection measures being in place, the Bill includes interim guidelines. These are expressed in broad and general terms, and it is expected that after consultation they will be replaced by more specific guidelines.

The Privacy Commissioner will be able to investigate complaints about alleged misuse of tax file numbers and attempt to conciliate and, failing that, make determinations, including a determination for compensation or costs. Such determinations will not be formally binding as between the parties. If compliance with the Privacy Commissioner's determination is not forthcoming then either the Privacy Commissioner or the complainant will be able to apply to the Federal Court to have the determinations enforced. Where a complaint is made and the Privacy Commissioner considers that there may be a breach of the offence provisions of the Taxation Administration Act 1953, the Privacy Commissioner is required to inform the appropriate law enforcement authorities of the complaint and suspend his investigations until the relevant law enforcement processes are completed.
I turn to the Government's approach to privacy regulation in relation to the private sector.

As I have indicated, the Information Privacy Principles only apply to Commonwealth agencies. Unlike the tax file number guidelines they do not apply to the private sector. The Privacy Commissioner is required to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information that are consistent with the OECD Guidelines on Personal Privacy. The Commissioner is required to report annually to the Government on the success of these arrangements. The Commissioner will be available to advise private sector bodies on privacy measures and it is hoped that corporations will take significant steps in the future in this regard. The Government will re-assess this approach following advice from the Privacy Commissioner. Of course, the tax file number guidelines will apply to the private sector.

I mentioned earlier that the law of confidence is an important existing means of protecting privacy in some circumstances. The Bill includes some limited extensions of the law of confidence recommended by the Law Reform Commission which will further enhance privacy protection. The Bill also includes amendments of the FOI Act to extend the opportunities for individuals to have access to their personal affairs records and establishes the requirement for such individuals to be alerted to requests for access to those records by others. It also makes essentially machinery amendments to ensure that privacy complaints wrongly directed to other agencies are transferred to the Privacy Commissioner for investigation under the Privacy Bill without inconvenience to the complainant.
The Office of Privacy Commissioner, to be established under the Privacy Bill, is expected to have a direct cost to the Government of around $970,000 in a full-year operation.

The Privacy Bill is the first legislation in Australia to establish a comprehensive code of privacy protection and to provide an enforceable right to privacy. It will provide a practical means for persons who have been adversely affected by a failure to comply with those standards to seek redress. It will also provide an effective mechanism for safeguarding the rights of individuals in relation to the tax file number scheme.
I commend the Bill to Senate.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I raise a matter of great concern to a large number of Australians, including many of my South Australian constituents, namely, the policy of cultural genocide now being undertaken by the Ceausescu regime in Romania. I intend to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the majority of my speech so that it can be handled within the few minutes available to me.

speech.para: I refer in particular to a petition containing more than 5,000 signatures-the largest tabled in the Senate this year-which I had the honour to present to the Senate on Wednesday. The petition, which contained the signatures of 5,247 South Australians, said that the Romanian Government's rural resettlement program, which involved the brutal razing of villages with fewer than 5,000 inhabitants, amounted to cultural genocide. The petition was organised by the President of the Council of the Hungarian Associations in South Australia, Mr Joseph Garamy. Mr Garamy is also the President of the Ethnic Communities Council of South Australia.

The Romanian regime intends to raze more than 7,000 villages-Romania has about 13,000 villages in all-in order to force the inhabitants into 500 new `agro-industrial complexes' in an attempt to somehow improve Romania's agricultural efficiency. Ceausescu has promised that the `agro-industrial complexes' will provide housing with electricity and running water. But the fact is that village inhabitants are to be forced out of villages and into massive concrete apartment blocks in artificial townships. It has been reported that several villages have already been flattened in test schemes.

Most of these villages are in Transylvania, a region heavily populated by German and Hungarian ethnic minorities. People of Hungarian, Romanian and German descent believe the Romanian regime's policy will destroy the culture and identity of the people of Transylvania. Transylvania was part of Hungary until 1918, and is now home to 2.5 million Hungarians. They constitute the largest ethnic minority in Europe.

Mr Deputy President, I should note to the Senate that I have visited Transylvania and I have direct knowledge of the minority language communities, especially the Hungarian and German communities in this region. I seek leave to incorporate the middle section of my speech in Hansard.

talk.start.para: —I think that the Senate should be aware how much the honourable senator wishes to incorporate. How many pages does he propose to incorporate?
—Everything but the last few paragraphs.
—How many pages? I think that we should have some idea.
—Everything but the last page.

interject.speaker: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?

interject.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Ceausescu-who has ruled Romania as a dictator since 1967-has surrounded himself with the trappings of a Stalinist personality cult.

On his 70th birthday last January, three national museums mounted official homages to his accomplishments, film documentaries were repeatedly featured on Romanian television in which choirs sang hymns of gratitude for his existence.

A fifth of Bucharest, a city once called the Paris of the east for its gracious architecture, is being razed and rebuilt in heroic socialist style as the ageing Ceausescu attempts to build a monument to himself.

Australians had a glimpse of the Ceausescu megalomania when the Romanian government paid for full-page advertisements to be run in Australian newspapers prior to the Ceausescu visit earlier this year.

That advertisement featured portraits of Ceausescu and his wife, obviously taken very many years ago. The advertisement claimed: ``Australia welcomes President Nicolae Ceausescu and Mrs Elena Ceausescu of Romania. President Ceausescu asserts himself not only as a remarkable leader of his country but also as a brilliant architect of the struggle for development in the world and the establishment of a new international economic order''.
I for one could not believe the gall and crassness displayed by the Romanian government in placing this advertisement in the Australian press.
How dare the Romanian regime claim to speak on behalf of the Australian people. How dare they presume Ceausescu was welcomed here by the Australian people.

It may be true that he was welcomed by the Australian Labor Government, which was no doubt more interested in the size of Romania's wallet than the gross violations of human rights carried out by the Ceausescu regime.
I found it outrageous, as did many other Australians, that this Labor Government played host to Ceausescu and by so doing, helped legitimise his regime in the eyes of the world.
Many nations look to Australia-particularly at international forums, like the United Nations-as a world leader in matters of human rights, democratic practices and liberal freedoms.
This image was badly tarnished by the Ceausescu visit in April this year. And you don't have to look too far to find out why.
Australian journalists who have visited Romania over the past few months paint a very dark picture of that troubled country.

Their accounts talk of dimly lit streets, there are queues everywhere. The food is of poor quality. For the past eight winters, meat, butter, sugar and cooking oil are rationed, as have been heat and electricity.

Huge queues form for food. Hunger is widespread, malnutrition is on the rise. Typewriters 70 years old sell for the equivalent of a month's salary-and a buyer would have to register the purchase with the police.
Secret police follow foreigners everywhere. They ring the western embassies, ready to prevent Romanian citizens from seeking refuge there.
Already, between 15,000 and 20,000 refugees have fled to Hungary-and Hungarian officials believe another 30,000 are wanting to leave Romania.

One refugee said he left because of brutal suppression of the Hungarian ethnic minorities. This refugee, a 33-year-old worker from Cluj, said he left Romania ``because the mere utterance of our language is put down with truncheons''.
There can be little doubt that ethnic Hungarians are persecuted and prevented from teaching or writing books in their own language.

It is reported that ethnic Hungarians are drafted into the armed services, where they are given jobs too dangerous for ordinary Romanians, including working in salt mines and in the insufferable, mosquito-ridden swamp areas towards the Baltic Sea.
A letter of protect, written by a former lecturer at the University of Cluj in Transylvania, Mrs Doina Cornea, wrote:
Was the brutal collectivisation forced on the majority of the rural population not enough?
Was it not enough to transform the Romanian peasants into a sort of proletariat and thus erode their moral and religious structures, their outlook, customs and traditions?
Will the last remnants of our unhappy peasantry now be shattered as well?
A village is built on shared suffering and joy; it represents the love of people for their land and for the house where they were born.
A village also means the graveyard where their parents are buried, the church where they got married and had their babies christened and prayed in their hour of need.
By demolishing the peasant home you strike at the very soul of the people.

Such is the reputation of the regime, that the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, has on several occasions, signalled the Kremlin's concern over the maverick economic and political policies of Ceausescu.
Perestroika and glasnost have no meaning in Bucharest.

Part of the problem lies in Ceausescu's decision in 1980 to pay off the nation's $10 billion debt. He has reduced the debt to just $5 billion in seven years, but at great social cost to the Romanian people.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has said that the actions in Transylvania were a `fundamental human rights violation' and were `obviously an important issue' to Australia. But he also said:

speech.para: All we can do is hope our voice will be heard. As a trading partner, there is hopefully a better chance that we'll be taken notice of.

Today in the Senate, I asked the Foreign Minister what protests the Australian Government had made. He confirmed directly that the destruction of rural villages is taking place. He expressed concern in similar terms to my own at this destruction. But I did not hear in his reply of any specific protests except two diplomatic messages. I ask the Government once more to give urgent and careful consideration to more significant Australian protest.

One of the groups in Australia which have been active in bringing the plight of rural Romanians to the attention of the public has been the Save Transylvania Committee. This Committee has been extremely upset by the continued involvement of the Australian Government in trade with Romania. Romania is Australia's biggest market in eastern Europe after the Soviet Union. Last year, Australian exports worth $115m were dispatched to Romania, while we imported Romanian goods valued at $13m.

The Government will no doubt say that, by trading with Romania, Australia is in no way sanctioning the repression for which the Ceausescu regime is notorious. However, as the Save Transylvania Committee has pointed out, it is hypocritical to have restrictions on trade and cultural contact with South Africa while being happy to maximise trading and cultural links with the brutally oppressive regime in Bucharest.

According to an assessment in the World Human Rights Guide of last year, Romania rates below both Chile and South Africa in its observance of human rights. I suggest that the Government should have a more consistent approach to its dealings with nations that abuse the human rights of its citizens. I recognise that Australia has a limited influence in eastern Europe. But action can be taken to join the international isolation of Romania. This Government is simply not doing enough.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday in the House of Representatives the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) made statements under parliamentary privilege accusing Mr George Raptis of A. Raptis and Son Fishing Co. of making a donation of $250,000 to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. Allegedly this was carried out in order to change a decision to award the sale of the Queensland Fish Board premises at Colmslie to Mr Raptis's company. There are other premises throughout Queensland also. The statement is untrue and was based on a statutory declaration given to Mr Wright by Mr Roland Cantley of Cairns.

speech.para: Let me say categorically that Mr Wright's statement is not true. He has made incorrect statements based on misinformation given to him by Mr Roland Cantley. I have checked with Mr Raptis. I have checked with officers of the National Party of Australia. Both deny that Mr Raptis ever gave any donation to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation or the National Party head office, as alleged.

The National Party Bjelke-Petersen Foundation was wound up in 1982. The National Party books, including details of the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation, are open to examination by the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. If any such donation was made I am sure Mr Fitzgerald will bring it out, as I understand Mr Wright has forwarded copies of relevant correspondence to the inquiry. In September 1987, five years after the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation was wound up, Mr Raptis acquired the Queensland Fish Board from the Queensland Government. It would have been impossible to make a donation to that organisation at the time stated by Mr Wright.

The facts are as follows: Mr George Raptis, director of A. Raptis and Son, took possession of the Queensland Fish Board in about September 1987 after the company had tendered for the Board, with a number of other companies. Mr Raptis gave a commitment to the Queensland Government that he would process the prawn catch from his gulf and northern Australian fishing fleet at the Queensland Fish Board premises if awarded the tender, rather than at the Adelaide plant where the processing was taking place at the time. Mr Raptis outlined that he would use his Adelaide plant to process fish caught in the Bass Strait and the Great Australian Bight. His commitment to process the northern prawn catch in Queensland provided an additional 250 jobs for Queenslanders. Mr Raptis also agreed to spend millions of dollars with Queensland contractors in upgrading the very run-down Queensland Fish Board plant.

Near the time of the Queensland Government making its decision fear was expressed by the Queensland fishing industry that P. Manettas and Co., the other tenderer which had large wholesale outlets in Sydney, would have been able to manipulate prices. Mr Bob Baudino, manager of B. and M. Public Affairs Consultants, who was hired by Manettas to find out why its offer was not accepted by the Queensland Government, described the reputation of P. Manettas and his information was that reports dealing with the business approach of Manettas described it as ruthless. Mr Bob Baudino in his brief to Manettas also said the decision to proceed with Raptis by the Queensland Cabinet was not necessarily based on the bottom line as money was not the overriding factor. The Queensland Government had to be concerned about what was best for the fisherman and the buyers. This was the Queensland Government's priority consideration.

I believe it was for those two reasons that the Queensland Government made the decision that it did in respect of the future of the Fish Board. I seek leave to table the Baudino brief forwarded to John Diacopoulos, the solicitor acting for Manettas.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —George Raptis's company was also required to maintain the wet fish auction and to continue to supply seafood to Queensland retail fish outlets and wholesalers. This is not a profitable operation. The facts are that George Raptis's company has met every commitment made to the Queensland Government. He has spent a huge amount of money in upgrading the plant and equipment of the Colmslie Fish Board. He has provided over 300 jobs for Queenslanders. He has maintained the wet fish auction.

speech.para: Last night I contacted Mr Keith Wright and informed him I believed the accusations were wrong and ill founded. He gave me a set of documents on which his allegations were based. After reading these documents I am convinced that Mr Wright has made an error in judgment based on very questionable information he received from Mr Roland Cantley. The serious charge Mr Wright made in parliament yesterday, that George Raptis gave the Bjelke-Petersen Fund $250,000 to influence the decision made in relation to the Queensland Fish Board premises, has caused Mr Raptis hurt and embarrassment in his private and business life.

The fact is that the Queensland Cabinet, the then Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and the Minister for Primary Industries, the Hon. Neville Harper, all acted in the best interests of the Queensland fishing industry by allowing the sale of the Queensland Fish Board to A. Raptis and Son. Mr Raptis finds himself in the position of being caught up as an unwilling player in a political game and he clearly does not deserve that. I call on Mr Wright to apologise in parliament to Mr Raptis at the earliest possible opportunity.

speech.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: —I will see that the speech made by Senator Teague, and the information he gave along with the documents he tabled, are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). Senator Boswell raised some points particularly in relation to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, and the book or books from the National Party of Australia concerning donations given to the National Party. I feel sure that the Fitzgerald inquiry will be quite capable of deciding whether the points Senator Boswell raised are correct or whether the points raised by someone else are correct. In the long term the Fitzgerald inquiry will be able to determine the validity of Senator Boswell's claims.

speech.para: Senator Boswell also raised the matter of the fishing industry and Mr George Raptis. I will pass those comments on to the Minister concerned and I will make sure that a copy of Senator Boswell's speech goes to Mr Keith Wright, a member of the other place, in case he may want to answer some of the things the honourable senator has corrected him on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

question.speaker: Sanders Sen N.K.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 15 December 1987:

question.para: (1) Did the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service (QNPWS) refuse to supply the Minister's Kangaroo Advisory Committee (KAC) with background material justifying their proposed 1988 Kangaroo Management Program.
(2) Is the QNPWS Program for 1988 itself only 7 pages long.
(3) Has the Queensland Government insisted that the Program too be kept secret.
(4) Why did the KAC recommend 1988 kangaroo kill quotas for Queensland (2.24 million) to the Minister without the background information needed to justify that quota.
(5) Why are the KAC members required to observe strict confidentiality on many matters raised in the Committee, including the Kangaroo Management Programs of all States.

(6) Given that this confidentiality is maintained until the Programs are approved by the Minister, (a) does it not prevent meaningful public debate on the draft programs; and (b) are members of the public forced to pursue any objections through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, at substantial expense, and with no mandatory effect on the Programs.
(7) Is the Minister aware of the resignation of the RSPCA representative from the KAC.

(8) Why did the KAC chairman, Professor Derek Ovington, not include dissenting views in his letter of 3 December 1987 to the RSPCA criticising their resignation, despite having sought the views of the KAC Committee members on the draft of that letter.

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, in its initial submission. However, following Federal Court action initiated by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service (QNPWS) over the issue of confidentiality of information, but which was ultimately withdrawn with costs awarded to the Commonwealth, the QNPWS resubmitted its proposed 1988 management program and background material without any requirements on confidentiality.
(2) The 1988 Queensland Kangaroo Management Program is 8 pages including the title page.

(3) No. The QNPWS in its initial submission requested that the proposed management programs remain confidential until approved under Section 10 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. See also (1) above.

(4) In the absence of indirect monitoring and assessment information from the QNPWS, the National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos made recommendations based on past records and the direct monitoring through ground and aerial surveys undertaken by the National Kangaroo Monitoring Unit of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) and the CSIRO.

(5) All members of the National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos at its meeting in December 1987, reaffirmed a previous agreement that all advice to the Minister should remain confidential until the Minister had received the advice and made an announcement on it.

(6) (a) All State wildlife authorities that have submitted kangaroo management programs for approval under S10 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 have their own advisory committees which consider draft programs prior to submission to the Commonwealth. The National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos has been specifically established to provide advice to the Minister on the spectrum of community views on kangaroo management programs and quotas amongst other related kangaroo matters.

(b) Any person or organisation that is affected by the decision of the Minister to approve a management program under Section 10 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Acts 1982 has the right under the Act to make application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in accordance with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
(7) Yes. The RSPCA (Australia) is reconsidering its withdrawal from the National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos.

(8) Professor Derrick Ovington, the Director of ANPWS and the Chairperson of the National Advisory Committee on Kangaroos, provided a copy of his letter of 3 December 1987 to the RSPCA (Australia) to all members of the Committee. The letter took account of comments by Committee members as a whole. The Director also suggested to all Committee members that, if they so wished, they write separately to the RSPCA (Australia) so that it would be properly informed of their views.

question.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 19 May 1988:

question.para: (1) What are the terms of reference of the Ministerial task force directed at stopping the downhill slide in land degradation.
(2) In addition to the formulation of policy initiatives, what other functions will the task force be required to perform.

(3) Will there be any follow up work on the Commonwealth and State Governments' collaborative soil conservation study 1975-77; if so, (a) who will do the necessary survey work; and (b who will pay for it.

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Ministerial Task Force on Soil Conservation was established in May 1988 in recognition that the memberships of the National Farmers' Federation (NFF) and the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF), working jointly with the Government, could add substantial weight to existing efforts to combat land degradation. The Task Force members have been asked to:
(a) provide advice on further policies and programs to achieve a more effective national effort in soil conservation,
(b) evaluate a range of financial assistance measures,
(c) consider aspects of other rural policies which impact on soil conservation, and
(d) develop an appropriate extension and awareness campaign as a means of encouraging effective `grass roots' local, and regional efforts in combating land degradation.
Professor Burton, presiding member of the Federal Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, has now also joined the Task Force.

(2) Other functions will depend on the policy initiatives developed but are expected to involve the respective memberships in both education and an awareness campaign and in local community-based district landcare groups.
(3) Most of the 32 recommendations of the 1975 Commonwealth-States Collaborative Study on soil conservation have now in fact been implemented.

At its meeting in September 1986 the Technical Committee on Soil Conservation reviewed the recommendations contained in the report. Committee members indicated that 22 of the 32 recommendations had been implemented and that of the remaining ten recommendations, nine had been satisfactorily addressed or were of an on-going nature and required no specific action. The final recommendation, relating to training needs for soil conservationists, has since become the subject of a major study by the University of New England. The report, which was recently completed, is under consideration by State and Commonwealth Governments and tertiary education institutions.

In regard to the need for follow-up survey work, it is widely accepted that an updated assessment of the land degradation status of Australia is required. A number of methodologies for such an investment have been tested on a pilot basis. These will be considered for Australia-wide applicability by the Standing Committee on Soil Conservation. Decisions on responsibilities and funding will await the Standing Committee's consideration.

question.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1988:

question.para: (1) What are the cut-off criteria in passenger movement for the construction of an airport fire station facility at country airports.
(2) What are the yearly traffic figures for the Albury airport.

(3) Is the Department of Transport and Communications aware that one third of this traffic is through traffic between Sydney and Melbourne, which may be reduced due to a change in airline policy later this year.

(4) Under these circumstances can the Minister explain why the Department is continuing with plans to build an airport fire station at Albury at a cost of $1.8 million when the local fire station is in close proximity.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The criterion for the provision (or withdrawal) of Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) at domestic aerodromes is 150,000 persons-on-board (pob) scheduled passenger services per calendar year. The pob statistic includes uplift/discharge passengers and transit passengers as well as aircrew.

(2) The latest pob statistic available for Albury Airport is 314,458 for calendar year 1986. It was on the basis of that figure and the then forecast continued growth in passenger activity at Albury that the decision to proceed with the new fire station was endorsed by the Minister for Aviation in 1987.
(3) Yes. Criteria is still met without the transit traffic.

(4) A joint review was commenced on 1st of May 1988 by officers of the Department and the Albury City Council into the most cost-effective method of providing rescue and fire fighting at Albury. That study group has consulted with the Aviation Industry and the NSW Board of Fire Commissioners.

Changes by Air New South Wales and East West Airlines in their pattern of usage of Albury together with other potential future variations in airline usage stemming from deregulation will be taken into consideration. A final decision to proceed with the construction will therefore not be made until a clearer picture of the long term pob forecasts is known and the joint review team's recommendations have been considered.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

question.para: (1) In terms of employment in the manufacturing sector, would the Minister outline Queensland's performance since 1984-85 in comparison with: (a) other States; and (b) Queensland's manufacturing employment in ratio to general employment elsewhere in the State.
(2) What measures are available to the Federal Government on a national basis to lift the efforts of States to attract new manufacturing industry for the benefit of the overall economic effort.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1a) During the period March 1985-March 1988, employment in the manufacturing sector in Queensland grew from 112.6 to 122.6 thousand. This represents an average annual rate of growth of 2.9 % and compares with 1.7% for Australia as a whole.

(1b) The manufacturing sector in Queensland employed between 13.7% and 14.4% of the total Queensland work force during the period. At 31 March 1988 the figure was 14.1% which compares with 17.4% for Australia as a whole.
More details are available in the attached table.

(2) At the national level, the Federal Government is helping the States attract new manufacturing industry by improving the environment for business investment. Appropriate macroeconomic policies have been put in place, accompanied by structural reforms designed to increase the efficiency and flexibility of capital markets. The floating of the currency, the deregulation of the banking sector and the liberalisation of foreign investment guidelines are important examples.

On the wages front, the Accord has moderated the growth in wage rises and locked in the competitive advantage stemming from the depreciation of the currency. Australian wage costs are now competitive with those in comparable developed countries.
Investment in manufacturing has been made more attractive by reducing the corporate tax rate to an internationally competitive 39 cents in the dollar.

Industry and technology policies designed to revitalise mature industries and facilitate the growth of new industries have enhanced the attractiveness of investment in the manufacturing sector. Chief among them are:

the industry plans which have provided a stable and predictable environment, resulting in significantly increased investment, especially in Steel, Passenger Motor Vehicles and Textiles, Clothing and Footwear
the 150% taxation concession for research and development which has stimulated a dramatic growth in R&D investments
the Management and Investment Company scheme which was responsible for the spectacular development of the Australian venture capital market in recent years

the Partnerships for Development program that encourages multinational corporations to expand their research and manufacturing activities in Australia in exchange for a waiver of their offset obligations
the Investment Promotion program, aimed at encouraging overseas investment in Australian manufacturing industries

Foreign investment provides a major supplement to domestic funds available for private investment in the Australian manufacturing sector. The Federal Government welcomes and encourages foreign investment. Foreign investment guidelines have been substantially relaxed, particularly in the case of manufacturing industries. Proposals for investment in manufacturing are generally automatically approved.

The strategy to encourage foreign investment in Australian manufacturing industries was announced and funding provided for it in the 1987-88 budget. The investment promotion program is undertaken jointly by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE).
The investment promotion strategy targets countries with the capacity to invest and Australian industries with the potential to compete internationally. It involves:
publicising Australia's improved industrial relations climate, relevant Government policies and opportunities for investment in specified industries
conducting research to provide a data base for commercial investment decisions and to identify factors inhibiting foreign investment
following up promotional activities to exploit potential interest and bring projects to fruition
helping local and overseas firms make contacts and establish joint ventures
ensuring acceptance of the strategy by State Governments, unions and industry associations
facilitating the dealings of potential investors with these agencies.

The overall increase in bankruptcies is attributable to the substantial increase in non-business bankruptcies, and excessive use of credit is the most consistent cause of these.

The Government is aware of the problem and has taken a number of steps to deal with it. Significant changes have been made to bankruptcy procedures in the Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1987 which should reflect in a reduced number of bankruptcies. The most notable of these is the pre-bankruptcy moratorium or cooling off period, which is due to come into operation later in 1988. This provision should prevent ``mistake'' bankruptcies and encourage debtors to make more use of existing voluntary arrangements with creditors under Part X of the Act.

Other initiatives have been taken. The Government encouraged the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council to conduct a national forum on consumer credit in April 1988 to focus and promote discussion on broad issues in the current debate on consumer credit. The Forum agreed that there is a need for better education of potential credit users as to the implications of credit borrowing and failure to maintain repayment commitments, and that bankruptcy should not be regarded as the only remedy for credit overcommitment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of concern by local residents and environmental experts at the Queensland Government's insistence that an international airport has to be built near Yeppoon.
(2) What effects would the construction and operation of the airport have on the local environment.
(3) Has any survey been taken to show what would be the effects on wildlife, flora and fauna by any such airport development.
(4) Have any consultations been arranged between the Federal and State Governments on this question, or are any envisaged in the near future.

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, my attention has been drawn to reports of concerns by local residents and environmental experts regarding the possible construction of an international airport near Yeppoon.

(2) I understand that a consultant has been appointed by the Iwasaki Company to examine the feasibility of an international airport located near the Yeppoon resort and the environmental implications of such an airport.
(3) I am not aware of any survey of the effects of an airport on the flora and fauna of that area-certainly there has not been a survey on the part of the Commonwealth.
(4) Yes, contact at officials level with the Queensland Government.
